title: State v. Horton
description: In this criminal appeal, the court analyzes a reckless homicide charge in regard to a vehicle collision scenario with a pedestrian.  Additionally, the chain of custody rule is reviewed in connection with the admissibility of a urine test.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

 

  
    
      
        
          
The State, Respondent,
v.
Christopher Clarke Horton, Appellant.
          
        
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Â Gary E. Clary, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3787
Submitted April 6, 2004 â€“ Filed May 3, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
William G. Rhoden, of Gaffney, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Charles H. Richardson, 
  Senior Assistant Attorney General Harold M. Coombs, Jr., all of Columbia; and 
  Solicitor Harold W. Gowdy, III, of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
      
    
  


ANDERSON, J.: Â  Christopher Clarke Horton 
  was indicted for felony driving under the influence causing death (felony DUI) 
  and reckless homicide.Â  The jury returned a verdict of guilty of reckless homicide 
  and not guilty of felony DUI.Â  The trial judge sentenced Horton to ten years 
  imprisonment.Â  We affirm. [1]
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
On September 26, 2001, Gregory Thomas, fourteen years old,
was struck and killed while walking with his family.  Horton was driving
the vehicle that struck Thomas.
At trial, the State presented the testimony of Suzie
Thomas (Gregory's mother) and Geoffrey Thomas (Gregory's nineteen-year-old
brother).  Suzie stated that she, Gregory, and Geoffrey were walking down
the left-hand side of a road near their home shortly after 6:30 p.m.  Suzie
professed that, as they saw a green car approaching, the three crossed the
road.  According to Suzie, even though all three of them looked both ways
before crossing, Gregory was struck by a white car that was coming down the road
"very fast."  Suzie stated that, when she "looked to go
across the road," she did not see the white car.  Suzie and Geoffrey
"made it to the side of the . . . road."  Suzie said Gregory was
"almost on the side of the road on the grass, but he had not made it to the
side of the road."  Suzie declared:

  And when I saw the car coming, I screamed "Gregory,
  get out of the road.  Go to the side."  And as I said that,
  Gregory's right leg went up like he was going to step on the grass.  And
  when he did that, the car hit him and he flew up.

After striking Gregory, the white car proceeded down the
street for approximately 275 feet.  When Horton stopped and exited the
vehicle, Suzie asked: "'Why did you hit my son?'"  Horton
responded: "'[B]ecause he wouldn't get out of my way.'"
On cross-examination, Suzie admitted she did not
"tell any of the police officers about" the green car.  When
queried as to whether she told the officers about Horton's statement that her
"son wouldn't get out of the way," Suzie answered: "I don't
remember.  I don't think so . . . ."  Suzie acknowledged she did
not see Horton's car until it hit Gregory.  The following colloquy occurred
on cross-examination:

  Q. Well, I believe you said that you never saw the white
  car.
  A. No, I never saw the white car until we stepped over, but he was-that's how
  fast he came up on us.
  Q. So you only saw the white car just a split second before it hit your son?
  A. Right when it hit my son.
  Q. So that's the only time that you saw the white car?
  A. Yes.  I heard him.  I heard it and that's when I, you know,
  screamed for Gregory, and then he-before Gregory could step over onto the
  grass, he hit him.

Geoffrey corroborated Suzie's testimony regarding the
facts leading up to the accident.  Geoffrey testified he did not see the
white car when they began to cross the road and did not "hear any
brakes" or see any skid marks after the accident.  Geoffrey did not
testify that Horton made a statement after exiting the white car. 
Officer David H. Burgess, with the South Carolina Highway
Patrol, was the responding officer.  Officer Burgess testified that, upon
reaching the accident scene, he noticed there were no skid marks on the
road.  While sitting beside Horton in his patrol vehicle, Officer Burgess
detected "an odor of alcohol."  Although the officer did not
perform any field sobriety tests and noted that Horton did not slur his speech
or stagger, he opined that Horton was under the influence.  Officer Burgess
stated that Horton's attitude after the accident was unusual, commenting that
Horton was "unemotional."  The officer admitted he did not know
"anything about [a] green car" until the day of trial.
Horton was given a Datamaster test at the Spartanburg
County Detention Center.  Horton registered a 0.03.  Highway Patrol
Officer Russell Joye, who administered the test, testified Horton was
cooperative, and that he did not smell an odor of alcohol on Horton's person.
After the Datamaster test, Officer Joye drove Horton to the hospital for a urine
test.  Horton signed an implied consent form before a urine sample was
collected.  On direct examination, Sue Mobley, a nurse at the hospital who
participated in the urine test, was asked if she smelled any alcohol on
Horton.  Mobley answered: "A slight smell."
Robert Michael Sears, a forensic toxicologist with SLED,
later analyzed the urine sample.  The results of the urine test indicated
the presence of a tetrahydrocannabinol metabolite, hydrocodone, dihydrocodeine,
and benzoylecgonine.  Tetrahydrocannabinol, more commonly known as THC, is
the "pharmacologically active component of marijuana." 
Hydrocodone and dihydrocodeine are opiates.  Benzoylecgonine is a
"major metabolite" of cocaine.  A blood test was not
performed.  Sears declared that "what [he] found in the urine test,
plus the alcohol that was in [Horton's] system," would "affect a
person's ability to drive."  According to Sears, urine tests show
"a history of use," but "not necessarily [the] presence of drugs
in the blood."  On cross-examination, defense counsel posited the
following question to Sears: "So without the blood test, we don't know
whether or not Mr. Horton was under the effects of those drugs at the time of
this accident, do we?"  Sears answered: "That's
correct."  The following exchange occurred between defense counsel and
Dr. David H. Eagerton, chief toxicologist at SLED:

  Q. All right.  So by looking at this evidence here,
  this urine test, it doesn't tell you anything about what was in Mr. Horton's
  blood at the time of this accident, does it?
  A. At exactly the time of the accident, no, it doesn't.  It only tells
  you what was in his blood within that three-day window.

  Horton presented the testimony of 
    Alison Cocoros, the chief investigator for the Spartanburg County Coronerâ€™s 
    Office.Â  Cocoros observed Horton at the accident scene.Â  When asked by defense 
    counsel if she â€œsmell[ed] any odor of alcohol on Mr. Horton that evening when 
    [she] talked to him,â€ Cocoros answered in the affirmative.Â  However, when 
    queried regarding whether Horton appeared to be impaired, she responded: â€œNo, 
    sir.â€Â 
    Cocoros spoke with Suzie and Geoffrey at the 
      hospital on the night of the accident.Â  She declared that neither Suzie 
      nor Geoffrey mentioned a green car â€œcoming in the opposite directionâ€ or 
      any statement made by Horton after the accident.Â  Cocoros stated that Suzie 
      and Geoffrey told her the following when explaining the events leading up 
      to the accident:

    When I asked them what had happened, . . . [t]hey stated 
      that they walked around the curve on Casey Creek Road, that the son Geoff 
      and Ms. Thomas crossed to the right-hand shoulder.Â  Gregory was in the middle 
      of the left-hand lane.Â  They said that they heard a car behind them.Â  They 
      started telling Gregory to get out of the road.Â  Instead of crossing to 
      the left this way, he crossed to the right towards them on this side of 
      the road and a car came around the curve and hit him.

    Kristin Rodgers was Hortonâ€™s passenger 
      on the night of the accident.Â  She testified in his defense.Â  Rodgers stated 
      Horton had two beers at dinner and did not have any problems operating his 
      car.Â  Rodgers discussed the accident:

    We are going down the road.Â  We starting to go around a curve and there is three 
      people walking in the middle of the road, and [Horton] slowed down.Â  A lady 
      and a boy went to the right side of the road and another boy went to the 
      left side of the road to let us through.Â  So we starting to go through them 
      and as we are starting to go through them, the boy from the left side of 
      the road runs back on the right side of the road and thatâ€™s when we hit 
      him. . . . [I]t all happened in a matter of seconds.

    Hortonâ€™s testimony corroborated that of his 
      passenger.Â  He affirmed that he had two beers with dinner, but had drunk 
      no other alcohol that day.Â  Horton denied taking any drugs on the day of 
      the accident.Â  However, he admitted to smoking marijuana and snorting cocaine 
      three days before, and taking a Lortab two days before the accident.Â  Both 
      Horton and Rodgers testified they did not know of anything that Horton could 
      have done to avoid the accident.
    At trial, Horton moved to suppress 
      the results of the urine test, arguing improper procedure, an incomplete 
      chain of custody, and the urine test results were more prejudicial than 
      probative under Rule 403, SCRE.Â  The trial judge denied the motion.Â  At 
      the close of the Stateâ€™s case, Horton moved for a directed verdict on the 
      charges of felony DUI and reckless homicide.Â  This motion was denied.Â  After 
      he presented his case, Horton renewed his motion for a directed verdict, 
      which was denied.Â  The jury returned a guilty verdict as to reckless homicide 
      and a not guilty verdict as to felony DUI.
    ISSUES

  
    
      
        I.  
         Did the trial judge err in failing to grant Hortonâ€™s motion for a directed 
      verdict as to the reckless homicide charge?
      
      
        II.  
         Did the trial judge err in admitting the results of the urine test?
      
      
        III.
         Did the trial judge err in allowing the State to present evidence that 
      Horton lacked remorse?
      
    
  


    LAW/ANALYSIS
    I. 
    Directed Verdict â€“ Reckless Homicide
    Horton argues the trial judge erred in denying
    Horton's motion for a directed verdict as to the reckless homicide
    charge.  We disagree.
    On appeal from the denial of a directed 
      verdict in a criminal case, an appellate court must view the evidence in 
      the light most favorable to the State.Â  State v. Curtis, 356 S.C. 
      622, 591 S.E.2d 600 (2004); State v. Al-Amin, 353 S.C. 405, 578 S.E.2d 
      32 (Ct. App. 2003); State v. Morgan, 352 S.C. 359, 574 S.E.2d 203 
      (Ct. App. 2002).Â  When ruling on a motion for a directed verdict, the trial 
      court is concerned with the existence or nonexistence of evidence, not its 
      weight.Â  State v. Gaster, 349 S.C. 545, 564 S.E.2d 87 (2002); State 
      v. Wilds, 355 S.C. 269, 584 S.E.2d 138 (Ct. App. 2003); State v. 
      McLauren, 349 S.C. 488, 563 S.E.2d 346 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  If there is 
      any direct evidence or substantial circumstantial evidence reasonably tending 
      to prove the guilt of the accused, this Court must find the case was properly 
      submitted to the jury.Â  State v. Rosemond, 356 S.C. 426, 589 S.E.2d 
      757 (2003); State v. Lindsey, 355 S.C. 15, 583 S.E.2d 740 (2003); 
      see also State v. Ballington, 346 S.C. 262, 551 S.E.2d 280 
      (Ct. App. 2001) (stating judge should deny motion for directed verdict if 
      there is any direct or substantial circumstantial evidence which reasonably 
      tends to prove accusedâ€™s guilt, or from which his guilt may be fairly and 
      logically deduced).Â  On the other hand, a defendant is entitled to a directed 
      verdict when the State fails to produce evidence of the offense charged.Â  
      State v. McKnight, 352 S.C. 635, 576 S.E.2d 168 (2003); State 
      v. McCluney, Op. No. 3742 (S.C. Ct. App. filed February 2, 2004) (Shearouse 
      Adv. Sh. No. 6 at 63); State v. Padgett, 354 S.C. 268, 580 S.E.2d 
      159 (Ct. App. 2003).
    â€œWhen the death of a
    person ensues within three years as a proximate result of injury received by
    the driving of a vehicle in reckless disregard of the safety of others, the
    person operating the vehicle is guilty of reckless homicide. . . .â€ 
    S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 56-5-2910(A) (Supp. 2003). 
    Reckless homicide requires proof that the defendant (1) operated an
    automobile; (2) in reckless disregard for the safety of others; (3) the
    defendantâ€™s conduct proximately caused injury to the victim; and (4)
    within three years, the victim died as a result of these injuries. 
    See State v. Watson, 349 S.C. 372, 563 S.E.2d 336
    (2002). See State v. Watson, 349 S.C. 372, 563 S.E.2d 336 (2002).
    To convict an individual of reckless 
      homicide, the State must prove the individual was driving a vehicle â€œin 
      reckless disregard of the safety of others.â€Â  State v. Rowell, 326 
      S.C. 313, 487 S.E.2d 185 (1997).Â  Reckless disregard for the safety of others 
      signifies an indifference to the consequences of oneâ€™s acts.Â  Id.; 
      see also McKnight, 352 S.C. at 645, 576 S.E.2d at 173 (â€œ[I]n 
      reckless homicide cases, we have held that reckless disregard for the safety 
      of others signifies an indifference to the consequences of oneâ€™s acts.â€).Â  
      It denotes a conscious failure to exercise due care or ordinary care or 
      a conscious indifference to the rights and safety of others or a reckless 
      disregard thereof.Â  Rowell, 326 S.C. at 315, 487 S.E.2d at 186.
    We find the State presented
    sufficient evidence to submit the reckless homicide charge to the jury. 
    Both Suzie and Geoffrey Thomas testified that Gregory looked both
    ways before crossing the street.  The
    Thomases declared they did not see the white car that Horton was driving
    until it struck and killed Gregory.  Officer
    Burgessâ€™s testimony that there were no skid marks on the road where the
    car struck Gregory supported the statement by the Thomases that Hortonâ€™s
    car came upon them very quickly.  Officer
    Burgess said that he detected â€œan odor of alcoholâ€ on Hortonâ€™s person
    and, although Horton was not slurring his speech or staggering, he believed
    Horton was under the influence.  The
    officer indicated that his suspicions were strengthened by the fact that
    Horton was â€œunemotionalâ€ after the accident and that â€œ[h]is attitude
    and behavior just didnâ€™t add up to [the] reality of what had just
    happened.â€  The forensic
    toxicologist with SLED noted that, at the time of the accident, Horton had
    alcohol, THC, opiate derivatives, and cocaine metabolite in his system. 
    A jury could conclude from these facts that, on the day in question,
    Horton operated his vehicle â€œin reckless disregard of the safety of
    others.â€
    The State presented
    evidence reasonably tending to prove Hortonâ€™s guilt of the offense of
    reckless homicide.  Accordingly,
    the trial judge did not err in denying Hortonâ€™s motion for a directed
    verdict on the charge of reckless homicide. 
    
    
    II. 
    Urine Test 
    
    
    Horton
    contends the trial judge erred in admitting the results of his urine test. 
    We disagree. 
    
    
    An in
    camera hearing was held to determine the admissibility of the urine
    test.  Officer Joye testified
    that, after administering the Datamaster, he asked Horton to submit to a
    urine test.  The officer drove
    Horton to the emergency room (ER) at Spartanburg Regional Medical Center. 
    He filled out the implied consent form at the hospital. 
    Horton signed the implied consent form. 
    Because a male nurse was not available to go in the bathroom with
    Horton while he was giving the sample, Officer Joye went into the â€œone
    unit bathroomâ€ with Horton and observed him give the urine sample. 
    The bathroom had a toilet but no stall. 
    Horton handed the urine sample to Officer Joye. 
    The officer then passed the sample to an ER staff nurse, Sue Mobley,
    who had observed from outside the partially open door. 
    Mobley â€œlabeled the kit, as far as putting the tape over the urine
    sampleâ€ and â€œput[ting] the identification information . . . on it.â€ 
    After Mobley signed, sealed, and labeled the urine sample, she
    returned the sample to Officer Joye.  Officer
    Joye gave the urine sample to Officer Burgess for transport. 
    
    
    Officer
    Burgess witnessed Mobley sign the â€œspecimen seal.â€ 
    Officer Burgess signed the outside of the box indicating that he had
    received the urine sample.  The
    officer â€œkept the sample in his possession until [he] turned it in to the
    evidence locker at the patrol office.â€ 
    Officer Burgess stated he did not sign the sample in to the evidence
    locker until September 27.  He
    could not recall at what time he placed the sample in the evidence locker. 
    Further, he did not remember whether he stored the sample in his
    personal refrigerator prior to placing it in the evidence locker. 
    When he placed the sample in the evidence locker, â€œ[t]he bottle
    [was] sealed and [was] in plastic.  And
    on the outside . . . of the box there [are] tabs . . . that are sealed and
    initialed.â€ 
    
    
    Sergeant William Eugene
    Williford removed the urine sample from the evidence locker and transported
    it to SLED headquarters in Columbia.  When
    Sergeant Williford arrived at SLED, the evidence technician removed the
    sample from the box and placed it in a plastic bag. 
    Sergeant Williford sealed the bag, initialed it, and placed it in the
    SLED drop box.  When asked on
    cross-examination what type of container the sample was contained in when he
    removed it from the evidence locker, Sergeant Williford responded: â€œA
    styrofoam-type container.â€  He
    stated the urine sample was in a plastic container which was inside a sealed
    box which was inside a second sealed box. 
    Robert Michael Sears, the SLED forensic toxicologist, confirmed that
    he removed Hortonâ€™s sample from a sealed plastic bag prior to conducting
    his analysis of the urine sample.  The
    trial judge denied Hortonâ€™s motion to suppress the results of the urine
    test. 
    
    
    The
    admission or exclusion of evidence is left to the sound discretion of the
    trial judge.  State v. Adams, 354 S.C. 361, 580 S.E.2d 785 (Ct. App.
    2003).  A courtâ€™s ruling on
    the admissibility of evidence will not be reversed on appeal absent an abuse
    of discretion or the commission of legal error which results in prejudice to
    the defendant.  State v.
    Hamilton, 344 S.C. 344, 543 S.E.2d 586 (Ct. App. 2001); State v.
    Mansfield, 343 S.C. 66, 538 S.E.2d 257 (Ct. App. 2000). 
    An abuse of discretion occurs when the trial courtâ€™s ruling is
    based on an error of law.  State
    v. Foster, 354 S.C. 614, 582 S.E.2d 426 (2003); State v. McDonald,
    343 S.C. 319, 540 S.E.2d 464 (2000). 
    A.     
    Collection of Urine Sample 
    
    
    Horton
    maintains the results of the urine test should have been suppressed because
    the urine sample was improperly collected. 
    
    
    â€œBlood and urine samples must
    be obtained by physicians licensed by the State Board of Medical Examiners,
    registered nurses licensed by the State Board of Nursing, and other medical
    personnel trained to obtain the samples in a licensed medical facility.â€ 
    S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 56-5-2950(a) (Supp. 2003). 
    
    
    Horton
    claims section 56-5-2950 was violated because Officer Joye was the
    individual who collected the urine sample. 
    We find this argument is without merit. 
    Because there were no male nurses available that evening to
    personally witness the production of the sample and immediately collect it,
    Mobley followed hospital policy and did not accompany Horton into the
    bathroom.  However, while Mobley
    did not stand next to Horton while he gave his sample, she observed the
    situation from the partially open bathroom door. 
    The only role played by Officer Joye was to place a lid on the sample
    and hand it to Mobley, who then signed the appropriate labels on the
    container and sealed it. 
    
    
    We
    find the trial judge did not err in finding that, as Mobley was in the
    â€œimmediate proximityâ€ of the test, the procedure followed was
    appropriate under the circumstances. 
    B.     
    Chain of Custody
    Horton avers the State failed to 
      prove a complete and proper chain of custody in regard to the urine sample.
  The State must prove a chain
  of custody for a urine sample from the time it is obtained until it is tested. 
  See State v. Carter, 344 S.C. 419, 544 S.E.2d 835 (2001)
  (case involving a blood sample); Ex parte Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl.
  Control, 350 S.C. 243, 565 S.E.2d 293 (2002). 
  A complete chain of evidence must be established as far as practicable,
  tracing possession from the time the specimen is given to the final custodian
  by whom it is analyzed.  Carter,
  344 S.C. at 424, 544 S.E.2d at 837; State v. Cribb, 310 S.C. 518, 426
  S.E.2d 306 (1992); Benton v. Pellum, 232 S.C. 26, 100 S.E.2d 534
  (1957).  Where the substance
  analyzed has passed through several hands, the evidence must not leave it to
  conjecture as to who had it and what was done with it between the taking and
  the analysis.  Benton, 232
  S.C. at 33-34, 100 S.E.2d at 537.
    Proof
    of chain of custody need not negate all possibility of tampering but must
    establish a complete chain of evidence as far as practicable. 
    Carter, 344 S.C. at 424, 544 S.E.2d at 837; State v.
    Williams, 297 S.C. 290, 376 S.E.2d 773 (1989); Benton, 232 S.C.
    at 33, 100 S.E.2d at 537.  In
    applying this rule, our Supreme Court has found evidence inadmissible only
    where there is a missing link in the chain of possession because the
    identity of those who handled the specimen was not established at least as
    far as practicable.  Carter,
    344 S.C. at 424, 544 S.E.2d at 837.  On
    the other hand, where the identity of persons handling the specimen is
    established, the Supreme Court has found that evidence regarding its care
    goes only to the weight of the specimen as credible evidence. 
    Id.  In other
    words, where there is a weak link in the chain of custody, as opposed to a
    missing link, the question is only one of credibility and not admissibility. 
    Id. 
    
    
    In
    his brief, Horton cites testimony by Officer Burgess and Sergeant Williford
    in support of his contention that the State failed to adequately prove the
    chain of custody of the urine sample.  Officer
    Burgess did not recall: (1) whether he received the urine sample from Mobley
    or Officer Joye; (2) at what time he delivered the sample to the evidence
    locker; and (3) whether he stored the sample in his home refrigerator until
    he transported it to the evidence locker. 
    Horton points to testimony by Sergeant Williford that, when he
    delivered the urine sample to SLED, the plastic container which held the
    urine sample was inside a Styrofoam container. 
    Horton claims â€œ[t]here was no testimony as to how the plastic
    container got into a styrofoam container.â€
    Regardless, the identities of all persons handling
    Hortonâ€™s urine sample were firmly established. 
    See Carter, 344 S.C. at 424, 544 S.E.2d at 837.  The persons who handled the evidence testified to a
    sufficient chain of custody.  The
    State proved a continuous chain of custody through the testimony of all
    people who had control and possession of the evidence.
  There is no missing link in the chain of custody.Â  
    The trial judge did not abuse his discretion in finding a complete chain of 
    custody and allowing the jury to consider the results of the urine test.
   C.Â Â Â Â Â  Rule 403 Analysis
    Horton
    claims the results of the urine test were more prejudicial than probative
    and should have been excluded by Rule 403, SCRE.  
    
    
     â€œAlthough relevant, evidence may be excluded if its probative
    value is substantially outweighed by the danger of unfair prejudice,
    confusion of the issues, or misleading the jury, or by considerations of
    undue delay, waste of time, or needless presentation of cumulative
    evidence.â€  Rule 403, SCRE.  A trial judgeâ€™s decision regarding the comparative
    probative value and prejudicial effect of evidence should be reversed only
    in exceptional circumstances.  State
    v. Adams, 354 S.C. 361, 580 S.E.2d 785 (Ct. App. 2003). 
    We review a trial courtâ€™s decision regarding Rule 403 pursuant to
    the abuse of discretion standard and are obligated to give great deference
    to the trial courtâ€™s judgment.  Id. 
    
    
    The
    toxicologistâ€™s report confirming the presence of alcohol, THC, opiate
    derivatives, and cocaine metabolite in Hortonâ€™s urine was certainly
    damaging to his case.  However, we find this evidence was more probative than
    prejudicial in nature.  The test
    results corroborate Officer Burgessâ€™s suspicion that, even though the
    Datamaster registered a legal alcohol level, Horton was under the influence. 
    Furthermore, Horton was free to challenge the veracity of the test
    results.  In fact, Horton
    advanced this argument at trial, eliciting testimony from two SLED
    toxicologists that it was impossible to determine whether Horton was under
    the influence of these drugs at the time of the accident.
  Recently, the Court of Appeals, in Kennedy v. Griffin, 
    ___S.C.___, 593 S.E.2d 512 (Ct. App. 2004), analyzed the admissibility of 
    evidence of marijuana usage in an automobile collision scenario.Â  Kennedy 
    is inapposite to the facts of the case at bar.Â  Here, there is a definite 
    correlation between the ingestion of the drugs and alcohol and the toxicology 
    analysis.Â  In Kennedy, the evidence offered was inconclusive and indefinite 
    in regard to the impact on the individual ingesting the substance.Â  The test 
    results in this case corroborated Officer Burgessâ€™s observation of Horton.
  The trial judge did not abuse his discretion 
    in allowing the admission of the results of Hortonâ€™s urine test.Â  The probative 
    nature of this evidence, especially when viewed in conjunction with Officer 
    Burgessâ€™s testimony, far outweighs any prejudice.Â  We note the admission of 
    the urine test did not restrict Hortonâ€™s ability to present an adequate defense, 
    as he was still able to attack the test results.
  III.Â  Lack of Remorse/Constitutional Right to Remain Silent
  Horton asserts the trial judge erred in
  allowing the State to present evidence of Hortonâ€™s lack of remorse. 
  We disagree.
  â€œAll relevant evidence is admissible, except 
    as otherwise provided by the Constitution of the United States, the Constitution 
    of the State of South Carolina, statutes, these rules, or by other rules promulgated 
    by the Supreme Court of South Carolina.â€Â  Rule 402, SCRE; State v. Aleksey, 
    343 S.C. 20, 538 S.E.2d 248 (2000).Â  â€œâ€˜Relevant evidenceâ€™ means evidence having 
    any tendency to make the existence of any fact that is of consequence to the 
    determination of the action more probable or less probable than it would be 
    without the evidence.â€Â  Rule 401, SCRE.Â  Under Rule 401, evidence is relevant 
    if it has a direct bearing upon and tends to establish or make more or less 
    probable the matter in controversy.Â  In the Matter of the Care and Treatment 
    of Corley, 353 S.C. 202, 577 S.E.2d 451 (2003); State v. Adams, 
    354 S.C. 361, 580 S.E.2d 785 (Ct. App. 2003).
  The testimony in question
  concerns the following remarks by Officer Burgess:
    
  During my conversations with him, as far as asking 
    phone numbers and things like that, insurance information, thatâ€™s all I was 
    getting from Mr. Horton, he sat there unemotional.
  . . . .
  He sat there unemotional, no response whatsoever.Â  His 
    attitude and behavior just didnâ€™t add up to [the] reality of what had just 
    happened.
    
  Horton frames the issue as an error 
    in regard to evidence that Horton lacked remorse.Â  However, Horton professes 
    that Officer Burgessâ€™ testimony was an improper comment on Hortonâ€™s right 
    to remain silent.Â  Citing State v. Reid, 324 S.C. 74, 476 S.E.2d 695 
    (1996), overruled on other grounds by State v. Watson, 349 S.C. 
    372, 563 S.E.2d 336 (2002), Horton avers â€œthis line of questioning was a comment 
    on [Hortonâ€™s] lack of remorse and therefore improper.â€
   Reid edifies:
  It is a violation of due process for a State 
    to permit comment on a defendantâ€™s post-arrest silence since the giving of 
    Miranda warnings might induce silence by implicitly assuring a defendant 
    his silence will not be used against him.Â  Doyle v. Ohio, 426 U.S. 
    610, 96 S.Ct. 2240, 49 L.Ed.2d 91 (1976).Â  See also State v. Arther, 
    290 S.C. 291, 350 S.E.2d 187 (1986); State v. Smith, 290 S.C. 393, 
    350 S.E.2d 923 (1986); State v. Hale, 284 S.C. 348, 326 S.E.2d 418 
    (Ct. App. 1985), cert. denied, 286 S.C. 127, 332 S.E.2d 533 (1985).Â  
    References to a defendantâ€™s lack of remorse are also improper as violative 
    of a defendantâ€™s Fifth, Eighth, and Fourteenth Amendment rights.Â  State 
    v. Diddlemeyer, 296 S.C. 235, 371 S.E.2d 793 (1988), overruled on other 
    grounds, State v. Torrence, 305 S.C. 45, 406 S.E.2d 315 (1991); 
    State v. Cockerham, 294 S.C. 380, 365 S.E.2d 22 (1988); State v. 
    Johnson, 293 S.C. 321, 360 S.E.2d 317 (1987), cert. denied, 503 
    U.S. 993, 112 S.Ct. 1691, 118 L.Ed.2d 404 (1992) (comments by the prosecution 
    upon an accusedâ€™s failure to express remorse invite jury to draw an adverse 
    inference merely because the defendant did not appear penitent); State 
    v. Sloan, 278 S.C. 435, 298 S.E.2d 92 (1982).Â  Here, the State was permitted 
    to inquire both as to Reidâ€™s post-arrest silence and his lack of remorse; 
    this inquiry was therefore clearly improper.
  Id. at 78, 476 S.E.2d at 696.
  Horton complains that the trial court 
    should have suppressed Officer Burgessâ€™ observation and description of Horton 
    at the accident scene.Â  Horton sat in Officer Burgessâ€™ patrol vehicle approximately 
    twenty to thirty minutes while the officer made an accident report.Â  The officer 
    noted a smell of alcohol about Hortonâ€™s person.Â  Horton appeared unemotional.Â  
    Officer Burgess thought Horton was under the influence of something and arrested 
    him.Â  The State offered the officerâ€™s factual observations to support his 
    opinion and conclusion that Horton was under the influence.Â  â€œ[I]t is well 
    settled that a lay witness may testify whether or not in his opinion a person 
    was drunk or sober on a given occasion on which he observed him and that the 
    weight of such testimony is for determination by the jury.â€Â  State v. Ramey, 
    221 S.C. 10, 13-14, 68 S.E.2d 634, 635 (1952).
  The testimony was not presented as evidence of Hortonâ€™s 
    lack of remorse or as a comment on Hortonâ€™s post-arrest silence.Â  Rather, 
    the testimony was presented for the purpose of illustrating Hortonâ€™s actions 
    and attitudes after the accident, and how his unemotional response to the 
    events led Officer Burgess to believe he was under the influence.Â  The challenged 
    testimony was clearly relevant and admissible to support the officerâ€™s decision 
    to have Horton submit to both a Datamaster and urine test.
  Concomitantly, the 
    trial judge did not err in allowing Officer Burgessâ€™s testimony about Hortonâ€™s 
    attitude and behavior after the accident.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
  Based on our review of the record, we come to 
    the ineluctable conclusion that the testimony of Officer Burgess is NOT 
    a comment upon post-arrest silence nor an impermissible comment on the defendantâ€™s 
    lack of remorse.
  CONCLUSION
  
  
  Based upon the foregoing, Hortonâ€™s 
    conviction and sentence for reckless homicide are
   AFFIRMED.
  HEARN, C.J., and BEATTY, J., concur.

 
   [1]  
    We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

description: Determines circuit court lacks statutory authority to require refund of portion of bail bond fee when company is relieved as surety.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Ex Parte: Gene Frye Bail Bonds., Appellant,
In Re: The State, Respondent,
v.
Robert Husted, Defendant.
      
    
  


 
Appeal From Lexington County
James R. Barber, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3788
Submitted April 6, 2004 â€“ Filed May 
  3, 2004

REVERSED


  
    
      
Robert T. Williams, of Lexington, for Appellant. 
No Appearance by Respondent.
      
    
  

STILWELL, J.:Â  In this case, we must decide 
  whether the circuit court can order a bail bond company to return a portion 
  of the money it collected from the defendantâ€™s family when the company is relieved 
  as surety on a criminal bond.Â  We hold the court may not issue such an order. 
  [1] 
BACKGROUND
Robert Husted was arrested in Lexington 
  County and charged with several general sessions court offenses.Â  Gene Frye 
  Bail Bonds (GFB) acted as surety on a $60,100 bond and Husted was released from 
  jail.Â  Following Hustedâ€™s arrest on additional charges and his failure to make 
  a court appearance, GFB requested to be released as surety.Â  
At a hearing on the motion, GFB 
  asserted Hustedâ€™s father asked to be relieved of his obligations as the bondâ€™s 
  guarantor.Â  The court asked GFB to reappear the next morning with Hustedâ€™s 
  father to determine the amount already paid on the bond.Â  Following the 
  second hearing, the court released GFB from further obligations on the bond 
  but required it to return $4500 of the $6000 fee it had received from Hustedâ€™s 
  father.Â  
DISCUSSION
GFB contends the circuit court erred by requiring it to repay 
  a portion of its previously collected fee to Hustedâ€™s father.Â  We agree.
S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 38-53-50 establishes the procedure 
  to be followed when a surety seeks to be relieved from a bond:

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  (A)Â Â Â  A surety desiring to be relieved on a bond 
  for â€œgood causeâ€ or the nonpayment of fees shall file with the court a motion 
  to be relieved on the bond.Â  A copy of the motion must be served upon the defendant, 
  his attorney, and the solicitorâ€™s office.Â  The court shall then schedule a hearing 
  to determine if the surety should be relieved on the bond and advise all parties 
  of the hearing date.Â  
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  (B)Â Â Â  If the circumstances warrant immediate incarceration 
  of the defendant to prevent imminent violation of any one of the specific terms 
  of the bail bond, or if the defendant has violated any one of the specific terms 
  of the bond, the surety may take the defendant to the appropriate detention 
  facility for holding until the court orders that the surety be relieved.Â  The 
  surety must immediately file with the detention facility and the court an affidavit 
  stating the facts to support the surrender of the defendant for good cause or 
  the nonpayment of fees. When the affidavit is filed with the court, the surety 
  must also file a motion to be relieved on the bond pursuant to subsection (A).Â  
  A surety who surrenders a defendant and files an affidavit which does not show 
  good cause or the nonpayment of fees is subject to penalties imposed for perjury 
  as provided for in Article 1, Chapter 9 of Title 16.Â  

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 38-53-50 (2002). 
This version of section 38-53-50 became effective 
  in 1998.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 38-53-50 (2002) (history); see also 
  Act No. 425, 1998 S.C. Acts 3134, 3138.Â  Prior to the 1998 amendments, section 
  38-53-50(B) further provided the circuit court â€œmay order the surety to refund 
  to the defendant any fees paid toward the bail bond after deducting the suretyâ€™s 
  actual costs, reasonable expenses, and reasonable fees, as determined by the 
  court.â€Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 38-53-50(B) (Supp. 1997).Â  However, when 
  section 38-53-50 was revised in 1998, this provision was deleted and the circuit 
  court was granted no similar authority.
Clearly, section 38-53-50 gives the circuit court 
  discretion in determining whether a surety should be relieved from a bond.Â Â  
  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 38-53-50(A) (After a surety files a motion to be 
  relieved on a bond, â€œ[t]he court shall then schedule a hearing to determine 
  if the surety should be relieved on the bond.â€) (emphasis added).Â  However, 
  nothing in the statute vests the court with the discretion to require the surety 
  return any portion of the fee the defendant paid for the bond.Â  Although the 
  circuit court previously had the power to require a return to the defendant 
  of a portion of the fee, that authority did not survive the 1998 amendment to 
  section 38-53-50.
We conclude the governing statute does not authorize 
  the circuit court to require a bonding company to pay any portion of the fee 
  back to the defendant or his guarantor in order to be released from a bond.Â  
  Accordingly, the challenged portion of the circuit courtâ€™s order is 
 REVERSED.
 HUFF, J., and CURETON, A.J., concur.

 
   
    [1]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 
    215, SCACR.

title: Upchurch v. Upchurch
description: In this domestic relations case, the court analyzes the following issues: (1) subject matter jurisdiction relating to a mailing emanating from the office of the family court judge to the parties and a notice of appeal filed in that regard; (2) the effect of the parties' prior child support agreement on the family court's authority to award child support; and (3) the sufficiency of the pleadings in regard to an allegation of changed circumstances.

<!--

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Michael E. Upchurch, Respondent,
v.
Susan O. Upchurch, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Colleton County
Â Jane D. Fender, Family Court Judge

Opinion No. 3789
Heard April 6, 2004 â€“ Filed May 3, 
  2004

DISMISSED


  
    
      
David L. DeVane and Gregory Samuel Forman, both of Charleston, 
  for Appellant.
Kenneth A. Campbell, Jr. and Lucius Scott Harvin, both 
  of Walterboro, for Respondent.
      
    
  

ANDERSON, J.:Â  Michael E. Upchurch (â€œHusbandâ€) 
  brought this action against Susan O. Upchurch (â€œWifeâ€) seeking tuition and child 
  support payments.Â  The family court granted Husbandâ€™s request for child support, 
  ordering Wife to pay it retroactive to the filing of the summons and complaint.Â  
  We find this court is without jurisdiction to review this case because the notice 
  of appeal was not timely served.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Husband and Wife were married in March 
  1981. They had three children, Sloane G. Upchurch, born September 19, 1984, 
  Michael O. Upchurch, born October 25, 1985, and Catherine Ellis Upchurch, born 
  May 29, 1989.Â  Husband and Wife subsequently divorced on February 3, 2001.
At the time of their divorce, they had entered 
  into a separation agreement, which was incorporated into the final divorce decree 
  of February 3, 2001.Â  Pursuant to the decree, Husband and Wife were awarded 
  joint custody of the three children, with Husband serving as the primary custodial 
  parent subject to Wifeâ€™s right to reasonable visitation.Â  With regard to child 
  support, the decree ordered: â€œDue to the current financial situation of the 
  parties, including the wifeâ€™s establishment of a new household in Charleston, 
  South Carolina, the husband waives child support.Â  The husband and wife may 
  decide to revisit the issue of child support should the financial situation 
  of either party change drastically.â€
In September 2001, Husband brought the present 
  action requesting that the family court order Wife to pay private school tuition 
  and child support.Â  At the hearing, Husband testified there had been a dramatic 
  change in his financial circumstances.Â  He claimed that his oldest daughter 
  would be attending college soon, giving rise to substantial tuition and related 
  expenses.Â  Husband also testified that medical expenses for the children had 
  increased due to injuries that were not covered by insurance and orthodontic 
  treatment required for all three children.Â  Wife did not object to this testimony.Â  
  The only objection she raised concerned testimony regarding Husbandâ€™s payment 
  of their oldest daughterâ€™s college expenses, which would occur after the daughter 
  had reached eighteen. 
Wifeâ€™s circumstances had also changed since the 
  divorce.Â  At the time of the original divorce decree, she had just purchased 
  her own home in Charleston and had incurred substantial expense in establishing 
  a new household there.Â  Wife, however, subsequently sold her new home and moved 
  to Savannah, Georgia.Â  She received $31,000 profit from the sale.
The family court concluded Husband was entitled 
  to receive child support.Â  In its ruling, the court observed that because Wife 
  had sold her home in Charleston and was no longer established in a new household, 
  â€œ[t]he reason for waiving support no longer existed.â€Â  In determining the amount 
  of child support owed, the court opined that it would apply the Child Support 
  Guidelines, using financial declarations submitted by Husband and Wife.Â  In 
  setting the amount, the court noted Wife was currently unemployed but was receiving 
  income from a severance package with her previous employer.Â  The court found, 
  because Wife held a masterâ€™s degree, it was appropriate to impute to her a monthly 
  income of $3,600.Â  Based on these facts, the family court awarded Husband child 
  support retroactive to the time he commenced the present action.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In appeals from the family court, this Court has 
  authority to find facts in accordance with our own view of the preponderance 
  of the evidence.Â  Woodall v. Woodall, 322 S.C. 7, 10, 471 S.E.2d 154, 
  157 (1996); Rutherford v. Rutherford, 307 S.C. 199, 204, 414 S.E.2d 157, 
  160 (1992); Charest v. Charest, 329 S.C. 511, 515, 495 S.E.2d 784, 786 
  (Ct. App. 1997).Â  This broad scope of review, however, does not require us to 
  disregard the findings of the court below.Â  Stevenson v. Stevenson, 276 
  S.C. 475, 477, 279 S.E.2d 616, 617 (1981).Â  We are mindful that the trial judge, 
  who saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better position to evaluate their 
  credibility and assign comparative weight to their testimony. Â McAlister 
  v. Patterson, 278 S.C. 481, 483, 299 S.E.2d 322, 323 (1982); Cherry v. 
  Thomasson, 276 S.C. 524, 525, 280 S.E.2d 541, 541 (1981); Kisling v. 
  Allison, 343 S.C. 674, 677, 541 S.E.2d 273, 275 (Ct. App. 2001).
LAW/ANALYSIS
As a threshold matter, Husband argues 
  this court lacks jurisdiction to review this case because Wifeâ€™s notice of appeal 
  was not timely served.Â  We agree.
Under the South Carolina Appellate Court 
  Rules, a notice of appeal from a domestic relations action â€œshall be served 
  on all respondents within thirty (30) days after receipt of written notice of 
  entry of the order or judgment.â€Â  Rule 203(b)(1) & (3), SCACR.Â  An order 
  becomes effective once the judge delivers it to the clerk of court.Â  See 
  Bayne v. Bass, 302 S.C. 208, 209, 394 S.E.2d 726, 727 (Ct. App. 1990) 
  (holding that until a ruling is reduced to writing, signed by the judge, and 
  delivered for recordation it is not binding on the parties).Â  â€œThe recording 
  of the judgment or order is only to give notice and secure the safety of the 
  record of the solemn acts of the courts.â€Â  Genobles v. West, 23 S.C. 
  154, 160 (1885).Â  â€œAny notice in writing which would convey to a losing party 
  that judgment has been entered [i]s sufficient.â€Â  Rosen, Rosen & Hagood 
  v. Hiller, 307 S.C. 331, 335, 415 S.E.2d 117, 119 (Ct. App. 1992).Â  â€œA person 
  who knows of a thing has notice thereof.Â  Stated differently, â€˜[n]o one needs 
  notice of what he already knows.â€™â€Â  Hannah v. United Refrigerated Servs., 
  312 S.C. 42, 47, 430 S.E.2d 539, 541 (Ct. App. 1993).Â  Actual notice is synonymous 
  with knowledge.Â  Strother v. Lexington County Recreation Commâ€™n, 332 
  S.C. 54, 63 n. 6, 504 S.E.2d 117, 122 n. 6 (1998).Â  â€œNotice is regarded as actual 
  where the person sought to be charged therewith either knows of the existence 
  of the particular facts in question or is conscious of having the means of knowing 
  it, even though such means may not be employed by him.â€Â  Id.
In the present case, the presiding family court 
  judge signed the order under appeal on May 30, 2002.Â  The following day on May 
  31, 2002, the judgeâ€™s administrative assistant mailed the original signed order 
  to the Colleton County Clerk of Court.Â  The cover letter enclosed with the order 
  asked the clerk to file the order and forward copies to the partiesâ€™ attorneys 
  of record.Â  The judgeâ€™s administrative assistant also carbon copied both attorneys 
  of record and included a copy of the family courtâ€™s signed order.Â  By letter 
  dated August 23, 2002, Wifeâ€™s attorney acknowledged receiving the copy of the 
  signed order from the judgeâ€™s administrative assistant, but noted that he did 
  not consider the signed and dated, but as yet unfiled, copy of the order sufficient 
  notice of its entry.
We find the letter and accompanying copy 
  of the signed order from the family court judgeâ€™s administrative assistant was 
  sufficient â€œwritten notice of entry of the order or judgmentâ€ to begin tolling 
  the thirty-day time limit for appeal under Rule 203(b)(1), SCACR.Â  Though our 
  courts have not addressed the question of when notice of written entry of judgment 
  has occurred under Rule 203(b)(1), this Court has addressed the application 
  of a similar notice requirement in Rosen, Rosen & Hagood v. Hiller.
In Rosen, Rosen & Hagood, the 
  plaintiff law firm sued one of its former clients for unpaid attorney fees.Â  
  Prior to trial, the defendant moved for change of venue.Â  After the defendant 
  failed to appear at the call of the motions calendar, the chief administrative 
  judge issued an order holding the change of venue motion had been abandoned, 
  stricken, and denied.Â  Id. at 332, 415 S.E.2d at 117.Â  The law firm mailed 
  a letter to defendantâ€™s counsel enclosing an unsigned, undated, and unfiled 
  copy of the order.Â  Id. at 332-33, 415 S.E.2d at 117.Â  The defendantâ€™s 
  attorney responded by letter in which he acknowledged receipt of the order, 
  but noted that he did not consider the unsigned order sufficient notice of its 
  entry.Â  Id. at 333, 415 S.E.2d at 117.Â  This court disagreed, finding 
  the letter and unsigned, undated order provided sufficient notice that the order 
  had been signed and entered.Â  Id. at 335, 415 S.E.2d at 119.
In the present case, the notice provided 
  to Wifeâ€™s attorney was more substantial than that which was deemed minimally 
  sufficient in Rosen, Rosen & Hagood.Â  Here, unlike the situation 
  in Rosen, Rosen & Hagood, Wifeâ€™s attorney received a copy of the 
  signed and dated order that was entered by the family court judge.Â  Furthermore, 
  the letter and order were received directly from the judgeâ€™s chambers, not from 
  opposing counsel or other party.Â  We discern no reason why the rationale this 
  court followed in Rosen, Rosen & Hagood does not compel a similar 
  result in the instant case.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
We find the notice of appeal in this case was not 
  timely served.Â  The present appeal is therefore
 DISMISSED.
 HEARN, C.J. and BEATTY, J., concur.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Willie Earl Reese, Jr.,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
G. Thomas Cooper, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Opinion No. 3790
Heard April 7, 2004 â€“ Filed May 3, 
  2004

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Jack B. Swerling, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, 
  Senior Assistant Attorney General William Edgar Salter, III, and Solicitor Warren 
  Blair Giese, all of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

ANDERSON, J.:Â  Appellant Willie Earl Reese, 
  Jr. was indicted and charged with the murder of his wife Teresa.Â  Following 
  a jury trial, he was found guilty and sentenced to thirty-five years in prison.Â  
  He now appeals, asserting the trial court erred in the admission of hearsay 
  testimony, the admission of photographs of the victimâ€™s body and autopsy, denying 
  certain requested jury charges, and failing to grant a mistrial based on the 
  Solicitorâ€™s closing arguments.Â  We reverse and remand.Â  
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Following her marriage to Reese in January 
  1999, Teresa Joyner moved out of the marital house and returned to her parentsâ€™ 
  home on two occasions, the first in January 2001 and again in April of the same 
  year.Â  Late in the evening during her second stay away from the marital home, 
  as Teresa stood on the sidewalk in front of her parentsâ€™ house, Reese shot Teresa 
  in the head, killing her.
During the evening leading up to the fatal 
  shooting, Teresa had been playing softball with her neighbor and cousin, Edith 
  McKenzie.Â  After the game, the two went to a club.Â  Throughout the evening, 
  while Teresa was with Edith, Teresaâ€™s mother received repeated telephone calls 
  from Reese inquiring about Teresaâ€™s whereabouts and asking that she call him 
  when she returned home.Â  Each time he called, Teresaâ€™s mother assured Reese 
  that she would tell her daughter he had called.
Edith testified that after leaving the 
  club with Teresa around 1:30 a.m., she noticed Reeseâ€™s car parked at a stop 
  sign as she pulled into Sandstone Lane.Â  Pulling alongside his car, Teresa spoke 
  briefly with Reese, after which he turned his car around and followed Teresa 
  to her parentsâ€™ house.Â  Standing in front of her parentsâ€™ house, Teresa assured 
  Edith that everything was okay, gave her a hug, and told her that she would 
  see her tomorrow.Â  Edith then departed, leaving Teresa and Reese standing on 
  the sidewalk facing each other.
Edith drove to her own home two houses 
  away, and once inside, called to check on Teresa.Â  Teresaâ€™s mother answered 
  the phone, and Edith asked if Teresa had come inside.Â  According to Edithâ€™s 
  testimony, when Teresaâ€™s mother went outside to check, she began screaming.Â  
  Edith then drove back to where she had left Teresa and found her body on the 
  sidewalk.
The following day, using his father as 
  an intermediary, Reese contacted the police and informed them he wanted to turn 
  himself in.Â  Deputy Thomas Reese, the officer who took Reese into custody, testified 
  that Reese was upset, at times crying, and cooperative throughout the process.Â

Additionally, Knoten is instructive 
  in this case.Â  The State argued that because Knoten retracted his confession 
  at trial, the trial court correctly refused to charge voluntary manslaughter.Â  
  The court held that because the confession was introduced at trial, it would 
  support a charge on voluntary manslaughter regardless of the fact that the defendant 
  withdrew this confession:

In support of its second argument, that because Appellant 
  recanted his statement he was properly denied the requested voluntary 
  manslaughter charge, the State cites a single case, State v. Weaver, 
  265 S.C. 130, 217 S.E.2d 31 (1975).Â  In that case, the Court held there was 
  no error in denying the defendantâ€™s request to charge that if the jury found 
  the arresting officer used unreasonable force in effecting the arrest, the defendantâ€™s 
  resistance would not have been unlawful.Â  At trial, the defendant denied that 
  he resisted arrest.Â  The officer testified that he did not use unreasonable 
  force in effecting the arrest.Â  The defendant had made no pre-trial statement 
  which would have supported the requested charge.Â  The record contained no evidence 
  that the officer used unreasonable force, and therefore the requested charge 
  was not warranted.Â  See State v. Cole, supra.Â  Weaver 
  is distinguishable from the instant case.Â  Moreover, the Stateâ€™s argument does 
  not accurately reflect the law of this State.Â  In State v. Moore, 245 
  S.C. 416, 140 S.E.2d 779 (1965), the defendant was charged with, and convicted 
  of, assault and battery of a high and aggravated nature.Â  The trial court refused 
  his requested jury charge on simple assault and battery, despite testimony that 
  the victim had received only slight injuries.Â  The defendant testified that 
  he had been elsewhere when the incident occurred, and under the defenseâ€™s theory, 
  he could have been not guilty of even simple assault and battery.Â  The Court 
  held that the refusal to charge on the lesser included offense was reversible 
  error.Â  The Court stated that, 
  
In determining the issues to be submitted to the jury . . 
  . all of the testimony, both for the State and the defense, must 
  be considered. . . .Â  The fact that the defendant interposed the defense of 
  alibi did not deprive him of the benefit of the reasonable inferences to be 
  drawn from the testimony relative to the degree of the offense committed, for 
  the burden of establishing the offense charged rested upon the State. 
  
Id. at 420-21, 140 S.E.2d at 781.
Because there was evidenceâ€”in this case introduced 
  by the Stateâ€”supporting a conviction for the lesser included offense 
  of voluntary manslaughter, we reverse Appellantâ€™s conviction in the slaying 
  of Kimberly Brown.

347 S.C. 296, 308-09, 555 S.E.2d 391, 397-98 (emphasis 
  added).
The efficacy of Knoten is that when the 
  State introduces a statement or confession, that statement or confession may 
  support an involuntary manslaughter charge.
Evidence must exist that the killing was unintentional 
  and without malice, in addition to either an unlawful activity not naturally 
  tending to cause death or great bodily harm or a lawful activity with reckless 
  disregard for the safety of others.Â  The State introduced Reeseâ€™s statement 
  where the jury could infer Reeseâ€™s intent was to threaten to kill himself and 
  he did not point or present the gun to her; thereby finding the shooting of 
  the gun was unintentional.Â  Reese stated: 
I pulled the gun out and told her I was going to kill myself. 
  . . . I was moving the gun back and forth as a reaction.Â  I donâ€™t know why the 
  gun went off.Â  I thought both safeties were on.Â  I just wanted to see how she 
  would react when I told her I was going to kill myself.Â  I didnâ€™t mean to shoot 
  her.Â  When the gun went off I put my hands on my head.Â  I panicked.
Accordingly, evidence does exist in the record that would 
  allow the jury to infer the lesser-included offense of involuntary manslaughter 
  was committed.Â  The trial judge committed reversible error by failing to charge 
  the jury on involuntary manslaughter, which resulted in prejudice to the Reese. 
  [1] Â  
REVERSED AND REMANDED.
 BEATTY, J., concurs.
HEARN, C.J., dissents in a separate opinion.
 HEARN, C.J.: In my view, even 
  if the jury believed Reeseâ€™s statement that he shot his wife accidentally, he 
  was not entitled to an involuntary manslaughter or accident charge because the 
  shooting occurred while Reese was engaged in the felony of pointing or presenting 
  a firearm.Â  Further, although I agree the trial judge erred by allowing the 
  solicitor to urge jurors to speak for the victim, I believe the error was harmless.Â  
  Thus, I respectfully dissent.
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Involuntary Manslaughter and Accident Charge
If there were any evidence from which it could 
  be inferred that Reese committed involuntary manslaughter, Reese would undoubtedly 
  be entitled to receive a jury charge on that lesser-included offense. See 
  State v. Gourdine, 322 S.C. 396, 398, 472 S.E.2d 241, 241 (1996) (â€œThe 
  trial judge is to charge the jury on a lesser included offense if there is any 
  evidence from which it could be inferred the lesser, rather than the greater, 
  offense was committed.â€). Likewise, a charge on accident would be warranted 
  if any evidence suggested that the victimâ€™s death resulted from an accidental 
  shooting.Â  However, I believe no such inferences can be drawn based on the record 
  before me.Â  
It is undisputed that Reese and the victim were 
  separated at the time of the shooting, and the victim was living with her parents.Â  
  The evening before the shooting, the State introduced phone records showing 
  that Reese had called the victimâ€™s cell phone fifty-one times between 9:45 p.m. 
  and 2:00 a.m.Â  When the victim was returning home during the early morning hours 
  on the day of the shooting, Reese was waiting for her at a stop sign in front 
  of her parentsâ€™ street.Â  The two drove separately to the home of the victimâ€™s 
  parents, and they talked outside.Â  As the majority opinion quoted, Reese made 
  a statement to the police claiming that while they were talking, he â€œpulled 
  the gun outâ€ and did not â€œknow why the gun went offâ€ when he was â€œmoving it 
  back and forth.â€Â  Importantly, Reese never denied pointing the gun at the victim.Â  
  Rather, he stated that he was surprised by the shooting because â€œhe thought 
  both safeties were on.â€Â  Moreover, in addition to Reeseâ€™s admission that he 
  was waving the gun back and forth, numerous witnesses testified (and the tragic 
  result makes clear) that the gun was pointed in the victimâ€™s direction.Â  In 
  fact, the crime scene investigator, the deputy coroner, and a forensic pathologist 
  all testified that the gun was not only pointed at the victim, but was very 
  near to or right against the victimâ€™s head. [2] Â  There is simply nothing in the record to contradict 
  this evidence.
To warrant a charge of involuntary manslaughter 
  or accident, a homicide cannot have occurred during the commission of a felony. [3] Â Â  In South Carolina, it is a felony â€œfor a 
  person to present or point at another person a loaded or unloaded firearm.â€Â  
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-23-410 (1976).Â  Thus, whether or not Reese intended to shoot 
  his wife, he would not be entitled to an involuntary manslaughter or accident 
  charge because the only evidence in the record is that the shooting occurred 
  while he was committing the felony of â€œpresenting or pointingâ€ a firearm.Â  See 
  State v. Tucker, 324 S.C. 155, 170, 478 S.E.2d 260, 268 (1996), cert. 
  denied, 520 U.S. 1200 (1997) (defining involuntary manslaughter, in relevant 
  part, as the killing of another without malice and unintentionally, but while 
  one is engaged in the commission of some unlawful act not amounting to a felony 
  and not naturally tending to cause death or great bodily harm); State v. 
  Young, 319 S.C. 33, 39-40, 459 S.E.2d 84, 87-88 (1995) (finding the defendant 
  was not entitled to a charge of involuntary manslaughter despite his statement 
  that the gun â€œjust went offâ€ because his statement also indicated he was committing 
  the felony of armed robbery at the time of the shooting).Â  
The majority correctly notes that the negligent 
  handling of a firearm supports a charge for involuntary manslaughter; however, 
  where the mishandling of a weapon coincides with the commission of a felony 
  or some other unlawful act that naturally tends to cause death or great bodily 
  harm, an involuntary manslaughter charge is not warranted.Â  In State v. Burris, 
  334 S.C. 256, 2665, 513 S.E.2d 104, 109 (1999), our supreme court found that 
  evidence on the record could support a finding that appellant was entitled to 
  arm himself in self-defense and was therefore acting lawfully when his negligent 
  handling of a loaded weapon caused the weapon to fire and kill the victim. 
  [4] Â  Likewise, in State v. Crosby, 355 S.C. 47, 50, 584 S.E.2d 110, 
  111 (2003), the supreme court held that involuntary manslaughter should have 
  been instructed because there was evidence that the victim was charging the 
  appellant with his hand behind his back, and the appellant closed his eyes and 
  fired the gun, without even realizing he had pulled the trigger.Â  In both of 
  these cases, the appellants were entitled to a charge of involuntary manslaughter 
  because there was evidence from which the jury could infer they were lawfully 
  acting in self-defense when they unintentionally fired a gun. 
  [5] 
In the case at hand, Reese was not acting in self-defense. 
  Â Rather, by his own admission, he was brandishing a gun in order to see how 
  his wife would react if he threatened to shoot himself.Â  While he had the gun 
  in the air, he moved it back and forth, and according to all the evidence in 
  the record, when it was very close to his wifeâ€™s head, he shot her.Â  Even if 
  Reese did not intend to shoot his wife, he is not entitled to an involuntary 
  manslaughter charge because, at the time of the shooting, he was pointing or 
  presenting a weapon, which is a felony, and he was attempting suicide, an unlawful 
  act naturally tending to cause death or great bodily harm.Â  See State 
  v. Levelle, 34 S.C. 120, 13 S.E. 319 (1819) (stating that suicide is an 
  unlawful act and that if A takes Bâ€™s life when attempting suicide, A is guilty 
  of murder) overruled on other grounds by State v. Torrence, 305 
  S.C. 45, 406 S.E.2d 315 (1991).Â  Accordingly, I would affirm the trial judgeâ€™s 
  ruling denying Reeseâ€™s request to charge the jury on involuntary manslaughter 
  and accident.Â  
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Closing Argument
In regards to the solicitorâ€™s closing argument, 
  which urged the jury to â€œspeak for the victim,â€ I agree with the majorityâ€™s 
  finding that this type of argument impermissibly asks the jurors to advocate 
  for the victim.Â  However, I find the judgeâ€™s error in allowing the argument 
  was harmless in light of the overwhelming evidence of Reeseâ€™s guilt.Â  See 
  State v. Mitchell, 286 S.C. 572, 573, 336 S.E.2d 150, 151 (1985) (stating 
  that an error is harmless when it could not reasonably have affected the result 
  of the trial); see, e.g., State v. Primus, 349 S.C. 576, 
  577-578, 564 S.E.2d 103, 109 (2002) (applying harmless error analysis to improper 
  comment by prosecutor during closing argument as to defendantâ€™s failure to call 
  a witness).
In Reeseâ€™s statement to police, he claimed he pulled 
  out a gun and told the victim he was going to kill himself.Â  He admitted that 
  he was waving the gun back and forth and that the gun went off, though he denied 
  purposefully killing her.Â  Numerous witnesses testified that the victim died 
  as a result of a single gunshot wound.Â  Those witnesses also testified that 
  the gun was either very near or right against the victimâ€™s head.Â  Based on this 
  overwhelming evidence of Reeseâ€™s guilt, especially the uncontradicted evidence 
  that he shot the victim in the head while feloniously presenting a firearm, 
  I firmly believe the solicitorâ€™s improper comments during closing argument were 
  harmless beyond a reasonable doubt.
III. Purported Hearsay Regarding Marital Problems
Because I propose to affirm Reeseâ€™s convictions, 
  I briefly address his other arguments on appeal.Â  Reese contends the trial judge 
  erred in allowing witnesses to testify that the victim had moved to her motherâ€™s 
  home because of marital problems.Â  Reese asserts such testimony was hearsay.Â Â  

The victimâ€™s cousin testified without objection 
  that â€œa week or twoâ€ before the victim was killed, she and Reese separated and 
  she had moved back in with her parents.Â  Because no objection was made to this 
  testimony, subsequent testimony wherein witnesses stated that Reese and the 
  victim had marital problems, without giving any details, was cumulative to the 
  cousinâ€™s testimony, which was admitted without objection.Â  Therefore, even assuming 
  arguendo that the other witnessesâ€™ testimony was impermissible hearsay, 
  any error in admitting their testimony was harmless. See State v. 
  South, 285 S.C. 529, 535, 331 S.E.2d 775, 778 (1985) (finding that although 
  the court erred by admitting officerâ€™s notes into evidence, the â€œerror was harmless 
  beyond a reasonable doubt since [notes were] cumulative to the abundant amount 
  of similar evidence admitted at trialâ€).Â Â  
IV.Â Â Â  State of Mind Hearsay Exception
Reese also argues the trial judge erred 
  in allowing witnesses to testify that the victim was â€œafraid for her lifeâ€ because 
  such testimony did not meet the state of mind exception to the rule against 
  hearsay.Â  Our supreme court addressed the scope of the state of mind exception 
  in State v. Garcia, 334 S.C. 71, 76, 512 S.E.2d 507, 509 (1999), and 
  found that â€œwhile the present state of the declarantâ€™s mind is admissible as 
  an exception to hearsay, the reason for the declarantâ€™s state of mind is not.â€Â  
  Reese contends that the witnessesâ€™s testimony that the victim was afraid for 
  her life impermissibly related to the reason for the victimâ€™s state of mind.Â  
  I disagree.Â  
In Garcia, the witnesses repeated out-of-court statements 
  that the defendant had kicked and threatened to kill the decedent and because 
  of that, the decedent had been afraid.Â  Here, the witnesses merely testified 
  that Reeseâ€™s wife feared for her life, which described the type of fear she 
  experienced rather than the cause for such fear.Â  As such, the trial judge correctly 
  admitted the testimony under Rule 803(3), SCRE.
V.Â Â Â Â Â  Admissibility of Photographs
Finally, Reese argues the trial judge erred by allowing the 
  State to admit photographs of the victimâ€™s body into evidence because the photographs 
  were more prejudicial than probative.Â  Generally, a trial judgeâ€™s decision to 
  admit evidence will not be reversed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.Â  
  State v. Adams, 354 S.C. 361, 377, 580 S.E.2d 785, 793 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  
  Because Reese failed to provide this court with a copy of those photographs, 
  I would not meet the merits of this issue.Â  See Harkins v. Greenville 
  County, 340 S.C. 606, 616, 533 S.E.2d 886, 891 (2000) (explaining that the 
  appellant has the burden of presenting the appellate court with an adequate 
  record).Â  
CONCLUSION
I respectfully disagree with the majorityâ€™s holding that 
  Reese was entitled to a charge on involuntary manslaughter.Â  Further, although 
  I agree that the solicitorâ€™s closing argument was improper, I believe the error 
  was harmless in light of the overwhelming evidence of Reeseâ€™s guilt.Â  All of 
  Reeseâ€™s other arguments on appeal are without merit.Â  Therefore, I would affirm 
  Reeseâ€™s conviction for murder.

 
   [1]  In view of our reversal of the case on the identified 
    issues, we decline to address any other arguments.

 
   
    [2]  The deputy coroner testified that â€œ[t]he gunshot wound appeared to 
    be a contact or very near a contact type wound.â€Â  The crime scene investigator 
    also testified that upon observation of the body he believed the victimâ€™s 
    death was caused by a either â€œsoft contact or a close contact type wound.â€ 
    Likewise, the forensic pathologist, who performed an autopsy on the body, 
    testified that there was a â€œloose contact gunshot wound to the left side of 
    the head.â€Â  The pathologist further explained that â€œ[t]he gun was just brushing 
    the skin.â€Â  

 
   
    [3]  South Carolina courts have defined involuntary manslaughter as either 
    (1) the killing of another without malice and unintentionally, but while one 
    is engaged in the commission of some unlawful act not amounting to a felony 
    and not naturally tending to cause death or great bodily harm; or (2) the 
    killing of another without malice and unintentionally but while engaged in 
    the doing of a lawful act with a reckless disregard of the safety of others.Â  
    State v. Tucker, 324 S.C. 155, 170, 478 S.E.2d 260, 268 (1996), 
    cert. denied, 520 U.S. 1200 (1997).Â  For a homicide to be deemed an accident, 
    there must be evidence that the killing was unintentional, the defendant was 
    acting lawfully, and due care was exercised in the handling of the weapon.Â  
    State v. Goodson, 312 S.C. 278, 280, 440 S.E.2d 370, 372 (1994).

 
   
    [4]  The majority also cites to State v. White, 253 S.C. 475, 478, 
    171 S.E.2d 712, 714 (1969), for the proposition that the negligent handling 
    of a loaded gun supports a finding for involuntary manslaughter.Â  Although 
    White does cite that proposition of law, the opinion does not discuss 
    whether the defendant was entitled to an involuntary manslaughter charge based 
    on the negligent mishandling of a loaded gun.Â  The issue in White was 
    whether the trial judge erred in allowing an indictment for murder to go to 
    the jury when the only charge submitted to the jury was involuntary manslaughter.Â  
  

 
   
    [5]  The only other cases in which our appellate courts have found that 
    a defendantâ€™s negligent handling of a loaded firearm supported a charge for 
    involuntary manslaughter are State v. Causer, 87 S.C. 516, 517, 70 
    S.E. 161, 161 (1911) (defendant took a hunting rifle away from decedent, who 
    had been pointing the gun at two little boys, and defendant was walking away 
    with the gun when, â€œin some unexplained way it went off, killing the [decedent], 
    who had walked up behindâ€); State v. Tucker, 86 S.C. 211, 212, 68 S.E. 
    523, 524 (1910) (defendant was â€œrubbing [a] pistolâ€ while sitting next to 
    his half-brother, and â€œwithout knowing that [the pistol] was loaded or that 
    his brother was in front of him, [defendant] pulled the trigger without meaning 
    to do soâ€); State v. Revels, 86 S.C. 213, 214-215, 68 S.E. 523, 523 
    (1910) (a decedent grabbed and pulled on the defendantâ€™s cocked gun when it 
    fired, fatally shooting decedent in the knee); State v. Gilliam, 66 
    S.C. 419, 421, 45 S.E. 6, 7 (1903) (defendant and his decedent wife were â€œin 
    a playful tussleâ€ for the possession of a pistol when the gun unintentionally 
    fired).Â Â Â  Notably, all of these cases differ from the case at hand because 
    the negligent mishandling of the weapon coincided with lawful activities.Â

title: Seabrook Island v. Marchland Trust
description: Property owners' association brought a declaratory judgment action and an action for an injunction against a development company to prevent the construction of a bridge from a lot on Seabrook Island to two nearby marsh islands.  The association appealed the circuit court's finding that the association did not have the right to deny the construction and the court's denial of the association's request for an injunction.  We affirm.
