THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Seabrook Island Property Owners Association,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Marshland Trust, Inc., Orangehill
Plantation, LLC and Michael Casa,        Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Clifton Newman, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3791
Heard December 9, 2003 â€“ Filed May 3, 
  2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
David B. Wheeler & Edward T. Fenno, of Charleston, for Appellant.
Timothy A. Domin, of Charleston, 
  for Respondents.
      
    
  

CURETON, A.J.: Seabrook Island 
  Property Owners Association (the â€œAssociationâ€) brought this action against 
  Michael Casa and his development companies, Marshland Trust, Inc., and Orangehill 
  Plantation, LLC, (collectively, â€œDevelopersâ€), to prevent construction of a 
  bridge from Seabrook Island to two nearby marsh islands.Â  The circuit court 
  found the Association did not have the right to deny the construction and denied 
  the Associationâ€™s request for an injunction.Â  The Association appeals.Â  We affirm. 

FACTS
Seabrook Island is a restricted-access resort community in 
  Charleston County, South Carolina.Â  In 1972, the subdivision of Seabrook Island 
  was zoned as a planned unit development (â€œPUDâ€) for Charleston County, which 
  allowed for multiple zoning uses without the need to obtain separate zoning 
  approval for each use.Â Â  Seabrook Island formed the Association to enforce the 
  restrictive covenants within the PUD.Â  In 1987, the incorporation of the Town 
  of Seabrook Island shifted control of the area from the county to the Town, 
  and the Town adopted the countyâ€™s PUD provisions.Â Â Â  
Casa owned two lots in Seabrook Island 
  in Area 6 of the PUD.Â  Area 6 was zoned mixed commercial and residential.Â  One 
  of the lots was located in the commercial area and another lot, Lot 5, was located 
  in a primarily residential area known as Marsh Creek.Â  Casa intended to develop 
  patio homes on Lot 5.Â  Marsh Creek is subject to the Associationâ€™s Covenants.Â Â Â  

In 1995, Developers outbid the Association and 
  purchased from the United States Bankruptcy Trustee two islands, Islands A and 
  B, located in the marsh near Seabrook Island.Â  Developers originally 
  sought a permit from the South Carolina Office of Ocean and Coastal Resource 
  Management (OCRM) to build two bridges to access the islands â€“ one 350 foot 
  bridge from Lot 5 to Island B and a 750 foot bridge from Casaâ€™s commercial lot 
  to Island A.Â  Developers changed their proposal to using Lot 5 as the jumping 
  off point for a bridge or â€œdrivewayâ€ to both islands.Â  A single 290 foot bridge, 
  emanating from Lot 5, would go to Island B, and a 600 foot bridge would emanate 
  from Island B to Island A.  [1]  
 

After receiving permit approval from the OCRM for 
  the single bridge proprosal, Developers submitted an application to the Associationâ€™s 
  Architectural Review Board (â€œARBâ€) for permission to install a curb cut on Lot 
  5 for access to Islands A and B.Â  The ARB denied Developersâ€™ proposal, believing 
  the islands were located outside the PUD. 
  [2] Â  The ARB informed Developers that it had no authority to approve a 
  curb cut for access to property outside the PUD.Â  The ARB denied Developersâ€™ 
  appeal, stating it would continue to deny any plans showing an easement across 
  Lot 5 to access the islands.Â  Â Â Â 
The Association then filed suit seeking: 
  (i) a declaratory judgment on its right to regulate use of Lot 5; (ii) a permanent 
  injunction against Developers from using Lot 5 or any other property within 
  the Seabrook Island Development to access Islands A and B; and (iii) an injunction 
  against Developers from using Lot 5 for any other nonresidential purpose.Â  
  The circuit court found the Association did not have the right to deny Developersâ€™ 
  use of Lot 5 as a â€œjumping off pointâ€ for the islands and denied injunctive 
  relief.Â  Â The judge stated although ARB approval is required for the 
  bridge, Developers should be allowed to use Lot 5; otherwise, access to the 
  islands would be unreasonably restricted.Â  The judge based his decision on favoring 
  Developersâ€™ free use of property.Â Â  The Association appeals.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
A declaratory judgment action is neither 
  legal nor equitable in nature, but it takes on the tenor of the underlying action.Â  
  Gordon v. Colonial Ins. Co. of California, 342 S.C. 152, 155, 536 S.E.2d 
  376, 378 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  â€œAn action to enforce restrictive covenants by injunction 
  is in equity.â€Â  Kneale v. Bonds, 317 S.C. 262, 265, 452 S.E.2d 840, 841 
  (Ct. App. 1994).Â  On appeal from an action at equity, tried by the judge alone 
  without a reference, the appellate court has jurisdiction to find facts in accordance 
  with its view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  In re Thames, 344 
  S.C. 564, 571, 544 S.E.2d 854, 857 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  â€œHowever, this broad scope 
  of review does not require the appellate court to ignore the findings below 
  when the trial court was in a better position to evaluate the credibility of 
  the witnesses.â€Â  Id.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  RESTRICTIVE 
  COVENANTS
The Association argues the restrictive covenants 
  convey upon it and the ARB the right to deny Developersâ€™ plan to construct a 
  bridge to Islands A and B.Â  The Association further argues the circuit court 
  erred in relying upon a zoning ordinance to supersede the authority found in 
  the restrictive covenants.Â  We disagree.
A.
The language of a restrictive covenant is to be 
  construed according to the plain and ordinary meaning attributed to it at the 
  time of execution.Â  Taylor v. Lindsey, 332 S.C. 1, 4, 498 S.E.2d 862, 
  863 (1998).Â  â€œ[A]s voluntary contracts, restrictive covenants will be enforced 
  unless they are indefinite or contravene public policy.â€Â  Houck v. Rivers, 
  316 S.C. 414, 416, 450 S.E.2d 106, 108 (Ct. App. 1994).Â  Restrictions on the 
  use of property will be strictly construed with all doubts resolved in favor 
  of free use of the property, although the rule of strict construction should 
  not be used to defeat the plain and obvious purpose of the restrictive covenant.Â  
  Taylor, 332 S.C. at 4, 498 S.E.2d at 864.Â  Although an architectural 
  review board has discretion regarding approval of proposed construction, that 
  discretion is â€œconstrained only by reasonableness and good faith.â€Â  River 
  Hills Prop. Owners Assâ€™n v. Amato, 326 S.C. 255, 259, 487 S.E.2d 179, 181 
  (1997); Oâ€™Shea v. Lesser, 308 S.C. 10, 15, 416 S.E.2d 629, 632 (1992). 

The Association first argues: (1) the Covenants apply to 
  Lot 5, the Covenants give the Association broad discretion to reject the bridge 
  proposal, and (2) it is reasonable for the Association to deny construction 
  of the bridge.Â  As explained below, we agree with the circuit court that it 
  is unreasonable for the Association to deny construction of the bridge on Lot 
  5.
Developersâ€™ counsel admitted, and Casa 
  testified at trial, that Lot 5 was subject to the Associationâ€™s Covenants.Â Â  
  Further, the deed to Lot 5 provided that the property was subject to the Covenants.Â  
  The Covenants grant the Association the right to adopt and enforce regulations 
  pertaining to â€œplanning, construction and design of improvements on property 
  or alterations thereto.â€Â  Association Covenants Â§ 2.Â Â  The Covenants give sole 
  discretion to the Board or the ARB to approve or disapprove of plans â€œbased 
  upon any ground, including purely aesthetic conditions.â€Â  Id. at Â§ 19.Â  
  Â The sections of the Covenants pertinent to this appeal provide as follows:

â€œNo building of any kind or description, fence, swimming 
  pool, or other structure, shall be erected, placed, or altered on any Lot in 
  the Seabrook Island Development, until the proposed building plans . . . shall 
  have been approved in writing by the . . . [Associationâ€™s] Architectural Review 
  Board . . . .â€Â  Association Covenants Â§ 19.
â€œThe design and location of [bridges] on Property which is 
  . . . subject to these Covenants, must be approved by the ARB.â€Â  Id. 
  Â§ 25.

The circuit court held the islands were listed 
  within the Countyâ€™s original PUD, which was adopted by the Town of Seabrook 
  Island.Â Â  The court found Lot 5 was subject to the restrictions in the Covenants, 
  but the restrictions conflicted with the mixed commercial/residential use permitted 
  in Area 6.Â  Although the court found that the â€œdrivewayâ€/bridge from Lot 5 to 
  the islands would be a â€œbuilding . . . or other structureâ€ subject to the ARBâ€™s 
  approval under Covenant Â§ 19, Developers were nevertheless entitled to use Lot 
  5 as a driveway to the island.Â Â  The court found that otherwise, â€œaccess to 
  the islands would be unreasonably restricted, and [Developers] would be . . 
  . unjustifiably denied the free use of its property.â€ 
Reviewing the restrictive covenants and strictly 
  construing them in favor of free use of the property, we find the circuit court 
  did not commit error.Â  The Covenants grant the ARB the right to approve or disapprove 
  building plans, even for purely aesthetic reasons.Â  Lot 5, as admitted by Developers 
  and pursuant to deed, is subject to those restrictions.Â  However, to outright 
  deny building a driveway/bridge from Lot 5 would deny access to the islands.Â  
  Although the ARB had the power to generally approve or disapprove of specific 
  bridge plans â€œon any grounds,â€ to outright deny the building of a bridge that 
  would give access to the islands would be an unreasonable exercise of that power.Â  
  Based on a preponderance of the evidence, the circuit court correctly held that 
  it would not grant the Association a declaratory judgment finding the Association 
  had the authority to deny Developersâ€™ request to build a bridge.Â  
B.
In its next argument, the Association states the 
  circuit court erroneously relied upon a â€œzoning ordinanceâ€ to supersede the 
  effect of the Covenants.Â  The Association, however, essentially argues the court 
  erred in relying upon the permitted uses of the PUD for Area 6.Â  We find the 
  circuit court did not commit error.Â  
The Covenants appear to restrict their residential provisions 
  to residential property.Â  Covenant Â§ 5 provides that â€œ[a]ll property shown 
  in the PUD as residential property which is now or hereafter becomes, by 
  express reference or otherwise, subject to these Covenants, shall be used for 
  residential purposes only.â€Â  Covenants Â§ 5 (emphasis added).Â  As previously 
  discussed, Lot 5 is located in a section known as Area 6, and Area 6 is â€œshown 
  in the PUDâ€ as allowing a mixture of commercial and residential use.Â Â  As admitted 
  by Developers, Lot 5 is subject to the Covenants by deed.Â  
Reviewing the conflict between the restriction 
  in application in the Covenants to properties shown in the PUD as residential 
  and the mixed commercial/residential use allowed in the PUD for Area 6, the 
  circuit court noted as follows:

I find that while Lot 5 is subject to the foregoing provisions 
  of the [Association] covenants, these provisions, as applied to [Developers], 
  conflict with the permitted use of the property in Area 6.Â  If [sic] find that 
  these provisions should not be interpreted to prohibit [Developersâ€™] use of 
  its property considering the mixed use allowed for other property located in 
  Area 6.Â  I find that when read as a whole the entire [Association] covenants 
  and PUD documents do not give the [Association] the right to deny [Developers] 
  the right to use the property as the â€œjumping off pointâ€ for the two islands.Â  


The Association points to this portion of the circuit courtâ€™s 
  order as proof that the judge erroneously relied upon the uses allowed for Area 
  6 instead of relying upon the applicable Covenants.Â  Clearly, the circuit court 
  did not rely on the allowed uses for Area 6; instead, the court merely pointed 
  out the conflict between the restriction in the Covenants to residential uses 
  â€œas shown in the PUDâ€ and the allowance of commercial uses listed in the PUD 
  for Area 6.Â  Despite the conflict, the circuit court found that nothing granted 
  the Association the right to deny complete access to the islands.Â  To deny complete 
  access to the islands would be an unreasonable exercise of the Associationâ€™s 
  authority.Â  Resolving this conflict in favor of free use of the property, we 
  find the circuit court did not commit any error.Â  See S.C. Depâ€™t of 
  Natural Res. v. Town of McClellanville, 345 S.C. 617, 622, 550 S.E.2d 299, 
  302 (2001) (â€œA restriction on the use of property must be created in express 
  terms or by plain and unmistakable implication, and all such restrictions are 
  to be strictly construed, with all doubts resolved in favor of the free use 
  of property.â€).
The Association further asserts the circuit court 
  erred by failing to find that Lot 5 was â€œsetâ€ as a residential property, despite 
  the mixed commercial/residential use allowed in the PUD for Area 6.Â  
Developers submitted plans to build patio homes 
  on Lot 5, in addition to using Lot 5 as the starting point for the â€œdrivewayâ€/bridge 
  to the islands.Â  The area surrounding Lot 5, Marsh Creek, contained purely residential 
  developments.Â Â  The Association argues this makes it clear that the character 
  of Lot 5 has been set as residential, and the circuit court erred in relying 
  upon the mixed use allowed by the PUD for Area 6 to overcome the restrictions 
  on building bridges as found in the Covenants.Â Â Â  
Although the developments surrounding Lot 5 in 
  Marsh Creek have been strictly residential, the circuit court correctly pointed 
  out in its order that â€œnothing in the governing PUD limits the use of Area 6 
  and Marsh Creek to residential use only.â€Â  Thus, nothing in either the Covenants 
  or the PUD indicates that the type of development located on Lot 5 has to be 
  residential.Â  Despite pointing out this conflict, the circuit court relied on 
  the potential restriction of free use of property if the Association were allowed 
  to completely bar construction of a driveway/bridge.Â  Thus, the circuit court 
  did not rely upon the PUD provisions to â€œoverrideâ€ the Covenants; the court 
  merely found the Associationâ€™s denial of a driveway unreasonable.Â  Accordingly, 
  there is no merit to the Associationâ€™s argument.Â  
We further note that it is unreasonable for the 
  Association to deny construction of the bridge because the bridge is essentially 
  a driveway to a single-family residence, and therefore, clearly a residential 
  use.Â  Developersâ€™ proposal states the bridge would be wooden and would 
  be only 14 feet wide and a total of 890 feet long.Â  The bridge would begin on 
  Lot 5, continue 290 feet to Island B, then 600 feet to Island A. Â A bridge 
  emanating from the commercial lot would be longer and more of an imposition 
  to the natural marsh environment.Â  OCRM did not approve a proposal concerning 
  a bridge emanating from the commercial lot.Â  The only approved plan was a bridge 
  from Lot 5.Â  Considering the proposed size and general appearance of the bridge, 
  it would be unreasonable for the Association to deny construction of the bridge 
  based on the argument it is commercial.Â Â  
While Lot 5 is subject to the Associationâ€™s Covenants, we 
  find the circuit court judge committed no error in finding the Association does 
  not have the right to deny Developers the use of the property as a jumping off 
  point for access to the islands.
II.Â  DENIAL OF 
  ACCESS
The Association also argues denying construction 
  of the bridge on Lot 5 would not unreasonably restrict access to the islands 
  because Developers can access the islands from Casaâ€™s adjacent commercial property 
  on Landfall Way.Â  However, Casa testified using Lot 5 as the jumping off point 
  would lead to a much more efficient and aesthetically pleasing way to build 
  the bridge.Â Â  Casa stated although he could use his commercial property as a 
  jumping off point, that would require using two separate bridges for a total 
  length of 1100 feet, whereas using Lot 5 allows the project to be consolidated 
  into one bridge that has less impact on the environment.Â Â  Further, OCRM approved 
  the plan with the bridge coming from Lot 5, not the plan with two bridges.Â Â  

Because using Lot 5 as the jumping off point allows the most 
  efficient and aesthetically pleasing way to construct the bridge, we find it 
  was proper for the circuit court judge to find Developers would be unreasonably 
  restricted from using Islands A and B if Lot 5 could not be used as a jumping 
  off point.
III.Â  DENIAL OF 
  INJUNCTIVE RELIEF
The Association argues the circuit court erred 
  in failing to grant its request for injunctive relief to enforce its valid restrictive 
  covenants.Â  We disagree.
â€œThe remedy of injunction is a drastic one and 
  should be cautiously applied only when legal rights are unlawfully invaded or 
  legal duties are willfully or wantonly neglected.â€Â  LeFurgy v. Long Cove 
  Club Ownersâ€™ Assâ€™n, Inc., 313 S.C. 555, 558, 443 S.E.2d 577, 578 (Ct. App. 
  1994).Â  â€œThe issuance of an injunction depends upon the equities between the 
  parties and if great injury will be done to the [party sought to be enjoined] 
  with little benefit to the other property owners, it is proper for the trial 
  court to deny equitable relief.â€Â  Kneale, 317 S.C. at 268, 452 S.E.2d 
  at 843.
Reviewing the evidence before this Court, we find 
  the circuit court correctly denied the Associationâ€™s request for an injunction.Â  
  The Association sought to deny the construction of any bridge to the 
  islands, thus denying complete access.Â  The circuit court held there was no 
  likelihood of irreparable harm to the Association if the injunction were denied 
  and great harm, in the form of denial of the free use of property, to Developers 
  if the injunction were granted.Â  Although the Covenants give the Association 
  the right to approve or disapprove of plans, including bridges, these restrictions 
  must be strictly construed in favor of the free use of property.Â  Taylor, 
  332 S.C. at 4, 498 S.E.2d at 864.Â  Because an injunction on the building of 
  a bridge to the islands would greatly harm Developersâ€™ ability to access the 
  property, we find the circuit court correctly denied the injunction.Â  
CONCLUSION
In order to allow Developers free use of Islands 
  A and B, some form of access to the islands is required.Â  We find using Lot 
  5 as a jumping off point is both a residential use of property and the most 
  efficient and aesthetically pleasing way to construct the bridge.Â  Based on 
  the above, the decision of the circuit court is 
 AFFIRMED.Â  
 GOOLSBY and ANDERSON, JJ., concur.    

 
   
    [1]  Interestingly, Developers informed the Court at oral argument that 
    they had settled a separate dispute with the Town of Seabrook Island.Â  As 
    part of that settlement, Developers agreed to only develop Island B.Â  Island 
    A would remain a natural area.Â  Thus, only one bridge, emanating from Lot 
    5, would be necessary and there would be less of an imposition on the natural 
    marsh environment.Â  However, because this settlement was not between the two 
    parties in the current appeal and was not a matter in the Record before us, 
    we cannot consider this agreement.Â Â  

 
   
    [2] The circuit court held the islands were within the PUD.Â  The Association 
    has not appealed this finding, and it is the law of the case.Â  ML-Lee Acquisition 
    Fund, L.P. v. Deloitte & Touche, 327 S.C. 238, 241, 489 S.E.2d 470, 
    472 (1997) (holding that an unappealed ruling is the law of the case).Â

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Clotell Bateman,       
Respondent/Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Helen V. Rouse,       
Appellant/Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
A. Victor Rawl, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3792
Heard March 11, 2004 â€“ Filed May 3, 
  2004

REVERSED and REMANDED


  
    
      
Craig E. Burgess, of Atlanta, for Appellant-Respondent.
Deena Smith McRackan, of Charleston, for Respondent-Appellant.
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.: Clotell Bateman brought 
  this action against Helen V. Rouse alleging conversion and wrongful withholding 
  of certain funds and personal property due to the widow of Robert L. Bateman.Â  
  The trial court issued an order awarding certain items of property to each party.Â  
  Both parties appeal.Â  We reverse and remand for a new trial.
FACTS
Clotell Bateman married Robert 
  Bateman in 1944 when she was sixteen years old.Â  The couple lived together continuously 
  until 1968.Â  On November 14, 1983, Robert Bateman purportedly obtained a divorce 
  from Clotell.Â  In 1988, Robert married Helen Rouse.Â  Robert died on August 9, 
  1994.Â  Upon his death, Helen received survivorâ€™s pension benefits, workerâ€™s 
  death benefits under Social Security, survivorâ€™s insurance policy proceeds, 
  and a flag from the Veterans Administration.Â  
In 1996, Clotell filed a motion to vacate 
  the order of divorce, contending that the decree was void and that Robertâ€™s 
  marriage to Helen was invalid.Â  On July 7, 1997, the family court declared the 
  1983 divorce decree void ab initio due to Robertâ€™s misrepresentations 
  and fraud upon the court in obtaining service by publication in his action for 
  divorce.Â  Therefore, the family court found the divorce decree and Robertâ€™s 
  marriage to Helen were void, and declared Clotell to be Robertâ€™s wife at the 
  date of his death.Â  The family court ordered that â€œany funds due to the widow 
  of [Robert] be paid over to [Clotell].â€Â  This order was not appealed.
Clotell brought this action on May 12, 2000 
  seeking to recover the following items that had been disbursed to Helen in her 
  capacity as Robertâ€™s widow:

  a)    Â $41,619.48 received from 
  Robertâ€™s pension;
  b)   a death benefit of $10,000 under 
  the Pension and Welfare Fund;
  c)    $35,000 survivorâ€™s insurance 
  policy proceeds under the Welfare Fund;
  d)   certain other bonuses and benefits;
  e)    a flag and certificate from 
  the Veterans Administration; and
  f)     Robertâ€™s discharge 
  papers.

Clotell alleged Helen committed conversion 
  and wrongful withholding [1]  
  by obtaining these items that rightfully belong to Clotell, as Robertâ€™s widow 
  under the 1997 family court order.Â  Helen answered Clotellâ€™s complaint, specifically 
  requesting a jury trial and asserting several equitable defenses. Â The 
  case was set on the jury roster in Charleston County.Â  Immediately before the 
  trial began, the trial judge ruled on his own motion that Helen did not have 
  a right to a jury trial because the claims and defenses were equitable in nature.Â  
  In denying Helenâ€™s request for a jury trial, the trial judge stated:

Now, bottom line is this.Â  No matter which way you couch it, [Clotellâ€™s] action 
  arises upon the basis of a family court decision unappealed from, finding that 
  their marriage was never ended, because jurisdiction in the â€™82 divorce action 
  was never conferred upon the family court in Charleston County.Â  Thatâ€™s it.
The defenses as raised, even though it may be styled as conversion, the defenses 
  as raised are all equitable.Â  In an equity cause of action the trial court has 
  to find matters of fact and matters of law in order to resolve equitable issues.Â  
  Just because thereâ€™s a question of fact in an equitable defense does not mean 
  itâ€™s a trial by jury.Â  It canâ€™t be.Â  If that were the case, then you could never 
  have a trial by court only, under equity, master in equity, or other issues, 
  because in every single case there has to be a finding of fact, conclusion of 
  law, an order in order to resolve the case
. . . .
Now, it is equity, no matter which way you cut it.Â  The reason it is equity 
  is because the family court made a decision that gave rights to [Clotell], perhaps.Â  
  Whether it should be here or in probate court, Iâ€™m not going to address that 
  issue except perhaps in a final order.
. . . .
I find as a matter of law that this is in essence an equitable action pursuant 
  to the code section â€“ excuse me, not the code section, Rule 39(a) and (b).Â  
  I do not find that [Helen] has a jury issue in this particular case.Â  I find 
  further that [Clotell] in her filing did not request a trial by jury, and therefore 
  weâ€™re going to go forward today as a nonjury trial.Â  Obviously both sidesâ€™ rights 
  are protected pursuant to my decision.Â  

The trial judge then advised counsel 
  that the jury trial issue was not immediately appealable and denied Helenâ€™s 
  motion to hold the matter in abeyance to allow for appeal.Â  The case proceeded 
  to trial that same day after a brief recess.
At the close of her case 
  in chief, Clotell moved to amend the pleadings to include causes of action for 
  recoupment and unjust enrichment.Â  The judge took the matter under advisement 
  until the conclusion of the case.Â  
In the final order dated June 17, 2002, 
  the trial judge found sufficient evidence to support the causes of action for 
  conversion and wrongful withholding, but did not find sufficient evidence to 
  support the claim for recoupment.Â  In addition, the judge found that while Helen 
  had been unjustly enriched at Clotellâ€™s expense, Clotellâ€™s original claims for 
  conversion and wrongful withholding afforded her sufficient relief.Â  He therefore 
  granted judgment against Helen in the amount of $41,619.48 for the survivorâ€™s 
  pension benefits and $255 for the workerâ€™s death benefit under Social Security.Â  
  He also awarded Clotell the flag from the Veterans Administration.Â  Clotellâ€™s 
  claims for return of the $35,000 survivorâ€™s insurance proceeds under the Welfare 
  Fund and the $10,000 death benefits were denied on the grounds that Robertâ€™s 
  designation of Helen as beneficiary was evidence of his intent that she receive 
  the proceeds and benefits.Â  Helen appeals, arguing the trial judge erred in 
  (1) denying her right to a jury trial, (2) refusing to grant her motion for 
  directed verdict, and (3) denying her equitable defenses.Â  Clotell also appeals, 
  asserting the trial judge erred by (1) failing to award her the $35,000 insurance 
  proceeds, and (2) excluding certain testimony.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS

  I.                 
Denial of the request for a jury trial 
   

Helen argues the trial judge erred in ruling 
  she did not have a right to a jury trial because Clotellâ€™s claim for conversion 
  was an action at law.Â  We agree.
The South Carolina Constitution 
  preserves the right of trial by jury only in those cases in which parties would 
  have been entitled to it at the time of the adoption of the Constitution.Â  Lester 
  v. Dawson, 327 S.C. 263, 267, 491 S.E.2d 240, 242 (1997).Â  See also 
  Rule 38 (a), SCRCP (â€œThe right of trial by jury as declared by the Constitution 
  or as given by a statute of South Carolina shall be preserved to the parties 
  inviolate.Â  Issues of fact in an action for the recovery of money only or of 
  specific real or personal property must be tried by a jury, unless a jury trial 
  be waived.â€).Â Â  â€œGenerally, the relevant question in determining the right to 
  trial by jury is whether an action is legal or equitable; there is no right 
  to trial by jury for equitable actions.â€Â  Lester, 327 S.C. at 267, 491 
  S.E.2d at 242 (citation omitted).Â  Whether an action is legal or equitable is 
  primarily determined by the allegations in the complaint.Â  See Natâ€™l 
  Bank of South Carolina v. Daniels, 283 S.C. 438, 440, 322 S.E.2d 689, 690 
  (Ct. App. 1984).Â  Where legal and equitable issues or rights are raised in the 
  same complaint, the legal issues are for determination by a jury and the equitable 
  issues are for determination by the court.Â  Floyd v. Floyd, 306 S.C. 
  376, 379, 412 S.E.2d 397, 398-99 (1991).Â  Furthermore, either party may demand 
  a trial by jury of any issue triable by jury.Â  See Rule 38 (b), SCRCP.Â Â  

 â€œAn action for damages for conversion 
  is an action at law.â€Â  Blackwell v. Blackwell, 289 S.C. 470, 471, 346 
  S.E.2d 731, 732 (Ct. App. 1986) (citation omitted).Â  In this case, Clotell asserted 
  causes of action for conversion, wrongful withholding, recoupment, and unjust 
  enrichment.Â  In addition to seeking equitable relief in the form of possession 
  of items of personal property, Clotell asserted a legal cause of action for 
  conversion and sought damages in the amount of the funds received by Helen as 
  Robertâ€™s widow, and pre- and post-judgment interest.Â  Furthermore, Helen properly 
  endorsed upon her answer a demand for a jury trial.Â  See Rule 38(b), 
  SCRCP.Â  Helenâ€™s assertion of equitable defenses does not change the nature of 
  Clotellâ€™s conversion claim from an action at law to one in equity.Â  Rather, 
  such equitable defenses are equitable issues for determination by the court.Â  
  See Hann v. Carolina Cas. Ins. Co., 252 S.C. 518, 526, 167 S.E.2d 
  420, 424 (1969).Â  Accordingly, we hold the trial judge erred in denying Helenâ€™s 
  request for a jury trial on Clotellâ€™s claim for conversion.Â  See Floyd, 
  306 S.C. at 379, 412 S.E.2d at 398-99.Â  

  II.             
Failure to immediately appeal 
   

Clotell argues that Helen waived 
  her right to a jury trial by not immediately appealing the trial judgeâ€™s denial 
  of her request for a jury trial.Â  We disagree.Â  
Not only did the trial judge err 
  in finding Helen did not have a right to a jury trial, but he also erred in 
  finding the denial of a right to a jury trial is not immediately appealable.Â Â  
  Orders of the trial judge denying a request for a jury trial involve the mode 
  of trial, affect substantial rights under section 14-3-330(2) of the South Carolina 
  Code (1976 & Supp. 2003), and are immediately appealable.Â  See Lester, 
  327 S.C. at 266, 491 S.E.2d at 241.Â  The failure to immediately appeal an order 
  affecting the mode of trial constitutes a waiver of the right to appeal these 
  issues.Â  Id.Â  
In Lester v. Dawson, 327 
  S.C. 263, 491 S.E.2d 240 (1997), an attorney brought an action to collect attorneyâ€™s 
  fees from a client.Â  The client made at least two pre-trial motions for a jury 
  trial.Â  The circuit court rejected the clientâ€™s motion for a jury trial and 
  placed the case on the non-jury roster.Â  The denial of the motion was not appealed 
  from; rather, the client renewed his motion that the case be transferred to 
  the jury roster at trial.Â  The circuit court found the question moot because 
  the client had not appealed from the previous order.Â  Id. atÂ  265, 491 
  S.E.2d at 241.Â  The supreme court agreed, finding the client waived his right 
  to a jury trial by not immediately appealing the order denying his motion for 
  a jury trial.Â  
 Here, Helen had no opportunity to immediately 
  appeal from the trial judgeâ€™s sua sponte decision to hold a non-jury 
  trial because the trial was held that same day after only a brief recess.Â  When 
  Helen requested that the case be continued to allow her to appeal, the trial 
  judge refused her request, declaring that a right to a jury trial was not immediately 
  appealable.Â  Thus, while the judgeâ€™s denial of Helenâ€™s request for a jury trial 
  was immediately appealable, we find this case is not controlled by the waiver 
  principles expressed in Lester.
Moreover, in other cases in which our 
  supreme court has required an immediate appeal from the denial of a jury trial, 
  the moving party had the opportunity to appeal when the trial court issued an 
  order of reference to a master-in-equity.Â  See, e.g., Edwards 
  v. Timmons, 297 S.C. 314, 316, 377 S.E.2d 97, 97 (1988) (holding that the 
  trial courtâ€™s unappealed order of reference to a master-in-equity became the 
  law of the case); Creed v. Stokes, 285 S.C. 542, 542-43, 313 S.E.2d 351, 
  351 (1985) (finding the appellant waived his objection to the order of reference 
  by not immediately appealing the order).Â  In this case, however, no order of 
  reference was ever issued.Â  Because the judge also denied Helenâ€™s motion to 
  hold the case in abeyance and because the non-jury trial proceeded shortly after 
  the judge made his erroneous finding that Helen had no right to a jury trial, 
  Helen had no meaningful opportunity to immediately appeal.Â  The judgeâ€™s denial 
  of Helenâ€™s motion to hold the trial in abeyance placed counsel in an untenable 
  position, as Helenâ€™s counsel could not both proceed with the trial and immediately 
  appeal the jury trial issue.Â  
Furthermore, the purpose of requiring 
  an immediate appeal of the denial of the right to a jury trial is to preserve 
  a partyâ€™s constitutional rights that would otherwise be lost.Â  See generally 
  S.C. Const. Art. I, Â§ 14; S.C. Code Ann. Â§14-3-330(2) (1976).Â  In this case, 
  Helenâ€™s constitutional right to a trial by jury on the conversion issue was 
  lost through no fault of her own.Â  Helen made every effort to assert her right 
  to a jury trial and to immediately appeal the issue.Â  However, due to the trial 
  judgeâ€™s errors, Helenâ€™s constitutional right to a trial by jury was lost.Â  As 
  a result, we find Helen did not waive her right to a jury trial because she 
  was afforded no opportunity to immediately appeal the issue.
Clotell asserted in oral argument that 
  Helen further waived her right to a jury trial by not appealing following the 
  non-jury trial. [2] Â  Specifically, 
  Clotell argues that Helen should have served a notice of appeal immediately 
  after the non-jury trial concluded rather than waiting until after the judge 
  issued a written order resolving the case.Â  We disagree.
As previously noted, the purpose of requiring 
  an immediate appeal is to preserve a partyâ€™s constitutional rights that would 
  otherwise be lost.Â  See generally S.C. Const. Art. I, Â§ 14; S.C. 
  Code Ann. Â§14-3-330(2) (1976).Â  Here, Helenâ€™s constitutional right to a jury 
  trial was lost despite her best efforts to secure a jury trial.Â  Once the case 
  was tried non-jury, Helenâ€™s right to a jury trial had already been forfeited.Â  
  Under these circumstances, we do not believe the policy behind requiring an 
  immediate appeal would have been furthered had Helen appealed at the conclusion 
  of the non-jury trial.Â Â  Moreover, once the case was tried non-jury, Helen arguably 
  was required to wait for a written order prior to appealing.Â  See Rule 
  203(b)(1), SCACR (â€œA notice of appeal shall be served on all respondents within 
  thirty (30) days after receipt of written notice of entry of the order or judgment 
  . . . .Â  When a form or other short order or judgment indicates that a more 
  full and complete order or judgment is to follow, a party need not appeal until 
  receipt of written notice of entry of the more complete order or judgment.â€); 
  Ford v. State Ethics Comâ€™n, 344 S.C. 642, 646, 545 S.E.2d 821, 823 (2001) 
  (â€œThe written order is the trial judgeâ€™s final order and as such constitutes 
  the final judgment of the court.â€).Â  Thus, we find Helen preserved her right 
  to a jury trial by timely serving her notice of appeal after the final judgment. 

CONCLUSION
The trial judge erred in denying Helenâ€™s 
  request for a jury trial and compounded that error when he ruled that the denial 
  of a right to a jury trial was not immediately appealable.Â  Because Helen had 
  no opportunity to appeal from the trial judgeâ€™s ruling prior to commencing the 
  non-jury trial, we hold she did not waive her right to a jury trial.Â  This case 
  presents both legal and equitable issues, and as such, the legal issues are 
  for determination by a jury and the equitable issues are for determination by 
  the court.Â  Floyd, 306 S.C. at 380, 412 S.E.2d at 399.Â  If both the legal 
  claims and the equitable claims are to be tried in a single proceeding, the 
  legal issues are to be determined first, and the findings of the jury are binding 
  on the court.Â  Johnson v. South Carolina Natâ€™l Bank, 292 S.C. 51, 55, 
  354 S.E.2d 895, 897 (1987).Â  Therefore, we reverse and remand for a new trial. [3] 
 REVERSED AND REMANDED.
 ANDERSON and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1] Batemanâ€™s claim for wrongful withholding arises from her assertion 
    that Rouse retained her property without authorization and after demand was 
    made.Â  This court can find no South Carolina case recognizing a cause of action 
    for wrongful withholding, as distinguished from conversion, except for an 
    action for the wrongful withholding of wages by an employer.Â  See e.g., 
    Kimbrell v. Jolog Sportswear, Inc., 239 S.C. 415, 420-21, 123 S.E.2d 
    524, 527 (1962) (discussing a cause of action for the tortious withholding 
    of wages due to an employee by the employer).

 
   [2]  Helen did not file her notice of appeal until after she received 
    the judgeâ€™s written order, which was more than four months following the non-jury 
    trial.Â  

 
   
    [3]  Because we reverse and remand for a new trial on the denial of a 
    jury trial issue, we need not reach the partiesâ€™ remaining issues on appeal.Â  
    See Futch v. McAllister Towing of Georgetown, Inc., 335 S.C. 
    598, 613, 518 S.E.2d 591, 598 (1999) (ruling that an appellate court need 
    not review remaining issues when disposition of prior issues is dispositive).

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Michael M. Pirayesh, Respondent/Appellant,
v.
Mary Alice Pirayesh, Appellant/Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â Robert N. Jenkins, Sr., Family Court 
  Judge

Opinion No. 3793
Heard March 10, 2004 â€“ Filed May 11, 
  2004

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, 
  and REMANDED


  
    
      
J. Falkner Wilkes, of Greenville, for Appellant-Respondent.
Bobby H. Mann, of Greenville, for Respondent-Appellant.
      
    
  


HEARN, C.J.: Michael M. Pirayesh (Husband) 
  and Mary Alice Pirayesh (Wife) were granted a divorce on the ground of one yearâ€™s 
  continuous separation without cohabitation. Husband was granted custody of the 
  partiesâ€™ two children, but was prohibited from traveling with the children outside 
  the United States. Wife was granted visitation rights and was ordered to pay 
  child support. The parties were ordered to split the guardian ad litem fees 
  and pay their own attorneyâ€™s fees. Both parties appeal this order. We affirm 
  in part, reverse in part, and remand.
FACTS
Husband, who was born in Iran, 
  moved to the United States in 1978 and has since become a United States citizen.Â  
  On June 11, 1984, he and Wife married. The parties had two children during their 
  marriage, a son, now fifteen years old, and a daughter, now thirteen years old. 
  Â Although Wife and children have always lived together in Greenville, 
  South Carolina, Husband worked for six months in Portland, Oregon in 1996 and 
  thereafter in Atlanta, Georgia until 1998. At the time of the divorce hearing 
  in March 2001, Husband had obtained a job in Charlotte, North Carolina, and 
  had been living there for approximately one year.Â  The children resided with 
  Wife during the coupleâ€™s one yearâ€™s separation as well as during the pendency 
  of this litigation.Â  
Husband claims the marital breakdown was a result 
  of Wifeâ€™s inability to handle the family finances and the accrual of a large 
  amount of credit card debt.Â  When asked if he and Wife tried to budget their 
  money, Husband testified:

Yes, we did. . . . Like for example, we said we donâ€™t have 
  . . . certain money to spend on certain things. . . . [W]e said, if you are 
  going to make a long distance phone call letâ€™s just keep it under a hundred 
  dollars. . . . She did not follow that.Â  As a matter of fact, I have one conversation 
  that she had with her mom for a hundred and twenty minutes.Â  My ear get[s] hurt 
  after fifteen (15) minutes. . . . Grocer[ies] for example, you know.Â  We bought 
  grocer[ies]; thatâ€™s fine.Â  Half of the grocery throw away (sic). Either she 
  burned it cooking or she didnâ€™t like to eat left over food.

Husband also testified that Wife had been un- or 
  under-employed for much of the marriage despite the fact that she has always 
  been in good health.Â  
Wife contended that the failure 
  of the marriage was largely a consequence of Husbandâ€™s emotional and physical 
  distance from her and the children, due namely to his out of town employment 
  and his preoccupation with playing tennis. According to Wife, the coupleâ€™s problems 
  began when, on the day of their daughterâ€™s birth, Wife called Husband to inform 
  him that their newborn had to be monitored because she had stopped breathing. 
  Wife testified as follows:

[T]hat evening I had fed Debra, she stopped breathing.Â  And 
  I tried to wake her up.Â  And nothing was happening. . . . And I rang the nurseâ€™s 
  station from the bed. . . . They came and they got her to start breathing again.Â  
  I called [Husband and] told him what had happened.Â  .Â  . . It was probably 10 
  oâ€™clock when I called back.Â  And his response was, â€œ[Wife], I was asleep.â€Â  
  And he hung up.

Wife testified that Husbandâ€™s response to their 
  daughterâ€™s health problems made her â€œwonder[] what kind of man [she] had marriedâ€ 
  and that their marital problems only increased from then on. 
Both parties sought custody of 
  their two minor children.Â  During the presentation of Husbandâ€™s case, Husband 
  and three witnesses testified on his behalf.Â  The witnesses, all of whom knew 
  Husband through his tennis hobby, testified that both Husband and Wife 
  were loving parents. Husband testified that his primary reason for seeking custody 
  was because, during the pendency of the litigation, the water in the Wifeâ€™s 
  home was cut off twice, the phone was disconnected five times, and the electricity 
  was also turned off.Â  He also complained that Wife was late dropping the children 
  off to visit with him a number of times and that Wife did not effectively discipline 
  the children while they were in her care.Â  Husband felt he was the better parent 
  because he had a flexible job that paid $60,000 a year, he knew how to budget 
  his money, and he could control the children.Â  
During the presentation of Wifeâ€™s case, 
  seven witnesses testified that Wife was a good parent. 
  [1] Â Â Â  One of those witnesses was a neighbor who has lived next door to 
  the couple for six years.Â  The neighbor testified that he and his wife had to 
  care for Wife after she had a hysterectomy because Husband was in Atlanta during 
  the week and playing tennis on the weekend. [2] Â  The neighbor also testified that Husband seemed 
  volatile with the children.Â  Another witness testified that she helped Wife 
  with her daughterâ€™s birthday party, and at the party, Husband complained to 
  the witness about Wife.Â  The witness testified that Husband seemed â€œvery alienated 
  and angry.â€Â  
Wife testified that, in addition to having 
  primary custody of the children during the coupleâ€™s separation, she had been 
  the primary caretaker for the children during the marriage.Â  In addition to 
  Husband working out of state for two-and-a-half years, she claimed Husband played 
  tennis five days a week, no matter what was going on in their childrenâ€™s lives. 
  [3] Â  She also testified that Husband gets agitated easily and that he was 
  always critical of her and the children.Â  
Wife testified that she has worked during 
  most of the marriage and that the periods during which she was unemployed occurred 
  when the children were newborns or when they were ill. [4] Â Â  While she admitted that she had trouble paying the utilities 
  during the partiesâ€™ separation, she pointed out that she and Husband were having 
  trouble paying their bills while they were a two-income family and that those 
  problems were amplified during the separation.Â  She further explained that she 
  missed several days of work during the partiesâ€™ separation when she severely 
  burned her leg from her knee to her hip, which put a further strain on her finances. 

On cross-examination, Wife was asked about 
  counseling appointments the children had missed. [5] Â  Wife explained that the December visit was rescheduled because 
  the counselor was on vacation.Â  Wife testified that she rescheduled the next 
  visit because she was working with a woman who was nine-and-a-half months pregnant, 
  and Wife felt she could not leave the woman alone.Â  On the third attempted visit, 
  Wife and children went to the office, but when they arrived, they found out 
  that the fee had increased from ten to fifteen dollars; when Wife did not have 
  the extra money, she was told she would have to reschedule.Â  On the fourth attempt 
  at rescheduling, the brakes on Wifeâ€™s car went out on the way to the appointment. 

Wife was also asked about why the partiesâ€™ 
  daughter had not had a psychological evaluation, as previously ordered by the 
  family court, and why the daughter had missed three dentist appointments.Â  Wife 
  explained that she could not afford the psychological evaluation and Husband 
  would not help her pay for it because he did not agree that the daughter needed 
  to be evaluated.Â  As for the missed dentist appointments, Wife claimed daughter 
  had been ill. 
In addition to custody of the children, 
  another major issue was whether or not Husband would be allowed to travel with 
  the children to Iran. When questioned about his desire to bring the children 
  to Iran, Husband explained he wanted his children to visit his parents and other 
  Iranian relatives.  [6]  However, he stressed that he had no desire 
  to relocate to Iran and said he wanted Wife to remain a major part of their 
  childrenâ€™s lives.Â  
According to Wife, Husband threatened 
  on more than one occasion to move back to Iran and take the children with him.Â  
  Wife offered the testimony of Christine Uhlman to show the inherent risks to 
  children in travel to Iran, the specific risks of parent/child abduction in 
  similar situations, and the lack of any legal remedy should this occur.Â  Due 
  to her extensive experience in this area, Uhlman was qualified by the court 
  as an expert witness on child abduction in the Middle East and the remedies 
  that might be available for people who find themselves in that predicament.Â  
  The court found, however, that she did not have an adequate education or background 
  to be qualified as an expert on the law of Iran, and limited her qualification 
  to the topics listed above.Â  
The family court also heard the guardian ad litemâ€™s 
  final report concerning Husbandâ€™s travel outside of the United States and custody 
  of the two children. The guardian testified that she believed Wifeâ€™s fears that 
  Husband would abduct and relocate the children were baseless, but acknowledged 
  that travel restrictions may nevertheless be warranted.Â  She also testified 
  to some psychological, social, and physical problems of both the children and 
  her perception that these problems were not being adequately addressed.Â  The 
  guardian was also troubled by Wifeâ€™s apparent inability to meet the basic health 
  and day-to-day living needs of the children.Â  In her opinion, Husband appeared 
  to be in a better position to meet these needs and it was therefore in the best 
  interests of the children to grant him custody.Â  The guardian made this recommendation 
  to the court.Â  
The family court followed the guardianâ€™s custody 
  recommendation, granting Husband custody of both children and granting Wife 
  standard visitation rights.Â  The family court also prohibited Husband from taking 
  the children out of the United States.Â  The parties were ordered to pay for 
  their own attorneyâ€™s fees, and the cost of the guardian was split between them. 
  Both parties appeal this order.
ISSUES ON APPEAL

  
    
      
         I. 
         
  Was the guardianâ€™s recommendation the product of an independent, balanced, and 
  impartial investigation?
      
      
         II.  
         
  Did the family court err in its reliance on the guardianâ€™s recommendation in 
  determining custody of the children?
      
      
         III.  
         
  Did the family court err by requiring each party to pay half of the guardian 
  ad litemâ€™s fees?
      
      
         IV.   
         
  Did the family court err by ordering the parties to pay their own attorneyâ€™s 
  fees and costs?
      
      
         V. 
         
  Did the family court err by restricting Husband from traveling outside of the 
  United States with the children?
      
      
         VI.  
         
  Did the family court err in the apportionment of the marital debt?
      
    
  

STANDARD OF
REVIEW
On appeal from the family court, this court has 
  jurisdiction to find the facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance 
  of the evidence.Â  Murdock v. Murdock, 338 S.C. 322, 328, 526 S.E.2d 241, 
  244-45 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  This court, however, is not required to disregard the 
  family courtâ€™s findings; nor should we ignore the fact that the family court 
  judge, who saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better position to evaluate 
  their testimony.Â  Badeaux v. Davis, 337 S.C. 195, 202, 522 S.E.2d 835, 
  838 (Ct. App. 1999); Smith v. Smith, 327 S.C. 448, 453, 486 S.E.2d 516, 
  519 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  Because the appellate court lacks the opportunity for 
  direct observation of witnesses, it should give great deference to the family 
  courtâ€™s findings where matters of credibility are involved.Â  Kisling v. Allison, 
  343 S.C. 674, 678, 541 S.E.2d 273, 275 (Ct. App. 2001); Dorchester County 
  Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Miller, 324 S.C. 445, 452, 477 S.E.2d 476, 480 (Ct. 
  App. 1996).Â  This is especially true in cases involving the welfare and best 
  interests of children. Id.; see also Cook v. Cobb, 271 
  S.C. 136, 140, 245 S.E.2d 612, 614 (1978) (stating that the welfare and best 
  interests of children are the primary, paramount, and controlling considerations 
  of the court in all child custody controversies).
LAW / ANALYSIS
Wife challenges the custody order by arguing: (1) 
  that the guardianâ€™s recommendation to the court was a product of an incomplete 
  and biased investigation; and (2) that the family court improperly relied on 
  the guardianâ€™s recommendation. We agree.Â  
I. Was the guardianâ€™s recommendation the product of an independent, 
  balanced, and impartial investigation?
In Patel v. Patel, 347 S.C. 
  281, 555 S.E.2d 386 (2001), the Supreme Court of South Carolina set the base 
  line standards for the responsibilities and duties of a guardian ad litem. Foremost 
  in the courtâ€™s list of duties, the guardian shall:

â€¦conduct an independent, balanced, and impartial investigation 
  to determine the facts relevant to the situation of the child and the family, 
  which should include: reviewing relevant documents; meeting with and observing 
  the child in the home setting and considering the childâ€™s wishes, if appropriate; 
  and interviewing parents, caregivers, and others with knowledge relevant to 
  the case.

Id. at 288, 555 S.E.2d at 390 (emphasis in 
  original); see also South Carolina Private Guardian Ad Litem Reform 
  Act, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1549 (Supp. 2003) (codifying the Patel guidelines 
  with more specificity, but only directly applicable to guardians ad litem appointed 
  after January 15, 2003).Â  
In Patel, 
  the guardianâ€™s investigation reflected overwhelmingly favorable treatment toward 
  the husband and negligible consideration of the wifeâ€™s capacity to competently 
  parent the children.Â  For example, the guardian contacted the husbandâ€™s attorney 
  nineteen times, but failed to contact the wifeâ€™s counsel once. The guardian 
  had frequent contact with the husband but minimal contact with the wife, and 
  the guardian only met with the children when they were with the husband.Â  The 
  guardian even secretly listened in on phone conversations between husband and 
  wife while visiting with the husband.Â  Id. at 286, 555 S.E.2d at 388-89.Â  
  The Patel court held that the actions and inactions of the guardian so 
  tainted the decision of the family court that the wife was not afforded due 
  process, and the court remanded the issue of custody to the family court.Â  Id. 
  at 286-87, 291, 555 S.E.2d at 389, 391.Â  
We recognize that the case at hand is different 
  from Patel in that Wifeâ€™s argument stems, not from the guardianâ€™s incomplete 
  investigation of her, but rather from the guardianâ€™s allegedly superficial investigation 
  of Husbandâ€™s parenting abilities.Â  However, we believe the requirements set 
  forth in Patel were meant not only to protect the parents who are the 
  subjects of the guardianâ€™s investigation but also to ensure that the fate of 
  a childâ€™s living arrangements does not rest in the hands of a guardian whose 
  investigation is biased or otherwise incomplete.Â  Thus, a parent, whether the 
  focus of the guardianâ€™s investigation or largely ignored by the investigation, 
  may appeal a custody decision if that parent believes the family courtâ€™s order 
  was tainted by the guardianâ€™s improper investigation.
Here, the guardian visited Wifeâ€™s home several 
  times to interview her and the children.Â  However, there is no indication that 
  she ever interviewed Husband and the children while they visited his home in 
  Charlotte.Â  Instead, she testified she met with him and the children at a McDonaldâ€™s 
  restaurant one time.Â  She further testified that she went to Charlotte to view 
  Husbandâ€™s residence and the schools the children would attend if custody was 
  changed and talked on one occasion to a college student who babysat the children 
  during their two-week summer visitation with Husband. 
The guardian testified that her recommendation 
  was largely based upon the concerns of the childrenâ€™s counselor regarding counseling 
  appointments they had missed and a psychological evaluation that had still not 
  been scheduled for the partiesâ€™ daughter. Apparently, the guardian blamed 
  Wife for the missed appointments and did not believe Husband had any responsibility 
  to make sure these appointments were made.Â  However, the record indicates that 
  the counselor had sent a letter to both Husband and Wife about the missed counseling 
  sessions.Â  Furthermore, where Wife at least attempted to schedule a psychological 
  evaluation, there was no evidence that Husband did anything to ensure that the 
  evaluation was completed.Â  On cross-examination, the guardian was asked:

  
    
      
        Q:  
         [Y]ou have concerns too about the father . . . as far as 
  your investigations?
      
      
        A:   
         Right
      
      
        Q: 
         But your concerns arenâ€™t listed necessarily on your report 
  because you didnâ€™t mention them in your report that you had concerns that the 
  father had not complied with the psychological evaluation for [the daughter], 
  and not attended counseling, and not attended co-parenting counseling, and has 
  also exposed the children as far as to more â€“ that both parents have exposed 
  the children to the divorce related issues.Â  So those arenâ€™t reflected on your 
  report on the second page that I was able to see?
      
      
        A: 
         Right
      
    
  

When asked whether she wanted to explain why she 
  had not mentioned Husbandâ€™s shortcomings in her report, the guardian merely 
  stated that she did not omit them for any particular reason and again pointed 
  out that the children spent more time with Wife.Â  
Additionally, the record indicates that the guardian 
  was mistaken about some of the facts she reported to the family court.Â Â  For 
  instance, the guardian testified that the partiesâ€™ daughter had nine absences 
  from school, which contradicted Wifeâ€™s testimony.Â  However, at the hearing for 
  reconsideration, the school verified Wifeâ€™s assertion that daughter had five 
  absences. While this mistake by the guardian appeared to be inadvertent, the 
  guardian was adamant during her testimony that the daughter had four additional 
  unexcused absences. [7] Â Â  Thus, 
  the guardianâ€™s recommendation was at least partially biased because of her mistaken 
  belief that the daughter had several unexcused absences while in Wifeâ€™s care.
Based on the guardianâ€™s superficial investigation of 
  Husband, her failure to hold Husband partially responsible for the children 
  not attending counseling, and her over-reporting the number of absences daughter 
  has had at school, we agree with Wife that the guardianâ€™s recommendation did 
  not result from a fair and impartial investigation.
II. Did the family court err in its reliance on 
  the guardianâ€™s recommendation in determining custody of the children?
In determining the best interest of the 
  child in a custody dispute, the family court should consider several factors, 
  including: who has been the primary caretaker; the conduct, attributes, and 
  fitness of the parents; the opinions of third parties (including the guardian, 
  expert witnesses, and the children); and the age, health, and sex of the children.Â  
  Patel, 347 S.C. at 285, 555 S.E.2d at 388.Â  Rather than merely adopting 
  the recommendation of the guardian, the court, by its own review of all the 
  evidence, should consider the character, fitness, attitude, and inclinations 
  on the part of each parent as they impact the child as well as all psychological, 
  physical, environmental, spiritual, educational, medical, family, emotional 
  and recreational aspects of the childâ€™s life.Â  See Woodall v. Woodall, 
  322 S.C. 7, 11, 471 S.E.2d 154, 157 (1996); Epperly v. Epperly, 312 S.C. 
  411, 415, 440 S.E.2d 884, 886 (1994); Wheeler v. Gill, 307 S.C. 94, 99, 
  413 S.E.2d 860, 863 (Ct. App. 1992). When determining to whom custody shall 
  be awarded, the court should consider all the circumstances of the particular 
  case and all relevant factors must be taken into consideration.Â  Woodall, 
  322 S.C. at 11, 471 S.E.2d at 157 (1996); Ford v. Ford, 242 S.C. 344, 
  351, 130 S.E.2d 916, 921 (1963).
A key component of the supreme courtâ€™s 
  decision to remand the custody order in Patel was the fact that â€œthe 
  custody question was hotly contested, with no clear choice for custodial parent 
  apparent from the testimony in the record.â€Â  347 S.C. at 286-87, 555 S.E.2d 
  at 389.Â  Since there were no substantial considerations made on record as to 
  the issue of custody apart from the guardianâ€™s recommendation, the court refused 
  to declare harmless the judgeâ€™s reliance on a biased guardianâ€™s report.Â  Id.Â  
  Here, a total of ten witnesses (not counting the Husband, Wife, and the guardian) 
  testified about each partyâ€™s parenting abilities.Â  All ten, three of whom were 
  called by Husband, described Wife as a loving and caring mother.Â  Five witnesses 
  testified that Husband was a capable parent, but two specifically questioned 
  his parenting ability. [8] Â  Thus, aside from Husband, the 
  guardian was the only witness who believed Husband was the better parent.
Because the family court obviously gave a great deal 
  of weight to the guardianâ€™s recommendation, which we have found was based on 
  a biased and incomplete investigation, we reverse the award of custody and remand 
  the case for a new custody hearing. [9] Â Â Â Â  
III. Did the trial court err by requiring Wife to pay half 
  of the guardianâ€™s fees?
Wife next argues that the family court erred by 
  requiring her to pay half of the guardianâ€™s fees because the guardian failed 
  to conduct an independent, balanced, and impartial investigation.Â  We reverse 
  and remand this issue to the family court.Â  
Section 20-7-1553(B) of the South Carolina Code 
  (Supp. 2003) provides that a court-appointed guardian â€œis entitled to reasonable 
  compensation, subject to the review and approval of the court.â€Â  That subsection 
  goes on to list the following factors to guide family courts when awarding guardian 
  fees:

  (1)  the complexity of the issues before the court;
 (2)  the contentiousness of the litigation;
 (3)  the time expended by the guardian;
 (4)  the expenses reasonably incurred by the guardian;
 (5)  the financial ability of each party to pay fees and costs; and
 (6)  any other factors the court considers necessary.

While the ultimate work product of the guardian is not specifically 
  listed under section 20-7-1553, it certainly qualifies as another factor â€œthe 
  court considers necessary.â€Â  Thus, we remand this issue along with the issue 
  of custody.Â  Upon remand, the family court should consider the guardianâ€™s incomplete 
  investigation, along with the other factors listed in section 20-7-1553, in 
  determining the amount of fees owed to the guardian.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
IV. Did the trial court err by restricting Husband from 
  traveling outside of the United States with the children?
Husband first contends that the family 
  court erred in restricting his travel with the children because the court wrongfully 
  relied on testimony from Wifeâ€™s expert that went beyond her qualification as 
  an expert witness. We disagree.
Wifeâ€™s expert witness was qualified by 
  the court as an expert on child abduction in the Middle East and the remedies 
  that might be available for people who find themselves in that predicament.Â  
  The court went on, however, to limit that qualification to those precise topics 
  and expressly held that she was not qualified as an expert on the law of Iran.Â  
  Husband contends that her subsequent testimony on legal remedies for the recovery 
  of abducted children and the recognition of American passports in Iran was admitted 
  in error as it overstepped the limitations of her qualification as an expert.
Permitting an expert witness to testify 
  beyond the scope of his or her expertise can constitute reversible error.Â  See 
  Nelson v. Taylor, 347 S.C. 210, 218, 553 S.E.2d 488, 492 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  
  We find, however, that the specific testimony at issue here fell within the 
  expertâ€™s qualification.Â  While the family court expressly found that the expert 
  witness was not an expert in the law of Iran, certain issues relating to that 
  law are so intertwined with the parameters of the expertâ€™s qualification as 
  to be manifestly compounded.Â  One would be hard pressed to discuss the remedies 
  for child abduction in Iran without at least tangentially touching on the law 
  of Iran.Â  Therefore, we find that Wifeâ€™s expert witnessâ€™s testimony fell within 
  that narrow area of Iranian law applicable to her qualification as an expert.
Second, Husband asserts error by the family 
  court on the merits of the restriction itself.Â  Citing cases from other jurisdictions 
  which held that fear of abduction and lack of foreign remedy, without more, 
  are an insufficient showing to reverse a family court on a custodial parentâ€™s 
  right to travel with his children, Husband argues that the family court erred 
  in limiting his right to leave the United States with his children.Â  See 
  Long v. Ardestani, 624 N.W.2d 405 (Wis. Ct. App. 2001) (finding that 
  difficulty of obtaining the return of the child in the event of abduction is 
  but one factor for a court to consider in imposing restrictions and deferring 
  to the family court); Al-Zouhayli v. Al-Zouhayli, 486 N.W.2d 10 (Minn. 
  Ct. App. 1992) (deferring to the family courtâ€™s decision not to restrict travel 
  despite threats of abduction and lack of Saudi remedies).Â Â  We disagree with 
  this argument as well.Â  
The prevailing rule gleaned from the cases 
  to which Husband cites is that appellate courts generally defer to a family 
  courtâ€™s decision regarding a parentâ€™s ability to travel with his or her children. 
  We agree with the Wisconsin Court of Appeals that:

We are satisfied that the standard 
  of the best interests of the child, comprehensive as it is, permits a full consideration 
  of concerns both about a parentâ€™s intention in abducting a child and about the 
  lack of a remedy should that occur. We are also satisfied that there is no need 
  to alter the deference appellate courts give to trial courtsâ€™ decisions on a 
  childâ€™s best interests in order to insure a full consideration of those concerns.

Long, 624 N.W.2d at 417-18.
At trial, Wife presented evidence of both 
  specific threats by Husband to relocate the children to Iran as well as testimony 
  concerning the inherent dangers in these types of situations.Â  Testimony was 
  also presented regarding the generalized dangers in travel with children born 
  of Iranian descent to that country and the possibility that Husband could easily 
  fly from another country into Iran if he was allowed to travel with the children 
  outside the United States.Â  Furthermore, even if Husband had every intention 
  to return the children after their visit to Iran, if he were to become incapacitated 
  while he and the children were there, Wife could do very little to retrieve 
  the children.Â  Based on the evidence regarding Husbandâ€™s threats, the risks 
  of abduction, and the lack of legal recourse in a country which is not a signatory 
  to the Hague Convention, we affirm the family court order banning Husband from 
  travel with the children outside the United States. 
V. Did the family court err in the apportionment of the 
  marital debt?
Husband argues the family court erred in not equally 
  splitting the partiesâ€™ debts between them. He contends that since all the debt 
  was accrued during the marriage, the entirety of the debt should be split between 
  the parties regardless of whose name it is in.Â  We disagree.
Marital debt should be divided in accord with 
  the same principles used in the division of marital property and must be factored 
  into the totality of equitable apportionment.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-472 
  (Supp. 2003); Jenkins v. Jenkins, 345 S.C. 88, 103, 545 S.E.2d 531, 539 
  (Ct. App. 2001); Thomas v. Thomas, 346 S.C. 20, 27, 550 S.E.2d 580, 584 
  (Ct. App. 2001).Â  The apportionment of marital property is within the discretion 
  of the family court and will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.Â  
  Thomas v. Thomas, 346 S.C. 20, 27, 550 S.E.2d 580, 584 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  

There are many factors which the family court 
  may consider in the apportionment of marital property.Â  On review, the appellate 
  court looks to the fairness of the overall apportionment, and if the end result 
  is equitable, the fact that the appellate court may have weighed specific factors 
  differently than the family court is irrelevant.Â  Johnson v. Johnson, 
  296 S.C. 289, 300-301, 372 S.E.2d 107, 113 (Ct. App. 1988).Â  In this review, 
  our focus is on whether the family court addressed the statutory factors governing 
  apportionment with sufficiency for us to conclude that the court was cognizant 
  of these factors.Â  Doe v. Doe, 324 S.C. 492, 502, 478 S.E.2d 854, 859 
  (Ct. App. 1996). 
In its final order, the family court noted the 
  income of each party, the absence of an alimony grant to Wife and her duty to 
  pay child support, the sale of the marital residence, the tax benefits of the 
  apportionment to each party, and the child custody arrangements. Because these 
  specific findings of the family court comport with those considerations mandated 
  by section 20-7-472, we are satisfied that the court was, in fact, cognizant 
  of the statutory factors of marital apportionment when allocating the marital 
  debt between the parties. Therefore, the family court acted within its discretion 
  in ordering Husband to pay all debts held in his name.Â  
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons, the order of the family 
  court is
AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, and REMANDED.
ANDERSON and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1]  Two of Wifeâ€™s witnesses testified that Husband was a fine parent 
    as well. 

 
   
    [2]  After Husband testified on direct that Wife had no health problems, 
    he was specifically asked on cross-examination about Wifeâ€™s hysterectomy.Â  
    Husband claimed he did not know she had one.Â  Wife testified she had a hysterectomy 
    in December of 1997, before the parties separated.Â  Husband then returned 
    to the stand on reply, recalled the hysterectomy, and claimed he took nine 
    days off from work in order to care for her and the children.Â  

 
   [3]  During Husbandâ€™s cross-examination, he admitted 
    playing tennis every other day during the marriage.Â  

 
   [4]  The partiesâ€™ son had ear problems when he was 
    little and now cannot hear out of his right ear.Â  Their daughter was born 
    with three kidneys.Â  

 
   
    [5]  The children had seen the counselor regularly from June 2000 to November 
    2000; however, at the time of the divorce hearing, they had not been to a 
    session in four months.Â  

 
   [6]  Husbandâ€™s father is ninety-one 
    years old; thus, travel by him to America is not feasible. 

 
   
    [7]  In fact, the daughter did not have any unexcused absences.Â  When 
    questioning the guardian, Wifeâ€™s attorney attempted to explain that the lower 
    case â€œuâ€™sâ€ on the daughterâ€™s attendance record denoted a tardy; however, the 
    guardian stated: â€œYour eyes might be better than mine.Â  I canâ€™t â€“ I just see 
    it as a U.â€ 

 
   
    [8]  The partiesâ€™ next-door neighbor testified that Husband seemed volatile 
    with the children.Â  Another witness described Husband as â€œvery alienated and 
    angry.â€Â  

 
   
    [9]  Because we remand the issue of custody, we also remand the issue 
    of attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.

description: Richard Shawn Pipkin was convicted of attempted first-degree burglary and sentenced to twenty years imprisonment, suspended on service of ten years confinement and five years probation.  He appeals this conviction, claiming error by the trial court in disallowing testimony regarding the victimâ€™s alleged bias and denying his motion for a directed verdict.
