THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Richard Shawn Pipkin, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Georgetown County
J. Michael Baxley, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3794
Submitted March 8, 2004 â€“ Filed May 
  11, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Aileen P. Clare, Office 
  of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy 
  Attorney General John W. McIntosh and Assistant Deputy Attorney General Charles 
  H. Richardson, all of Columbia; and Solicitor John Gregory Hembree, of Conway, 
  for Respondent.
      
    
  

BEATTY, J.:Â  Richard Shawn Pipkin was convicted 
  of attempted first-degree burglary and sentenced to twenty years imprisonment, 
  suspended on service of ten years confinement and five years probation.Â  He 
  appeals this conviction, claiming error by the trial court in disallowing testimony 
  regarding the victimâ€™s alleged bias and denying his motion for a directed verdict.Â  
  We affirm. 
FACTS
Patsy Cribb and Pipkin began dating in 
  November 1998.Â  In March 1999, Pipkin moved into Cribbâ€™s apartment.Â  
  By July, their relationship had become unstable and there were instances of 
  physical abuse.Â  Cribb moved out of the shared apartment in August.Â  
In January 2000, Cribb moved into an apartment 
  in the home of her sister and brother-in-law (Richardsons).Â  After moving in 
  with the Richardsons, Cribb began seeing Pipkin â€œoccasionally.â€Â  Â 
According to Pipkin, he and Cribb began seeing 
  each other four to five times a week and renewed the sexual aspect of their 
  relationship after Cribb moved in with her sister. 
  [1] Â  Pipkin alleges he and Cribb arranged a method of entry whereby Pipkin 
  would use one of two metal wires stashed on the porch to knock away the inside 
  boards holding the doors in a locked position and let himself in.Â  Pipkin stated 
  that he utilized this method of entry about â€œtwenty or thirtyâ€ times.Â  Cribb 
  denied any arrangement for Pipkin to visit her at this apartment.Â  
Months after Cribb moved to the Richardsonsâ€™ apartment, 
  her relationship with Pipkin once again grew volatile.Â  On September 13, 2000, 
  there was an episode of physical abuse. Cribb obtained a restraining order against 
  Pipkin barring him from any contact with her.Â  Â 
On October 27, 2000, Cribb went to a local bar 
  and was talking with another man when Pipkin entered.Â  Pipkin approached the 
  two of them, threw a drink in Cribbâ€™s face, and was escorted off the premises 
  by the barâ€™s bouncers.Â  Â 
Later that night, Pipkin drove to Cribbâ€™s apartment 
  and parked down the street away from the apartment.Â  According to 
  Pipkin, he approached the apartment, knocked, and, because he could 
  not tell if Cribb was home, attempted to enter using the wire method for entry 
  as discussed above. While attempting to enter, Pipkin heard Richardson exiting 
  the home.Â  Richardson was aroused out of sleep by â€œscratching noisesâ€ under 
  his bedroom window.Â  Once Pipkin saw Richardson, Pipkin â€œeased offâ€ and 
  walked away from the doors.Â  Â Â Pipkin fled to his truck and waited.Â  
  Richardson inspected the home and found severe damage to both a downstairs window 
  and a steel door (neither a part of the sliding glass doors).Â  Richardson woke 
  Cribb and the police were called.Â  The police remained at the home for about 
  two hours.Â  
Cribb returned to her bed shortly after the police 
  left.Â  Soon thereafter, she heard metal wire beating against the sliding glass 
  doors.Â  She entered her sisterâ€™s apartment through an internal stairwell and 
  woke Richardson.Â  The two of them inspected the home and found a metal rod stuck 
  in the sliding glass door.Â  Once again the police were called.Â  This time they 
  arrived with Pipkin, whom they had detained a few blocks from the home.Â  One 
  of Pipkinâ€™s shoes was found near the home.Â  Metal rods were found in his truck 
  which matched the type found lodged in the sliding glass door.Â  Richardson positively 
  identified Pipkin and claimed that Pipkin admitted to him his attempted entry 
  into the house and offered to pay for the damages.Â  Pipkin was arrested.
While being detained at the Georgetown Detention 
  Center, Pipkin was transported to a dental clinic.Â  Also on board was inmate 
  Joseph Allen (â€œAllenâ€).Â  Allen testified that he and Pipkin discussed Pipkinâ€™s 
  case on the way to the dentist.Â  He stated that Pipkin admitted to attempting 
  the break-in for the purpose of killing Cribb if she was with another man.Â  
  His testimony included several corroborating details of the events of October 
  27, 2000. He claimed that, prior to trial, he had discussed the facts of the 
  case with no one but Pipkin.Â  
Pipkin was released on bond pending trial with strict 
  orders not to contact Cribb.Â  Cribb, nevertheless, visited Pipkinâ€™s apartment 
  to talk with him the Friday after his release.Â  After this meeting, they again 
  began having a secret love affair, meeting four to five times a week.Â  During 
  this rekindled relationship, there was another incident of severe physical abuse.Â  

At some point, Cribb allegedly broke into Pipkinâ€™s 
  trailer home and damaged some items.Â  Cribb denied these allegations, but admitted 
  at Pipkinâ€™s trial that she was jailed for the incident.Â  The judge also allowed 
  testimony from Pipkinâ€™s two brothers regarding this damage and Cribbâ€™s presence 
  at the trailer at the time of the damage.Â  During the examination of Pipkinâ€™s 
  father, however, the judge sustained objections to similar testimony on the 
  ground of relevance.Â  
Pipkin was convicted on one count of attempted first-degree 
  burglary. This appeal follows.
LAW / ANALYSIS

  I.                 
Did the trial court err in disallowing Pipkin to present evidence of 
  the victimâ€™s bias? 
   

Pipkin contends that the trial court erred 
  in excluding the testimony of Pipkinâ€™s father in relation to the alleged break-in 
  and resulting property damage caused by Cribb.Â  He argues that, since this testimony 
  would attack the credibility of a witness and show bias, it was relevant evidence 
  and should have been admitted.Â  We disagree.
Generally, the admission of trial testimony 
  is within the discretion of the trial judge and, absent an abuse of this discretion 
  and resulting prejudice, will not be reversed by a reviewing court.Â Â  See 
  State v. Tucker, 319 S.C. 425, 428, 462 S.E.2d 263, 265 (1995); State 
  v. Hamilton, 344 S.C. 344, 355, 543 S.E.2d 586, 592 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  
The initial determination a trial judge makes in deciding 
  whether to admit testimony is its relevance to the case before the court.Â  Relevant 
  evidence is â€œevidence having any tendency to make the existence of any fact 
  that is of consequence to the determination of the action more probable or less 
  probable than it would be without the evidence.â€Â  Rule 401, SCRE.Â  â€œProof of 
  bias is almost always relevant because the jury, as finder of fact and weigher 
  of credibility, has historically been entitled to assess all evidence which 
  might bear on the accuracy and truth of a witnessâ€™ testimony.â€Â  U.S. v. Abel, 
  469 U.S. 45, 52, 105 S.Ct. 465, 469 (1984).
Â Even relevant evidence may be excluded on the grounds 
  of its competency.Â  See Hamilton, 344 S.C. at 355, 543 S.E.2d 
  at 592. For instance, relevant evidence may be excluded â€œif its probative value 
  is substantially outweighed by the danger of unfair prejudice, confusion of 
  the issues, or misleading the jury, or by considerations of undue delay, waste 
  of time, or needless presentation of cumulative evidence.â€Â  Rule 403, SCRE.Â  
  A trial judgeâ€™s decision regarding the competency of testimony under this rule 
  should be reversed only in exceptional circumstances and this court is obligated 
  to give great deference to the trial courtâ€™s judgment.Â  Hamilton, 344 
  S.C. at 358, 543 S.E.2d at 593-94.Â  This decision to exclude evidence under 
  Rule 403 should not be reversed simply because an appellate court believes it 
  would have decided the matter otherwise. Id.
Regardless of whether the trial judge abused his broad 
  discretion in excluding Pipkinâ€™s fatherâ€™s testimony, the error was harmless 
  as the evidence was cumulative.Â  See State v. Beckham, 334 S.C. 
  302, 319, 513 S.E.2d 606, 614 (1999) (opining erroneous exclusion of cumulative 
  evidence is harmless).Â  Pipkin sought to show Cribbâ€™s bias through his fatherâ€™s 
  testimony that his father acquired an arrest warrant for Cribbâ€™s allegedly burglarizing 
  and damaging his mobile home.Â Â Â  
The jury heard testimony from multiple witnesses as 
  to Cribbâ€™s alleged break-in and property damage to Pipkinâ€™s trailer.Â  Although 
  Cribb denied having damaged the trailer, she admitted that Pipkinâ€™s father had 
  her arrested for this damage.Â  Not only did Cribb testify regarding the damage 
  to the mobile home, Pipkinâ€™s brothers testified to seeing Cribb attempting to 
  break into the trailer, and seeing the resulting damage.Â  Since allegations 
  of Cribbâ€™s wrongdoing were previously presented to the jury, it was within the 
  trial judgeâ€™s discretion to exclude Pipkinâ€™s fatherâ€™s testimony as cumulative.Â  
  See Rule 403, SCRE.Â  Even if excluded in error, the exclusion of evidence 
  which would be merely cumulative to other evidence presented to the jury is 
  harmless.Â  See State v. Schumpert, 312 S.C. 502, 507, 435 S.E.2d 
  859, 862 (1993); State v. White, 353 S.C. 566, 575, 578 S.E.2d 728, 733 
  (Ct. App. 2003).

  II.              
Did the trial court err in the denial of Appellantâ€™s motion for a directed 
  verdict? 
   

Because evidence was presented at 
  trial showing that Cribb consented to his presence in her home, Pipkin claims 
  that the elements of attempted burglary were not proven by the State and, therefore, 
  his motion for a directed verdict should have been granted.Â  We disagree.
In a motion for directed verdict, the trial 
  court is concerned with the existence of evidence rather than its weight.Â  State 
  v. Spann, 279 S.C. 399, 402, 308 S.E.2d 518, 520 (1983).Â  This evidence 
  is â€œviewed in the light most favorable to the State to determine whether there 
  is any evidence, either direct or circumstantial which reasonably tends 
  to prove the guilt of the accused, or from which guilt may be fairly and logically 
  deduced.â€ State v. Creech, 314 S.C. 76, 83-83, 441 S.E.2d 635, 638 (Ct. 
  App. 1994) (emphasis added).Â  
In the case at bar, testimony was presented 
  by both sides on the issue of consent.Â  Pipkin testified to an agreement with 
  Cribb whereby he could â€œbreak-inâ€ to Cribbâ€™s apartment whenever he so desired.Â  
  Cribb testified that there was no such agreement and that she had taken out 
  a restraining order against Pipkin at the time of the attempted burglary.Â  Nowhere 
  in the record is evidence reflecting any specific consent to enter the apartment 
  on the evening in question.Â  
It is the duty of the trial judge, when ruling 
  on a motion for a directed verdict, to submit the case to the jury when there 
  is any substantial evidence, either direct or circumstantial, which reasonably 
  tends to prove the defendantâ€™s guilt.Â  State v. Brazell, 325 S.C. 65, 
  77, 480 S.E.2d 64, 71 (1997).Â  Since there was conflicting evidence presented 
  on the issue of consent, the trial judge acted properly in denying Pipkinâ€™s 
  motion and submitting the case to the jury.
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons, the decision of 
  the trial court is
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and ANDERSON, J., concur.

 
   [1]  Cribbâ€™s sister and Richardson forbade her to see 
    Pipkin. Accordingly, he would sneak into the apartment to avoid being seen 
    by them.

description: The primary issue in this appeal from the revocation of Appellant's probation is whether the disclosure rules of Rule 5, SCRCrimP, and Brady are applicable to probation revocation proceedings.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In the Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        The State of South Carolina,
        Respondent,
v.
Gary Thomas Hill, Appellant
      
    
  


Appeal from Anderson County
J.C. Nicholson, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3795
Heard January 14, 2004 â€“ Filed May 11, 
  2004

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED


  
    
      
J. Stephen Welch, of Greenwood, for Appellant.
Deputy Director for Legal Services Teresa A. Knox, Legal 
  Counsel Tommy Evans, Jr., and Legal Counsel J. Benjamin Aplin, all of South 
  Carolina Department of Probation, Parole and Pardon Services, of Columbia, for 
  Respondent.
      
    
  

CURETON, A.J.:  Gary Thomas Hill 
  appeals the circuit courtâ€™s decision revoking his probation and sentencing him 
  to seven years imprisonment.Â  We affirm in part, reverse in part, and remand.
FACTS
On November 4, 1991, Hill was convicted of second-degree 
  arson, second-degree burglary, malicious injury to personal property, driving 
  under the influence (fourth offense), and criminal domestic violence (third 
  offense).Â  The judge sentenced Hill to twenty years imprisonment, suspended 
  upon the service of ten years and five years probation.Â  Hill was granted parole 
  on July 28, 1996.Â  His parole ended on February 25, 1997, and his probation 
  began immediately thereafter.Â  When the events that are the subject of this 
  appeal took place, Hill had completed approximately four years and eight months 
  of his probation. 
On October 24, 2001, Hillâ€™s probation 
  officer, Marshall Evans, received a call from the Department of Social Services 
  (â€œDSSâ€).Â  DSS informed Evans that it had reason to believe Hill possessed firearms 
  and had been pointing them at his son.Â  To further investigate this information, 
  Evans called Hill and asked him to come to his office.Â  Hill went to see Evans 
  as requested on October 25, 2001. 
Evans confronted Hill with the information 
  received by DSS and asked whether he did in fact possess any weapons.Â  Hill 
  admitted that his son owned a .22 caliber rifle, which he had received for his 
  birthday.Â  Hill agreed to let Evans and other probation officers search his 
  house for weapons, but the agreed upon search never took place. 
While in Evansâ€™s office, Hill asked if 
  he could get a drink of water.Â  Evans agreed and accompanied Hill as he went 
  into the hallway.Â Â  After getting some water, Hill turned and headed down the 
  hall towards the exit.Â  Although Evans asked Hill to stop, he did not respond 
  and instead proceeded out of the building where he locked himself in his car.Â  
  Evans testified that at least three other probation officers were involved in 
  trying to â€œchaseâ€ Hill down. 
The officers surrounded Hillâ€™s car and 
  attempted to gain entry.Â  Despite the officersâ€™ commands to stop, Hill began 
  to drive out of the parking lot notwithstanding the proximity of the officers 
  to his car.Â  At this point, two of the officers opened fire on Hillâ€™s car.Â  
  Hillâ€™s car was hit several times in numerous places including the rear window, 
  the side window, the trunk, and the rear quarter panel.Â  Hill received three 
  gunshot wounds, one in the head and two in the back.Â  Although the officers 
  shot Hill three times, he never stopped his car.Â  He was arrested some time 
  later while seeking treatment at a hospital. 
Hill hired attorney James Brislane to 
  represent him at the probation revocation hearing.Â  On November 1, 2001, Brislane 
  filed motions under Rule 5, SCRCrimP, and Brady v. Maryland. 
  [1] Â  Hill asserts on appeal these motions were filed to determine exactly 
  what happened on the day of the incident.Â  Hill believed he was entitled to 
  the following:Â Â  (1) the names of witnesses that supported his version of the 
  incident; (2) written statements of the probation agents; (3) Anderson City 
  Police Department investigative materials; and (4) the South Carolina Law Enforcement 
  Division (â€œSLEDâ€) report. 
On November 11, 2001, Brislane moved for a continuance 
  of the probation revocation hearing.Â  At the hearing on the motion, the court 
  informed Brislane that because the probation and parole departmentâ€™s records 
  were confidential, [2]  neither a Rule 5 motion nor a Brady 
  motion were appropriate for obtaining the requested information.Â  The court 
  instructed Brislane to find the statute applicable to the parole departmentâ€™s 
  records and to serve the appropriate motion on counsel.Â  The court also informed 
  Brislane it would hear the motion once correctly made.Â  
The record does not disclose any motions made according 
  to the courtâ€™s instructions prior to the probation revocation hearing, which 
  was held on December 21, 2001.Â  Neither the SLED report outlining the investigation 
  of the incident nor the Anderson Police Departmentâ€™s report was furnished to 
  Hill or his counsel prior to the hearing. 
At the revocation hearing, the circuit court and 
  Brislane agreed the key issue was not whether Hill violated his probation, but 
  whether he violated his probation willfully. 
  [3] Â  All of the officers involved in the incident testified at the hearing.Â  
  The majority of the testimony presented consisted of the officersâ€™ assertions 
  that Hill intentionally tried to run them over during his escape.Â  On cross-examination 
  of each witness, Brislane tried to discredit the idea that Hill intentionally 
  attempted to harm the officers. Â However, at the conclusion of the hearing, 
  the court revoked Hillâ€™s probation and sentenced him to seven years imprisonment.
Following the revocation hearing, Hill hired Beattie 
  Ashmore to represent him.Â  Ashmore filed a motion to reconsider on December 
  28, 2001.Â  In the motion, Ashmore asked the court to reconsider the ruling based 
  on the fact that the SLED report investigating the incident was not complete 
  and the report contained mitigating information. 
Â After filing the motion to reconsider, Ashmore 
  made several additional motions in an attempt to obtain the SLED report.Â  These 
  motions included a motion to produce, another motion pursuant to Rule 5, SCRCrimP, 
  and another Brady motion.Â  Ashmore also served subpoenas on SLED and 
  the Anderson County Solicitorâ€™s Office.Â  Due to these efforts, Hill received 
  the SLED report prior to the hearing on the motion to reconsider. 
At the hearing, the circuit court asked 
  Ashmore whether he was proceeding under Rule 28 or Rule 29, SCRCrimP. [4] Â  After a brief colloquy, the court informed 
  counsel that he could not proceed under both so he would have to elect.Â  Ashmore 
  chose to proceed under Rule 29.Â  Relying on the information in the SLED report, 
  Ashmore presented evidence that countered the probation officersâ€™ assertions 
  that Hill intentionally tried to hit them with his vehicle. 
In an order dated July 3, 2002, the court denied 
  Hillâ€™s motion on the ground that he failed to meet the five elements required 
  to support the award of a new trial based on after-discovered evidence.Â  Specifically, 
  the court ruled that even considering the additional evidence presented, the 
  outcome would not change if a new hearing were permitted.Â  As such, the court 
  upheld its previously imposed sentence of seven years.Â Â  Hill appeals.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The determination of whether or not to revoke probation 
  is within the trial courtâ€™s discretion.Â  State v. Proctor, 345 S.C. 299, 
  301, 546 S.E.2d 673, 674 (Ct. App. 2001). â€œ[B]efore revoking probation, the 
  circuit judge must determine if there is sufficient evidence to establish the 
  probationer has violated his probation conditions.â€ State v. Lee, 350 
  S.C. 125, 131, 564 S.E.2d 372, 375 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  â€œThis courtâ€™s authority 
  to review such a decision is confined to correcting errors of law unless the 
  lack of a legal or evidentiary basis indicates the circuit judgeâ€™s decision 
  was arbitrary and capricious.â€Â  State v. Hamilton, 333 S.C. 642, 647, 
  511 S.E.2d 94, 96 (Ct. App. 1999); see State v. Brown, 284 S.C. 
  407, 410, 326 S.E.2d 410, 411 (1985) (holding judges are â€œallowed a wide, but 
  not unlimited, discretion in imposing conditions of suspension or probation 
  and they cannot impose conditions which are illegal and void as against public 
  policyâ€).Â Â Â Â Â Â  
DISCUSSION
I.Â  Brady 
  and Rule 5 Motions
Hill argues the circuit court erred by not requiring 
  the State to produce the information requested through the Rule 5 and Brady 
  motions prior to the probation revocation hearing.Â  
â€œThe rules encompassed in Brady, and its 
  progeny, and Rule 5 are separate and impose different duties.Â  Therefore, separate 
  analysis must be used to determine if either has been violated.â€Â  State v. 
  Kennerly, 331 S.C. 442, 452, 503 S.E.2d 214, 219 (Ct. App. 1998), affâ€™d, 
  337 S.C. 617, 524 S.E.2d 837 (1999).
â€œA Brady claim is based upon the requirement of due 
  process.Â  Such a claim is complete if the accused can demonstrate (1) the evidence 
  was favorable to the accused, (2) it was in the possession of or known to the 
  prosecution, (3) it was suppressed by the prosecution, and (4) it was material 
  to guilt or punishment.â€Â  Gibson v. State, 334 S.C. 515, 524, 514 S.E.2d 
  320, 324 (1999).Â  â€œThis rule applies to impeachment evidence as well as exculpatory 
  evidence.â€Â  Id.  
â€œThe requirements of Rule 5, as opposed to the constitutional 
  dictates of Brady, are judicially created discovery mechanisms for use 
  in criminal proceedings.â€Â  State v. Proctor, 348 S.C. 322, 330, 559 S.E.2d 
  318, 322 (Ct. App. 2001), revâ€™d on other grounds, Op. No. 25810 (S.C. 
  Sup. Ct. filed Apr. 19, 2004)(Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 16 at 34).Â  Although Hillâ€™s 
  counsel proceeded under several provisions of Rule 5, the primary subsection 
  was Rule 5(a)(1)(C).Â  This subsection provides:

(C) Documents and Tangible Objects.Â  Upon request of the 
  defendant the prosecution shall permit the defendant to inspect and copy books, 
  papers, documents, photographs, tangible objects, buildings or places, or copies 
  or portions thereof, which are within the possession, custody or control of 
  the prosecution, and which are material to the preparation of his defense or 
  are intended for use by the prosecution as evidence in chief at the trial, or 
  were obtained from or belong to the defendant.

Rule 5(a)(1)(C), SCRCrimP.
â€œThe definition of â€˜materialâ€™ for purposes of Rule 5 is the 
  same as the definition used in the Brady context.â€Â  Kennerly, 
  331 S.C. at 453, 503 S.E.2d at 220.Â  â€œImpeachment or exculpatory evidence is 
  material only if there is a reasonable probability that, had the evidence been 
  disclosed to the defense, the result of the proceeding would have been different.â€Â  
  State v. Von Dohlen, 322 S.C. 234, 241, 471 S.E.2d 689, 693 (1996).
The application of the discovery rules in the context 
  of a probation revocation hearing is a novel issue in this state.Â  Although 
  our appellate courts have found the rules to be applicable in â€œcriminal proceedings,â€ 
  the specific types of criminal proceedings have not been defined.Â  See 
  Kennerly, 331 S.C. at 453, 503 S.E.2d at 220Â  (â€œThe requirements of Rule 
  5, as opposed to the constitutional dictates of Brady, are judicially 
  created discovery mechanisms for use in criminal proceedings.â€); see also 
  Rule 5, SCRCrimP (titled â€œDisclosure in Criminal Casesâ€).Â  The text of Rule 
  5 and the theoretical underpinnings of Brady appear to suggest that these 
  disclosure rules are only applicable in criminal trials.Â  In this state, however, 
  these rules have not been so limited.
Aside from trial proceedings, our research reveals these 
  rules have been extended to apply to guilty plea and sentencing proceedings.Â  
  See Gibson, 334 S.C. at 525, 514 S.E.2d at 325 (â€œThe standard 
  for deciding the materiality of a Brady violation in the context of a 
  guilty plea is a novel issue in South Carolina.Â  We adopt the standard applied 
  by other courts, which essentially is the same standard that is applied in the 
  context of a trial:Â  A Brady violation is material when there is a reasonable 
  probability that, but for the governmentâ€™s failure to disclose Brady 
  evidence, the defendant would have refused to plead guilty and gone to trial.â€); 
  State v. Gulledge, 321 S.C. 399, 402, 468 S.E.2d 665, 667 (Ct. App. 1996) 
  (discussing and implicitly recognizing the application of Rule 5 and Brady 
  in the context of sentencing proceedings), affâ€™d as modified, 326 S.C. 
  220, 487 S.E.2d 590 (1997).Â Â  The application of these two rules is not, however, 
  without limitation.Â  See State v. McCoy, 285 S.C. 115, 116, 328 
  S.E.2d 620, 621 (1985) (declining to apply Brady in the context of a 
  family court transfer hearing given the hearing was not a trial and was not 
  a preliminary determination of guilt).
In order to determine whether these disclosure 
  rules apply to a probationer, we find it instructive to consider two United 
  States Supreme Court decisions analyzing the due process requirements for parole 
  and probation revocation.Â  See Gagnon v. Scarpelli, 411 U.S. 778 
  (1973); Morrissey v. Brewer, 408 U.S. 471 (1972).Â  
In Morrissey, the United States Supreme Court considered 
  whether the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment required the State 
  to afford an individual some opportunity to be heard prior to the revocation 
  of his parole. Â Id. at 472.Â  In answering this question, the Court first 
  considered the â€œfunction of parole in the correctional process.â€Â  Id. 
  at 477.Â  Because â€œthe revocation of parole is not part of a criminal prosecution,â€ 
  the Court concluded, â€œthe full panoply of rights due a defendant in such a proceeding 
  does not apply to parole revocations.â€Â  Id. at 480.Â  The Court did, however, 
  find that a parolee is entitled to due process to a limited extent.Â  
Specifically, the Court held that after arrest a parolee 
  is entitled to a preliminary hearing â€œto determine whether there is probable 
  cause or reasonable ground to believe that the arrested parolee has committed 
  acts that would constitute a violation of parole conditions.â€Â  Morrissey, 
  408 U.S. at 485.Â  Additionally, the Court found the parolee was also entitled 
  to a revocation hearing during which he would have â€œan opportunity to be heard 
  and to show, if he can, that he did not violate the conditions, or, if he did, 
  that circumstances in mitigation suggest that the violation does not warrant 
  revocation.â€Â  Id. at 488.Â  In terms of the specific procedural requirements 
  for due process, the Court listed several, including:Â  disclosure to the parolee 
  of evidence against him; the right to confront and cross-examine adverse witnesses; 
  a written statement by the fact finders as to the evidence relied on and the 
  reasons for revoking parole.Â  Id. at 489. Â 
The next year, the United States Supreme Court 
  extended the analysis in Morrissey to hold that a probationer is also 
  guaranteed due process.Â  Gagnon v. Scarpelli, 411 U.S. 778 (1973).Â  The 
  Court concluded, â€œ[p]robation revocation, like parole revocation, is not a stage 
  of a criminal prosecution, but does result in a loss of liberty.â€ Id. 
  at 782.Â  The Court explained, â€œa probationer can no longer be denied due processâ€ 
  on the ground that â€œprobation is an â€˜act of grace.â€™â€ Gagnon, 411 U.S. 
  at 782 n.4.Â Â Â  
In light of this precedent, we must determine whether 
  a probationer facing revocation is entitled to discovery based on these due 
  process rights.Â  State courts are divided on this issue. 
  [5] Â  See Bobbi J. Anello, Annotation, Availability of Discovery 
  At Probation Revocation Hearings, 52 A.L.R. 5th 559 (1997 & Supp. 2003) 
  (analyzing cases in which the courts have considered the availability of discovery 
  to probationers at their revocation hearings).Â  As discussed in the above-referenced 
  article, there are primarily two grounds for which discovery is permitted in 
  probation revocation cases.Â  
Some jurisdictions have adopted the view that discovery in 
  revocation proceedings is permissible based on a constitutional due process 
  right.Â  The courts in these cases have followed the reasoning outlined in Morrissey 
  and Gagnon.Â  See, e.g., Kanuck v. Meehan, 798 P.2d 420 
  (Ariz. Ct. App. 1990); People v. Boykin, 631 P.2d 1149 (Colo. Ct. App. 
  1981); Hines v. State, 358 So. 2d 183 (Fla. 1978); Piper v. State, 
  770 N.E.2d 880 (Ind. Ct. App. 2002); Reiter v. Camp, 518 S.W.2d 82 (Mo. 
  Ct. App. 1974); People v. Adams, 367 N.Y.S.2d 67 (N.Y. App. Div. 1975).Â  
  The jurisdictions that have rejected this concept do so on the theory that if 
  a criminal defendant does not have a constitutional right to discovery, then 
  a probationer should not be entitled to greater rights than a defendant at trial.Â  
  See, e.g., Irby v. State, 455 So. 2d 271 (Ala. Crim. App. 1984); 
  People v. King, 152 Cal. Rptr. 566 (Cal. Dist. Ct. App. 1979); State 
  v. Hass, 758 P.2d 713 (Idaho Ct. App. 1988); People v. DeWitt, 397 
  N.E.2d 1385 (Ill. 1979); Commonwealth v. Quinlan, 380 A.2d 854 (Pa. Super. 
  Ct. 1977), affâ€™d, 412 A.2d 494 (Pa. 1980).Â  
Taking a different approach, some jurisdictions have held 
  that state criminal discovery rules, comparable to our Rule 5, are applicable 
  in probation revocation hearings.Â  See, e.g., State v. Quelnan, 
  767 P.2d 243 (Haw. 1989); State v. Barton, 803 P.2d 1020 (Idaho Ct. App. 
  1991).Â  In contrast, a number of jurisdictions have rejected this view on the 
  ground that a probation revocation hearing is not a â€œcriminal trialâ€ and, thus, 
  the criminal rules of discovery are inapplicable.Â  See, e.g., Poole 
  v. State, 306 S.E.2d 394 (Ga. Ct. App. 1983); People v. DeWitt, 397 
  N.E.2d 1385 (Ill. 1979); People v. Mitchell, 607 N.Y.S.2d 417 (N.Y. App. 
  Div. 1994); State v. Gedutis, 653 A.2d 761 (Vt. 1994).Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
Given our appellate courts have extended the application 
  of Brady and Rule 5 beyond criminal trial proceedings, we are persuaded 
  by those jurisdictions that have applied Brady and state criminal discovery 
  rules in probation revocation proceedings. As previously discussed, these disclosure 
  rules have been applied in sentencing proceedings and guilty plea proceedings.Â  
  Thus, the fact that a probation revocation hearing is not the equivalent of 
  a â€œcriminal trialâ€ is not dispositive.Â  See State v. Franks, 276 
  S.C. 636, 638, 281 S.E.2d 227, 228 (1981) (A â€œprobation revocation proceeding 
  is not a criminal trial . . . but a more informal proceeding with respect to 
  notice and proof of the alleged violations.â€).Â  Similar to a sentencing or guilty 
  plea proceeding, a probation revocation hearing involves a determination of 
  â€œguilt,â€ i.e., whether a probation violation has occurred, as well as 
  an imposition of a sentence.Â  As such, we discern no reason to restrict the 
  application of the due process requirements of Brady in this setting.Â  
  See Huckaby v. State, 305 S.C. 331, 335 n.1, 408 S.E.2d 242, 244 
  n.1 (1991) (recognizing constitutional rights are available to probationer).Â  
  Moreover, even though the text of Rule 5 refers to trials, the heading of the 
  rule includes â€œcriminal casesâ€ and provides for disclosure of information that 
  is â€œmaterial to the preparationâ€ of the defense.Â  Furthermore, there is no apparent 
  statutory restriction placed on disclosure.Â  In fact, the statute that the circuit 
  court relied on in this case to restrict discovery permits the court to order 
  disclosure of material obtained by a probation agent.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 24-21-290 
  (Supp. 2003).
Our decision should not, however, be translated 
  into unlimited discovery for a probationer.Â  See State v. Mixon, 
  275 S.C. 575, 582-83, 274 S.E.2d 406, 409 (1981) (â€œBrady does not speak 
  in terms of creating rights to discover, but rather determined that suppression 
  by the prosecution of evidence favorable to an accused upon request violates 
  due process where the evidence is material either to guilt or punishment.â€).Â  
  Instead, we agree with those jurisdictions that permit â€œreasonableâ€ discovery.Â  
  See Bobbi J. Anello, Annotation, Availability of Discovery At Probation 
  Revocation Hearings, 52 A.L.R. 5th 559, 587 (1997 & Supp. 2003); see, 
  e.g., Kanuck v. Meehan, 798 P.2d 420 (Ariz. Ct. App. 1990); Cuciak 
  v. State, 410 So. 2d 916 (Fla. 1982); State v. DeBorde, 915 P.2d 
  906 (N.M. Ct. App. 1996).Â  Although the parameters of â€œreasonableâ€ discovery 
  are difficult to outline, at least one jurisdiction has explained â€œ[t]he trial 
  court has the inherent power to decide what is reasonable discovery in a probation 
  revocation proceeding. . . . At the very least a probationer is entitled to 
  the name and identification of his accusers and other basic information that 
  is reasonably necessary to the preparation of his defense.â€Â  Cuciak, 
  410 So. 2d at 918.
Applying the foregoing analysis to the instant case, we find 
  the trial court erred as matter of law in ruling that Brady and Rule 
  5 did not apply to Hillâ€™s probation revocation proceeding.Â  Moreover, we reject 
  the Departmentâ€™s position that it was unable to comply with these rules because 
  it is a separate entity from SLED and the Anderson County Solicitorâ€™s Office, 
  the departments that had direct access to the requested documents.Â  Even if 
  the information was not in the possession of the Department, Brady and 
  Rule 5 still required disclosure to Hill.Â  See Kennerly, 331 S.C. 
  at 452, 503 S.E.2d at 220 (The Brady disclosure rule â€œextends to evidence 
  that is not in the actual possession of the prosecution but known by others 
  acting on the governmentâ€™s behalf.â€); Id. at 453, 503 S.E.2d at 220 (Rule 
  5 â€œclearly applies to evidence within the actual possession of the prosecution 
  and seems to also apply to evidence within the possession of other government 
  agencies.â€); see also S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 24-21-280(B) (Supp. 2003) (â€œA 
  probation agent has the power and authority to enforce the criminal laws of 
  the State.Â  In the performance of his duties of probation, parole, community 
  supervision, and investigation, he is regarded as the official representative 
  of the court, the department, and the board.â€); cf. Morrissey, 
  408 U.S. at 480 (â€œSupervision [in a parole case] is not directly by the court 
  but by an administrative agency, which is sometimes an arm of the court and 
  sometimes of the executive.â€).Â  
Finally, the failure to disclose this evidence to Hill prior 
  to the revocation hearing was not harmless.Â  See Proctor, 348 
  S.C. at 334-35, 559 S.E.2d at 324-25 (applying harmless error analysis to Stateâ€™s 
  failure to comply with Rule 5 and Brady).Â  â€œFor Brady purposes, 
  in determining the materiality of nondisclosed evidence, an appellate court 
  must consider the evidence in the context of the entire record.Â  However, the 
  court should not consider the sufficiency of the evidence.Â  The courtâ€™s function 
  is to determine whether the appellantâ€™s right to a fair trial has been impaired.â€Â  
  State v. Taylor, 333 S.C. 159, 177, 508 S.E.2d 870, 879 (1998) (citations 
  omitted).Â  
Here, the requested documents were produced just prior to 
  the hearing on Hillâ€™s motion for reconsideration.Â  At that point in the procedure, 
  the circuit court had ruled on the merits of the revocation without the benefit 
  of all of the evidence.Â  The fact that Hill was able to use the information 
  at the reconsideration hearing did not remove the prejudice.Â  Having already 
  found Hill violated his probation and having imposed a sentence, we believe 
  it would have been difficult for the court to be completely objective during 
  the subsequent proceeding.Â  Thus, we find the information was material and the 
  failure to disclose it deprived Hill of a fair hearing.Â  See People 
  v. Mitchell, 607 N.Y.S.2d 417, 418 (N.Y. App. Div. 1994) (holding probationer 
  was entitled access to prior statements of hearing witnesses regarding the subject 
  of their testimony in order to afford him â€œa meaningful opportunity to conduct 
  cross-examinationâ€ at his probation revocation hearing); see also State 
  v. Cheeseboro, 346 S.C. 526, 553, 552 S.E.2d 300, 314 (2001), cert. denied, 
  535 U.S. 933 (2002) (â€œEvidence is material only if there is a reasonable probability 
  that, had the evidence been disclosed, the result of the proceeding would have 
  been different.Â  A reasonable probability is a probability sufficient to undermine 
  confidence in the outcome.â€); State v. Goodson, 276 S.C. 243, 247, 277 
  S.E.2d 602, 604-05 (1981) (stating, in discussing a Brady violation, 
  â€œ[w]hile we are not persuaded that this evidence necessarily exculpates appellant, 
  we find that sufficient question has been cast upon conclusions reached in the 
  trial below to justify a reconsideration of the matter by a jury appraised [sic] 
  of these new factorsâ€).Â Â 
Because the definition of â€œmaterialâ€ is the same for analysis 
  under Brady and Rule 5, we also find the failure to disclose the requested 
  documents constituted a Rule 5 violation.Â  â€œOnce a Rule 5 violation is shown, 
  reversal is required only where the defendant suffered prejudice from the violation.â€Â  
  Proctor, 348 S.C. at 330-31, 559 S.E.2d at 322.Â  Again, we find Hill 
  was prejudiced by the late disclosure given he was unable to present this evidence 
  and thoroughly cross-examine the witnesses.Â  Accordingly, we remand for a de 
  novo revocation hearing.
II.Â  42 U.S.C. 
  Â§ 1983
Hill argues the circuit court erred in offering 
  to reduce his sentence if he would release any claims he may have pursuant to 
  42 U.S.C. Â§ 1983.Â  Hill asserts this suggestion came up during a discussion 
  between the parties.
We, however, find the issue is not preserved for our review 
  because the conversation is not included in the record on appeal.Â  See 
  York v. Conway Ford, Inc., 325 S.C. 170, 173, 480 S.E.2d 726, 728 (1997) 
  (stating objection made in off-the-record conference not placed on record does 
  not preserve the issue for review); see also Hundley v. Rite Aid of 
  South Carolina Inc., 339 S.C. 285, 306, 529 S.E.2d 45, 57 (Ct. App. 2000) 
  (finding motions must be made on the record to be preserved for review by an 
  appellate court).Â  
III.Â  Rules 28 
  and 29, SCRCrimP
Hill contends the circuit court erred by not allowing 
  defense counsel to proceed simultaneously under both Rules 28 and 29, SCRCrimP.  

At the beginning of the hearing on Hillâ€™s motion 
  to reconsider, the court informed counsel he would have to choose between Rule 
  28 and Rule 29, as he could not proceed under both simultaneously.Â  Defense 
  counsel agreed and decided to proceed under Rule 29 for a new trial based on 
  after-discovered evidence.Â  Because counsel conceded this issue during the proceedings 
  below, it is not preserved for our review.Â  State v. Benton, 338 S.C. 
  151, 157, 526 S.E.2d 228, 231 (2000), cert. denied, 530 U.S. 1209 (2000) 
  (holding issue not preserved for appellate consideration where appellant conceded 
  the issue at trial); TNS Mills, Inc. v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Revenue, 
  331 S.C. 611, 617, 503 S.E.2d 471, 474 (1998) (issue conceded to the trial court 
  cannot be raised on appeal).Â  
IV.Â  Burden of 
  Proof under Rule 29, SCRCrimP
Hill further argues the circuit court erred in 
  finding he did not meet the burden of proof under Rule 29(b), SCRCrimP for the 
  grant of a new trial.Â Â Â  
The denial of a new trial will not be reversed 
  absent an abuse of discretion.Â  State v. South, 310 S.C. 504, 507, 427 
  S.E.2d 666, 668 (1993).Â  To prevail on a motion for a new trial based on after-discovered 
  evidence, it is necessary to show that the evidence:Â  â€œ(1) would probably change 
  the result if a new trial is had;Â  (2) has been discovered since the trial;Â  
  (3) could not have been discovered before trial;Â  (4) is material to the issue 
  of guilt or innocence; and (5) is not merely cumulative or impeaching.â€Â  Id. 
  at 507, 427 S.E.2d at 668-69.
Because we reverse and remand on Hillâ€™s issue involving 
  Rule 5 and Brady, we need not address this issue.Â  See Mixon, 
  275 S.C. at 582, 274 S.E.2d at 409 (comparing relief sought in Brady 
  motion to motion for new trial on the ground of after-discovered evidence); 
  see also State v. Spann, 334 S.C. 618, 619, 513 S.E.2d 98, 99 
  (1999) (wherein the Supreme Court, because it reversed and granted a new trial 
  on one issue, did not address other issues raised by appellant).
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing analysis, we find 
  the disclosure rules of Brady and Rule 5 are applicable in probation 
  revocation cases.Â  As such, we reverse the circuit courtâ€™s decision denying 
  Hill access to this information prior to the revocation hearing and remand for 
  a de novo revocation hearing.Â  Finally, we affirm Hillâ€™s issues 
  regarding 42 U.S.C. Â§ 1983 and Rules 28 and 29 of the South Carolina Rules of 
  Criminal Procedure.
AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED.
GOOLSBY and ANDERSON, JJ., concur.

 
   [1]  Brady v. Maryland, 373 U.S. 83 (1963).

 
   
    [2]  Although the judge did not reference the specific statute, he was 
    apparently relying on section 24-21-290, which provides:
  
  All information and data 
    obtained in the discharge of his official duty by a probation agent is privileged 
    information, is not receivable as evidence in a court, and may not be disclosed 
    directly or indirectly to anyone other than the judge or others entitled under 
    this chapter to receive reports unless ordered by the court or the director.
  
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 24-21-290 
    (Supp. 2003).

 
   
    [3] Â Â  Because the Department did not attempt to revoke Hillâ€™s probation 
    on a failure to pay fees, a finding of willfulness was not necessary for the 
    court to determine whether to revoke Hillâ€™s probation.Â  See State 
    v. Hamilton, 333 S.C. 642, 649, 511 S.E.2d 94, 97 (Ct. App. 1999) (â€œIt 
    is only when probation is revoked solely for failure to pay fines or 
    restitution that a finding of willfulness is mandatory.â€).Â  

 
   
    [4] Â Â  Rule 28 provides that a defendant â€œshall not be permitted to submit 
    any affidavit to the court which goes to deny matters of fact, but he may 
    submit affidavits as to matters in extenuation and mitigation.â€Â  Rule 28, 
    SCRCrimP.Â  Rule 29(b) provides for a new trial based on after-discovered evidence.Â  
    Rule 29(b), SCRCrimP.Â  

 
   
    [5] Â  Although there also appears to be a division among federal courts 
    as to whether Brady is applicable to probation revocation hearings, 
    we focus our analysis on state court decisions given Rule 32.1(b)(2) of the 
    Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure specifically outlines the procedure governing 
    revocation hearings.Â  See United States v. Dixon, 187 F. Supp. 
    2d 601, 602-03 (S.D.W.Va. 2002) (discussing federal courts which have questioned 
    whether Brady is applicable in the revocation context); Fed. R. Crim. 
    P. 32.1(b)(2) (â€œRevocation Hearing.Â  Unless waived by the person, the court 
    must hold the revocation hearing within a reasonable time in the district 
    having jurisdiction.Â  The person is entitled to:Â  (A) written notice of the 
    alleged violation; (B) disclosure of the evidence against the person; (C) 
    an opportunity to appear, present evidence, and question any adverse witness 
    unless the court determines that the interest of justice does not require 
    the witness to appear; and (D) notice of the personâ€™s right to retain counsel 
    or to request that counsel be appointed if the person cannot obtain counsel.â€).

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
William Settlemeyer,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Katherine McCluney,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From York County
John Buford Grier, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3796
Submitted December 8, 2003 â€“ Filed May 
  11, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Daniel J. Ballou, of Rock Hill; John Pressly Gettys, Jr., 
  of Rock Hill; for Appellant.
George W. Speedy, of Camden; for Respondent.
      
    
  


 HOWARD, J.:Â Â  William Settlemeyer 
  sued his daughter, Katherine McCluney, claiming ownership of four tracts of 
  land in York County (â€œthe propertiesâ€) by an express, constructive, or resulting 
  trust.Â  The circuit court concluded no trust existed and McCluney was the legal 
  and equitable owner of the properties.Â  Settlemeyer appeals, arguing the circuit 
  court erred by denying relief on his claim for: 1) an express trust; 2) a constructive 
  trust; and 3) a resulting trust.Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Between March 1982 and January 1991, 
  Settlemeyer purchased the properties. Â In each instance, he had the title 
  issued in McCluneyâ€™s name.Â  
Subsequently, Settlemeyer filed a lawsuit, alleging 
  the properties were held in an express, constructive or resulting trust, with 
  McCluney as the trustee and Settlemeyer as the beneficiary.Â  
At trial, Settlemeyer testified he voluntarily placed 
  title of the properties in McCluneyâ€™s name, admitting McCluney had not induced 
  him to have the properties conveyed to her. Â Settlemeyer further testified 
  he believed he and McCluney had an oral agreement in which he would purchase 
  property and title it in McCluneyâ€™s name, with the understanding that McCluney 
  would later convey it to him.Â  However, when specifically asked if there was 
  â€œever an agreement between [Settlemeyer] and [McCluney] that she would reconvey 
  the property back to [Settlemeyer],â€ Settlemeyer stated, â€œIt wasnâ€™t brought 
  up.Â  I trusted her to think she would deed it back to me.â€Â  Additionally, Settlemeyer 
  admitted he denied ownership of the properties during one of his divorce proceedings 
  and during a Department of Health and Environmental Control investigation of 
  one of the properties.Â  
McCluney denied she and her father had an agreement 
  in which she was to convey the properties to him but confirmed she did not pay 
  the purchase price or property taxes for the properties.Â  McCluney stated she 
  believed the properties were gifts from Settlemeyer.Â  
The circuit court found the Statute of Frauds barred 
  finding an express trust existed.Â  Additionally, the circuit court found the 
  claim of a constructive trust failed because Settlemeyer did not prove McCluney 
  acted fraudulently in the transaction.Â  Furthermore, the circuit court found 
  the claim for a resulting trust failed because Settlemeyer failed to rebut the 
  presumption that the properties were given to McCluney as gifts.Â  
Subsequently, in Settlemeyerâ€™s motion for reconsideration, 
  Settlemeyer argued the circuit court erred by failing to address his part-performance 
  argument concerning the express trust.Â  Thereafter, the circuit court denied 
  Settlemeyerâ€™s motion for reconsideration without addressing part performance.Â  
  Settlemeyer appeals.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œIn an action in equity, tried by the judge alone, 
  . . . this Court has jurisdiction to find facts in accordance with its views 
  of the preponderance of the evidence.â€Â  Stackhouse v. Cook, 271 S.C. 
  518, 521, 248 S.E.2d 482, 484 (1978).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Express Trust
Settlemeyer argues the circuit court 
  erred by denying relief on his claim of an express trust.Â  We disagree.
The statute of frauds requires that a declaration 
  of an express trust of land must be in writing. S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-7-101 (1987). 
  Â However, â€œsufficient part performance of a parol contract for the conveyance 
  of land will remove the contract from the statute of frauds.â€Â  Stackhouse, 
  271 S.C. at 521, 248 S.E.2d at 483. Â 
To compel specific performance of an oral agreement 
  where part performance is alleged to remove the contract from the statute of 
  frauds, a court of equity must find: 1) clear evidence of an oral agreement; 
  2) the agreement had been partially executed; and 3) the party who requested 
  performance had completed or was willing to complete his part of the oral agreement.Â  
  Gibson v. Hrysikos, 293 S.C. 8, 13-14, 358 S.E.2d 173, 176 (Ct. App. 
  1987).Â Â  
Because both Settlemeyer and McCluney testified no 
  written document existed governing conveyance of the properties between the 
  parties, we only address the issue of part performance.Â  
At trial, McCluney denied an oral agreement existed 
  between the parties in which she was to convey the properties to Settlemeyer. 
  Â Furthermore, although Settlemeyer testified he thought such an agreement 
  existed between the parties, he stated the parties did not orally express this 
  agreement.Â  Rather, he testified he trusted McCluney to act as he desired. 
Based on our review of the evidence contained in 
  the record, we hold Settlemeyer did not present clear evidence of an oral agreement 
  between the parties. See Gibson, 293 S.C. at 13, 358 S.E.2d at 
  176 (holding a court must find, among other things, clear evidence of the existence 
  of an oral agreement for part performance to remove the contract from the statute 
  of frauds).Â  
Without the existence of an oral agreement, Settlemeyer 
  cannot establish part performance of the alleged agreement.Â  See Stackhouse, 
  271 S.C. at 521, 248 S.E.2d at 483 (holding sufficient part performance of an 
  oral trust agreement is required to remove it from the statute of frauds). Â Thus, 
  the circuit court did not err by denying Settlemeyer relief on his claim of 
  an express trust. 
The remaining issues are affirmed pursuant to Rule 
  220, SCACR and the following authorities: As to Issue II: Smith v. 
  South Carolina Ret. Sys., 336 S.C. 505, 529, 520 S.E.2d 339, 352 (Ct. App. 
  1999) (â€œIn general, a constructive trust may be imposed when a party obtains 
  a benefit â€˜which does not equitably belong to him and which he cannot in good 
  conscience retain or withhold from another who is beneficially entitled to it 
  as where money has been paid by accident, mistake of fact, or fraud, or has 
  been acquired through a breach of trust or the violation of a fiduciary duty.â€™â€ 
  (quoting SSI Med. Servs. v. Cox, 301 S.C. 493, 500, 392 S.E.2d 789, 793-94 
  (1990))); see All v. Prillaman, 200 S.C. 279, 308, 20 S.E.2d 741, 
  753 (1942) (â€œâ€˜The law will not permit a party to deliberately put his property 
  out of his control for a fraudulent purpose, and then, through intervention 
  of a court of equity, regain the same after his fraudulent purpose has been 
  accomplished.â€™â€ (quoting Jolly v. Graham, 78 N.E. 919, 920 (Ill. 1906))). 

As to Issue III:Â  Bowen v. 
  Bowen, 352 S.C. 494, 499, 575 S.E.2d 553, 556 (2003) (holding when real 
  estate is conveyed to a child and consideration is paid by the parent, the presumption 
  is that the purchase was a gift to the child, and thus, no resulting trust arises); 
  Hayne Fed. Credit Union v. Bailey, 327 S.C. 242, 249, 489 S.E.2d 472, 
  476 (1997) (holding when real estate is conveyed to a child and consideration 
  is paid by the parent, the parent has the burden of proving a gift was not intended); 
  see also id. at 250, 489 S.E.2d 476 (holding when a parent purchases 
  real property and titles it in the name of his child for the purpose of defrauding 
  a third party, the parent cannot enforce a resulting trust). 
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons, the decisions 
  of the circuit court are
AFFIRMED.
 HEARN, C.J., and KITTREDGE, J., concur.

title: Angus v. Burroughs & Chapin Co.
description: Linda Angus appeals from the dismissal of her civil conspiracy claim against Horry County Council, her former employer, and other defendants. We affirm as to the members of the Council and reverse  as to the remaining defendants.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH 
  CAROLINA
  In The Court of Appeals
 
   
     
       
        Linda Angus, Appellant,
      
    
  

v.
 
   
     
       
        Burroughs & Chapin Co., 
          Myrtle Beach Herald, Doug Wendel, Pat Dowling, Deborah Johnson, Chandler 
          C. Prosser, Marvin Heyd, Chandler Brigham, and Terry Cooper, 
          Respondents. 
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
  Â J. Michael Baxley, Circuit 
  Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  3744
  Heard September 9, 2003 â€“ Filed 
  February 9, 2004

AFFIRMED IN PART, 
  REVERSED IN PART

 
   
     
      
        L. Sidney Connor, IV, of 
          Surfside Beach, for Appellant.
        Jerry Jay Bender and Robert 
          L Widener, both of Columbia;Â  L. Morgan Martin, Linda Weeks Gangi and 
          Michael W. Battle, all of Conway;Â  Scott B. Umstead, Thomas C. Brittain 
          and William Edward Lawson, all of Myrtle Beach;Â  and William C. Barnes, 
          of Florence, for Respondents.
      
    
  

BEATTY, J.:Â  Linda Angus appeals 
  the circuit courtâ€™s order granting summary judgment on her cause of action for 
  civil conspiracy. We affirm in part and reverse in part.
FACTS/PROCEDURAL 
  HISTORY
Linda Angus began employment with 
  Horry County as its county administrator and chief operating officer on June 
  3, 1996. Her employment contract stated that she was â€œemployed at the willâ€ 
  of the Horry County Council. The contract stipulated that Angus was to be given 
  365 days notice or 365 days severance pay in the event of a termination. On 
  June 22, 1999, Horry County terminated her employment. Pursuant to the terms 
  of the agreement, Angus was paid for 365 days and was extended the appropriate 
  benefits. 
On January 14, 2000, Angus filed 
  a complaint against Burroughs & Chapin Co., Doug Wendel, Pat Dowling, Myrtle 
  Beach Herald, Deborah Johnson, Chandler Prosser, Marvin Heyd, Chandler Brigham, 
  and Terry Cooper (â€œthe respondentsâ€). Wendel and Dowling were employees of Burroughs 
  & Chapin; Johnson was an employee of the Myrtle Beach Herald; Prosser, Heyd, 
  Brigham, and Cooper were all Horry County Council members. Angus alleged numerous 
  causes of action, including tortious interference with contractual relations, 
  defamation, civil conspiracy, and unfair trade practices, all arising from the 
  termination of her employment by Horry County. Specifically, Angus alleged that 
  the respondents â€œconspired with numerous persons â€¦ to see that Angus was terminated 
  from her employment as Horry County Administrator.â€Â  And sheÂ  alleged that the 
  respondents did this to gain financial advantage and to avoid regulatory requirements.Â  
  
After orders dismissing the causes 
  of action for intentional interference with contractual relations, defamation, 
  and unfair trade practices, the only remaining cause of action was for civil 
  conspiracy.Â  In an order dated November 28, 2001, the circuit court granted 
  summary judgment to all Respondents as to the civil conspiracy claims.Â  Angus 
  appeals.
STANDARD OF REVIEW 
   
â€œSummary judgment is proper where 
  there is no genuine issue of material fact and the movant is entitled to judgment 
  as a matter of law.â€Â  Dawkins v. Fields, 345 S.C. 23, 27, 545 S.E.2d 
  515, 517 (Ct. App. 2001) (citing Rule 56(c), SCRCP; Quality Towing, Inc. 
  v. City of Myrtle Beach, 340 S.C. 29, 33, 530 S.E.2d 369, 371 (2000)).Â  
  â€œSummary judgment should not be granted even when there is no dispute as to 
  the evidentiary facts if there is dispute as to the conclusions to be drawn 
  from those facts.â€Â  Id. at 28, 545 S.E.2d at 517 (citing Piedmont 
  Engineers, Architects & Planners, Inc. v. First Hartford Realty Corp., 
  278 S.C. 195, 196, 293 S.E.2d 706, 707 (1982)).Â  â€œIn determining whether any 
  triable issues of fact exist, the evidence and all inferences which can be reasonably 
  drawn from the evidence must be viewed in the light most favorable to the nonmoving 
  party.â€Â  Id. at 28, 545 S.E.2d at 518 (citing Bishop v. South Carolina 
  Depâ€™t of Mental Health, 331 S.C. 79, 85, 502 S.E.2d 78, 81 (1998)).Â  â€œSummary 
  judgment should be invoked cautiously to avoid improperly denying a party a 
  trial on the disputed factual issues.â€Â  Id. (citing Baughman v. Am. 
  Tel. & Tel. Co., 306 S.C. 101, 112, 410 S.E.2d 537, 543 (1991)).
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Angus argues the trial court erred 
  in granting the respondentsâ€™ motion for summary judgment as to the claim for 
  civil conspiracy. We agree in part.
In South Carolina, â€œ[a] civil conspiracy 
  exists when there is (1) a combination of two or more persons, (2) for the purpose 
  of injuring the plaintiff, (3) which causes the plaintiff special damage.â€ Robertson 
  v. First Union Nat. Bank, 350 S.C. 339, 348, 565 S.E.2d 309, 314 (Ct. App. 
  2002) (citing Island Car Wash, Inc. v. Norris, 292 S.C. 595, 600, 358 
  S.E.2d 150, 152 (Ct. App. 1987)). â€œA civil conspiracy may, of course, be furthered 
  by an unlawful act. â€¦ [but] an unlawful act is not a necessary element of the 
  tort. An action for conspiracy may lie even though no unlawful means are used 
  and no independently unlawful acts are committed.â€ Lee v. Chesterfield General 
  Hosp., 289 S.C. 6, 11, 344 S.E.2d 379, 382 (Ct. App. 1986). â€œA conspiracy 
  is actionable only if overt acts pursuant to the common design proximately cause 
  damage to the party bringing the action.â€Â  Future Group, II v. Nationsbank, 
  324 S.C. 89, 100, 478 S.E.2d 45, 51 (1996) (citing Todd v. S.C. Farm Bureau 
  Mut. Ins. Co., 276 S.C. 284, 292, 278 S.E.2d 607, 611 (1981)).
ANALYSIS
In granting summary judgment, the 
  trial court relied exclusively on Ross v. Life Ins. Co. of Va., 273 S.C. 
  764, 259 S.E.2d 814 (1979). There, plaintiff brought a wrongful termination 
  action against his former employer, alleging that the former employer had conspired 
  with others to terminate his employment. Our supreme court sustained the summary 
  judgment for the former employer, reasoning that an at-will employee â€œmay be 
  terminated at any time for any reason or no reason at all.â€ Id. at 765, 
  259 S.E.2d at 815. The supreme court based its decision largely on the employerâ€™s 
  ability to fire plaintiff at any time, for no reason or for a bad reason. 
Ross clearly holds that at-will 
  employees can be fired for any reason. Moody v. McLellan, 452, 295 S.C. 
  157, 162, 367 S.E.2d 449 (1988). It also holds that an at-will employee cannot 
  maintain an action against a former employer for civil conspiracy that resulted 
  in the employeeâ€™s termination. Mills v. Leath, 709 F. Supp. 671, 675 
  (D.S.C. 1988). The trial court was therefore correct to dismiss the action as 
  to the four council members. Angus claims that she was suing them not as council 
  members, but in their capacity as individuals. That argument is unpersuasive. 
  The employment agreement stated on its face that Angus served â€œat the willâ€ 
  of the Council. Clearly, the council members acted within their authority when 
  they fired Angus and they cannot be sued for doing what they had a right to 
  do. See Antley v. Shepherd, 340 S.C. 541, 550, 532 S.E.2d 294, 
  298 (Ct. App. 2000) (holding that a county official was immune from liability 
  in his individual capacity since that official acted within his authority in 
  firing an employee who was serving at the will of the official).
Burroughs & Chapin, Wendel, Dowling, 
  the Myrtle Beach Herald, and Johnson (â€œthe remaining respondentsâ€) present a 
  different issue than the one addressed in Ross. They are not Angusâ€™s 
  former employers. As to them, the appropriate inquiry is whether an at-will 
  employee can maintain an action for civil conspiracy against a third-party (other 
  than the former employer) on the theory that the third-partyâ€™s conspiracy caused 
  the former employer to fire the employee. We believe that an at will-employee 
  can maintain such an action.
In Todd v. S.C. Farm Bureau, 
  283 S.C. 155, 321 S.E.2d 602 (Ct. App. 1984) (overruled on other grounds), the 
  Court recognized that a former employee could bring an action for tortious interference 
  against a third party, even if the employment was at will. In that case, Farm 
  Bureau, the employer, had hired Equifax to investigate some irregularities. 
  Equifax identified Todd, an employee, as the alleged wrongdoer. Farm Bureau 
  then fired Todd. Todd sued Farm Bureau and Equifax. The jury found for Todd, 
  awarding him damages. Farm Bureau and Equifax appealed. The Court ruled that 
  â€œwhere a third party induces an employer to discharge an employee who is working 
  under a contract terminable at will, but which employment would have continued 
  indefinitely except for such interference, a cause of action arises in favor 
  of the employee against the third person,â€ if the alleged inducement â€œinfluence[d], 
  â€¦ or coerce[d] one of the parties to the contract to abandon the relationship 
  or breach the contract.â€ Id. at 163, 321 S.E.2d at 607 (citation omitted). 
  However, the Court found that the evidence failed to show that Equifax had participated 
  in a conspiracy and reversed. [1]  
Other jurisdictions have adopted 
the same principle. The Georgia Court of Appeals ruled in favor of an attorney 
who had sued a railroad company because the railroad company had â€œinduced the 
[attorneyâ€™s] client, and conspired with himâ€ to fire the attorney. Studdard 
v. Evans, 135 S.E.2d 60, 64 (Ga. Ct. App. 1964). As a result, the attorney 
was forced to withdraw from the case. The railroad company argued that the attorney 
did not state a cause of action because the client was free to fire him at any 
time. The court rejected the argument. The court held that â€œthe fact that employment 
is at the will of the employer, [does] not give immunity to a third person who, 
without justification, interferes with the relation between the parties to the 
contract.â€ Id.  
North Carolina reached a similar 
  conclusion in Smith v. Ford Motor Co., 221 S.E.2d 282 (N.C. 1976). There, 
  the court first defined an â€œoutsiderâ€ as â€œone who was not a party to the terminated 
  contract and who had no legitimate business interest of his own in the subject 
  matter thereof.â€ Smith, 221 S.E.2d at 292. Then the court explained:

  The question presented to us by 
    this appeal is: If A, knowing B is employed by C under a contract terminable 
    at will by C, maliciously causes C to discharge B, which C would not otherwise 
    have done, can B maintain in the courts of this State an action against A 
    for damages? Our conclusion is that he can. 

Id. at 290.
These facts are similar if not identical 
  to those alleged by Angus. If the remaining respondents maliciously caused Horry 
  County to discharge Angus, assuming that Angus was able to continue performing 
  her job well â€“ then the answer is yes, Angus can bring an action against them. 
   [2] Â  
As stated earlier, the trial court 
  in the current case relied on Ross in reaching its conclusion.Â  Ross 
  in turn cites Kirby v. Gulf Oil, 230 S.C. 11, 94 S.E.2d 21 (1956) as 
  its authority for the principle that â€œa conspiracy may not be based upon an 
  act done in the exercise of a legal right.â€ Ross, 273 S.C. at 765, 259 
  S.E.2d at 815. Kirby cites McMaster v. Ford Motor Co., 122 S.C. 
  244, 115 S.E. 244 (1921) and Howle v. Mountain Ice Co., 167 S.C. 41, 
  165 S.E. 724 (1932). But any reliance on Ross and those cases is misplaced. 
  Kirby, McMaster and Howle are all easily distinguishable 
  from Angusâ€™s claim, for there is no third party involvement in those cases.Â  
  
Kirby involved real estate.Â  
  Kirby had a month-to-month lease on a gas station, but Kirbyâ€™s landlord, Whitlock, 
  terminated the lease, causing Kirby to lose the business. Kirby sued, alleging 
  Whitlock, Gulf Oil, and Whitlockâ€™s son conspired to take his gas station. The 
  supreme court sustained a dismissal in favor of the defendants, holding that 
  â€œa conspiracy may not be based upon an act done in the exercise of a legal right.â€ 
  Kirby, 230 S.C. at 27. The court found that Whitlock, Sr., had terminated 
  the lease for his own reasons, without any prompting from anyone. Neither Whitlockâ€™s 
  son nor Gulf Oil had played an active role in Kirbyâ€™s ruin.
McMaster, too, is easily distinguished 
  from this case. In McMaster, the issue revolved around a partyâ€™s right 
  to determine with whom to conduct business. McMaster sued Ford and Fordâ€™s dealers 
  because Ford would not use and would not allow its dealers to use McMasterâ€™s 
  products on Ford-manufactured automobiles. Since the dealers were Fordâ€™s agents, 
  no independent third party was involved. See Todd, 283 S.C. at 
  164, 283 S.E.2d at 607 (1984) (citing Muller v. Stromberg, 427 So.2d 
  266 (Fla. Dist. App. 1983) (ruling that an officer or agent of a corporation 
  acting for or on behalf of the corporation is not a third party)). In dismissing 
  the action, the McMaster court explained that â€œ[w]hile there is some 
  difference of opinion, the weight of authority is in favor of the general proposition 
  that an act done in the exercise of a legal right cannot be treated as wrongful 
  and actionable merely because a malicious motive prompted the exercise of the 
  right.â€ McMaster, 122 S.C. at 246. But that general principle protects 
  only a person directly involved in the underlying relationship, not a 
  third party. [3] Â Â  
Moreover, the McMaster court 
  relied secondarily on the absence of an unlawful act and of an unlawful means. 
  The court reasoned that the allegation of conspiracy was of no import â€œin the 
  legal consequences, becauseâ€¦[the] defendants did nothing unlawful and resorted 
  to no unlawful means to accomplish their purpose.â€ Id. at 247. However, 
  as indicated earlier, an unlawful means and unlawful purpose are required elements 
  of a criminal, not civil, conspiracy. An action for civil conspiracy may exist 
  even though no unlawful means were used. See LaMotte v. Punch Line, 
  296 S.C. 66, 70, 370 S.E.2d 711, 713 (1988); Lee, 289 S.C. at 11, 344 
  S.E.2d at 382.
Finally, in Howle, the plaintiff 
  sued the defendants alleging they conspired to eliminate competition in the 
  ice business.Â  Even while sustaining a dismissal of the action, the supreme 
  court clarified its position:Â  

  [A]s to conspiracy, [the principle] 
    that two or more may lawfully do, under agreement and regardless of purpose 
    or motive whatever one may lawfully do singly â€¦ is not the majority 
    view or that of this court.Â  We should not be understood as holding 
    that under no circumstances can an act resulting in damage, when done by two 
    or more pursuant to an agreement, be actionable if a like act, when done by 
    one alone, would not be actionable.Â  The decision here is based solely â€¦ upon 
    the insufficiency of the evidence to show an agreement between the defendants 
    â€¦ the gravamen of the charge.Â  

Id. at 47, 165 S.E. at 729 
  (affâ€™d on rehâ€™g) (emphasis added).
In the current case, the remaining 
  respondents argued, and the trial court accepted, that â€œ[s]ince Mrs. Angusâ€™ 
  employment was terminable at will, she has no cause of action for civil conspiracy.â€ 
  That conclusion is excessively broad. In Lee, the Court pointedly rejected 
  the notion that â€œliability for the tort of conspiracy cannot be grounded on 
  a lawful act.â€ 289 S.C. at 12, 344 S.E.2d at 382. 
The United States Supreme Court had 
  reached a similar conclusion much earlier in Truax v. Raich, 36 S.Ct. 
  7, 9 (1915): 

  It is said that the bill does not 
    show an employment for a term, and that under an employment at will the complainant 
    could be discharged at any time, for any reason or for no reason, the motive 
    of the employer being immaterial. The conclusion, however, that is sought 
    to be drawn, is too broad. The fact that the employment is at the will of 
    the parties, respectively, does not make it one at the will of others.Â  
    The employee has manifest interest in the freedom of the employer to exercise 
    his judgment without illegal interference or compulsion and, by the weight 
    of authority, the unjustified interference of third persons is actionable 
    although the employment is at will.Â  

(emphasis added). 
CONCLUSION 

Its ruling notwithstanding, Ross 
  does not control the current case. The facts as alleged here place the remaining 
  respondents squarely at the heart of the conspiracy. The theory of the case 
  is not that Horry County decided to fire Angus and conspired with the remaining 
  respondents to achieve that result, but rather that they decided to â€œget 
  rid ofâ€ Angus and induced Horry County to fire her. 
Based on the foregoing, the trial 
  courtâ€™s order is AFFIRMED as to the council members and REVERSED 
  as to the remaining respondents.
HUFF, J., and CURETON, A.J., concur.

 
   [1]  In Todd v. S.C.Farm Bureau, 287 S.C. 190, 
    336 S.E.2d 472 (1985), the Supreme Court reversed that decision, reasoning 
    that the Court had replaced the juryâ€™s findings of facts with its own. Having 
    found â€œsome competent evidence on which the jury could return a verdict for 
    Toddâ€ (Equifax was the party that identified Todd as â€œleaking information,â€ 
    had administered a â€œvoice stressâ€ test, and was slated to conduct a polygraph), 
    the Supreme Court reinstated the juryâ€™s award against Equifax.

 
   [2]  Angus had been employed for about three years 
    at the time and had received excellent evaluations.

 
   [3]  Even in cases involving the former employer, South 
    Carolina courts and others have placed some limitations on the power to terminate 
    at-will employees. See e.g. Ludwick v. Minute of Carolina, 
    Inc., 287 S.C. 219, 225, 337 S.E.2d 213, 216 (1985) (recognizing a public 
    policy exception to the doctrine of at-will employment, reasoning that â€œ[w]here 
    the retaliatory discharge of an at-will employee constitutes violation of 
    a clear mandate of public policy, a cause of action in tort for wrongful discharge 
    arises); Bd. of County Commrs. v. Umbehr, 518 U.S. 668, 685 (1996) 
    (holding that the First Amendment protects independent contractors from termination 
    or prevention of automatic renewal of at-will government contracts in retaliation 
    for their exercise of freedom of speech); Haddle v. Garrison, 525 U.S. 
    121, 126 (1998) (holding that a fired at-will employee did suffer an â€œinjury 
    in his person or propertyâ€ within the meaning of Â§1985(2), reasoning that 
    common law had long offered a remedy for such losses).
