THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
RIM Associates, a South Carolina general partnership,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
John E. Blackwell,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Roger M. Young, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3747
Heard October 8, 2003 â€“ Filed February 
  23, 2004
Withdrawn, Substituted and Re-Filed 
  May 14, 2004Â Â 

REVERSED


  
    
      
G. Dana Sinkler, Mark S. Sharpe, Paul E. Tinkler, and R. Bruce Wallace, all 
  of Charleston, for Appellant.
Richard S. Rosen and Daniel F. Blanchard, III, both of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  

BEATTY, J.: RIM Associates, a South Carolina 
  general partnership, sued John Blackwell, a partner, seeking contribution for 
  a partnership debt the partnership had incurred as a result of a debt owed to 
  Blackwell. The trial court ordered Blackwell to make a contribution. We reverse.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  

FACTS
John Blackwellâ€™s company, R.I. of North Charleston 
  (â€œR.I.â€), owned a Ramada Inn. In 1985, Everett Smith, Joe Edens and James Finley 
  (â€œthe partnersâ€) decided to purchase the hotel.Â  Blackwell agreed to sell the 
  hotel for 4.575 million dollars. As part of the purchase price, R.I. accepted 
  a note of 1.3 million dollars (â€œthe Blackwell noteâ€). Blackwell also received 
  a twenty-five percent partnership interest in RIM Associates (â€œRIMâ€), the partnership 
  formed by Blackwell and the partners â€œto invest in, own, and operateâ€ the hotel. 
  The partners financed the transaction by taking out a bank loan for the 3.275 
  million dollar balance owed to Blackwell. The partners did not place any capital 
  in the transaction, but they guaranteed seventy-five percent of the Blackwell 
  note. 
RIM fell behind on its payments on the Blackwell 
  note and, in 1989, Blackwell and RIM renegotiated its terms. Blackwell extended 
  the maturity date of the Blackwell note and the partners guaranteed it one hundred 
  percent. The parties contemporaneously entered into an indemnification agreement 
  (â€œthe 1989 agreementâ€) that provided in part:

The Partners acknowledge and agree that each Partner, as 
  the owner of a twenty-five (25%) interest in the Partnership, is responsible 
  for twenty-five (25%) of the Partnership indebtedness and each Partner agrees 
  to indemnify and hold the others harmless from liability for such Partnerâ€™s 
  share of any such indebtedness . . . .
Edens, Smith, and Finley have, in the Note Modification, agreed 
  to jointly and severally guarantee the payment of the Note in its entirety.Â  
  It is agreed, however, that the indebtedness evidenced by the Note and any other 
  Partnership indebtedness in excess of the amounts above set forth shall remain 
  Partnership debts, the payment of which shall continue to be the obligation 
  of the Partnership, but Blackwell shall have no personal liability therefor 
  other than to the extent of his interest in the Partnership and Edens, Smith 
  and Finley shall not have the right to require contribution from Blackwell on 
  account of any payment which they may have to make on the Note. Any such 
  payment(s) shall be deemed to be a capital contribution(s) to the Partnership 
  by the party making the same. [1]   

(emphasis added).
Notwithstanding the 1989 agreement, RIM again fell 
  behind on its payments.Â  In 1997, Blackwell sued the partners for repayment 
  as guarantors of the Blackwell note. The partners brought a third party complaint 
  against RIM, seeking indemnification for the amounts due under the Blackwell 
  note. The partners then caused RIM to bring suit against Blackwell seeking contribution 
  from him in case RIM was required to indemnify the partners.Â  
The parties reached a settlement in April or June 
  of 1999 (â€œthe 1999 settlementâ€). The 1999 settlement provided in part: 

1)  The guarantors would pay $2 million including principal, 
  interest, attorneyâ€™s fees, and costs, to John and Hazel Blackwell.Â  John and 
  Hazel will satisfy the Note.Â  
  2)  All of the pending litigation against John
and Hazel Blackwell will be dismissed with
prejudice.
3)  John Blackwell will remain in the Partnership.Â  
4)Â Â  The Partnership will not attempt to borrow the money 
  to pay John and Hazel except with the prior written approval of John Blackwell.

(emphasis added).
Following the court-ordered 1999 settlement, Blackwell 
  moved to amend the order to include that â€œJohn Blackwell cannot be required 
  to respond to a capital call as a result of the settlement found by the Court.â€Â  
  The judge refused, reasoning that â€œ[the] issue may have been raised by [Blackwell] 
  but it is a post-settlement issue and not properly before this court at this 
  time.â€ On July 14, Edens and Smith paid two million dollars pursuant to the 
  1999 settlement. Finley did not contribute any funds. 
  [2]   
On August 5, the trial judge ordered â€œ[t]he action 
  . . . ended and dismissed with prejudice as [to] all parties.â€ RIM moved to 
  amend the order. As a result, the trial judge rescinded that order and issued 
  a second order that dismissed with prejudice all causes of action â€œby and againstâ€ 
  Blackwell â€œasserted within the action,â€ all claims by RIM â€œin the Amended Fourth 
  Party Complaint,â€ and all actions by Blackwell. The trial judge also dismissed 
  all actions by the individual partners Eden, Smith, and Finley against RIM but 
  without prejudice. 
In April 2000, RIM sued Blackwell. RIMâ€™s Amended 
  Complaint claimed breach of the partnership agreement and sought contribution 
  and specific performance.Â  Following a bench trial, the court found: 

The Partnership did not â€œborrowâ€ the money to pay the settlement 
  in violation of the settlement agreement and did not receive monies from Smith 
  and Edens.Â  
Blackwell was obligated to make a contribution to the Partnership 
  to fund the expenses of his own settlement.
The 1989 agreement, which expressly prohibits any such contribution, 
  had been rescinded by the Blackwell settlement.
The Partnership did not assert these claims in the prior litigation.
The Partnership claims were not barred by the dismissal with 
  prejudice.
The Partnership was entitled to recover attorneys fees and 
  costs.

The trial judge ruled that Blackwell had breached 
  his contractual and statutory obligations to make contributions under the partnership 
  agreement and the South Carolina Uniform Partnership Act.Â  Blackwell appeals.
 
  ISSUES
Blackwell raises eight exceptions to the trial 
  judgeâ€™s rulings, but those exceptions can be condensed in the following six 
  issues:

  
    Did the trial court err in finding that the partnership was
    authorized to bring this action?
    
  
    Did the trial court err in holding that Blackwell could be
    required to contribute to the payment of his own 
  note?
    
  
    Did the trial court err in not finding that the claims of the partnership had 
  previously been dismissed with prejudice?
    
  
    Did the trial court err in not finding that the partnership borrowed the settlement 
  funds in violation of the settlement agreement and the 1989 agreement?
    
  
    Did the trial court err in allowing this action without first requiring an accounting?
    
  
    Did the trial court err in awarding attorneysâ€™ fees to the partnership?

STANDARD 
  OF REVIEW
RIM alleges two causes of action against Blackwell. 
  RIM characterizes them as â€œContributionâ€ and â€œBreach of Contract / Specific 
  Performance.â€ However, an appellate court is not bound by a partyâ€™s characterization 
  of the actions. Klippel v. Mid-Carolina Oil, Inc., 303 S.C. 127, 129, 
  399 S.E.2d 163, 164 (Ct. App. 1990) (citing Ariail v. Ariail, 295 S.C. 
  486, 491, 369 S.E.2d 146, 149 (Ct. App. 1988)). Whether an action is at law 
  or in equity is determined by the main purpose of the suit. Mortgage Recovery 
  Fund-Riverbend, Ltd. v. Heritage Clipper Riverbend Trust, 327 S.C. 491, 
  493, 489 S.E.2d 655, 656 (Ct. App. 1997) (citing Baughman v. AT&T, 
  298 S.C. 127, 130, 378 S.E.2d 599, 600 (1989)). The court should determine the 
  main purpose of an action from the body of the complaint. Carjow, LLC v. 
  Simmons, 349 S.C. 514, 518, 563 S.E.2d 359, 362 (Ct. App. 2002) (citing 
  Ins. Fin. Servs., Inc. v. South Carolina Ins. Co., 271 S.C. 289, 293, 
  247 S.E.2d 315, 318 (1978) (â€œThe main purpose of the action should generally 
  be ascertained from the body of the complaint.â€)). â€œWhether the action is one 
  at law or in equity is determined by the nature of the pleadings and the character 
  of the relief sought.â€ In re Estate of Holden, 343 S.C. 267, 278, 539 
  S.E.2d 703, 709 (2000) (citing Bell v. Mackey, 191 S.C. 105, 119, 3 S.E.2d 
  816, 824 (1939) (â€œThe nature of the issues as raised by the pleadings or the 
  pleadings and proof, and character of relief sought under them, determines the 
  character of an action as legal or equitable.â€)).
Notwithstanding RIMâ€™s characterization of its complaint, 
  RIM alleges only one single cause of action for breach of contract and requests 
  the remedy of specific performance. [3]  An action for specific performance 
  lies in equity. [4]  Ingram 
  v. Kaseyâ€™s Assocs., 340 S.C. 98, 105, 531 S.E.2d 287, 290 (2000); see 
  alsoÂ  Barnacle Broadcasting, Inc. v. Baker Broadcasting, Inc., 343 
  S.C. 140, 146, 538 S.E.2d 672, 675 (Ct. App. 2000) (explaining that â€œ[a]n action 
  for specific performance [on a contract] lies in equityâ€). Â Because the action 
  is in equity, the appellate court â€œmay find facts in accordance with its own 
  view of the preponderance of the evidenceâ€ in reviewing such an action. Id. 

LAW/ANALYSISÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 

 I.             RIMâ€™s authority to bring this action 
   

Blackwell argues that the trial judge erred in ruling 
  that RIM was authorized to bring this action against Blackwell. We disagree.
The partnership agreement states that â€œ[i]f any Partner 
  fails to make contributions to capital as provided for by the terms of this 
  Agreement, the remaining Partners who are not in default shall have the right 
  to seek and obtain damages from the defaulting Partner . . . .â€ Blackwell argues 
  that language allows only the partners, and not the partnership, to sue Blackwell 
  for damages and specific performance. However, the partnership agreement was 
  signed in 1985, at a time when partnerships could not bring an action in their 
  own name. See Haddock Flying Serv. v. Tisdale, 288 S.C. 62, 64, 
  339 S.E.2d 525,Â Â  526 (Ct. App. 1986) (â€œHowever, a partnership is not such a 
  legal entity that it may maintain a suit in its name alone.â€).Â  Had the partnership 
  agreement stated otherwise, any such authority would have been meaningless. 
  The legislature remedied the situation in 1986 by adopting S.C. Ann. Code Â§ 
  15-5-45 (2003) which states that â€œ[a]ny partnership formed under the laws of 
  this State . . . shall have the capacity . . . to sue and be sued in the courts 
  and agencies of this State as a separate entity . . . .â€Â  
Moreover, while the partnership agreement did not 
  authorize the partnership to sue a defaulting partner, neither did it forbid 
  such an action. The partnership agreement is silent on the matter. In such a 
  situation, we look to state law to determine whether the action is permissible. 
  See Weeks v. McWilliams, 291 S.C. 287, 292, 353 S.E.2d 289, 292 
  (1987) (ruling that the dissolution of a partnership was permissible because 
  the partnership agreement did not specifically forbid it). The state of South 
  Carolina granted partnerships the power to sue on their own behalf in 1986. 
  Therefore, RIM can bring this action.

  II.             
The partiesâ€™ agreements  
   

The trial court ruled that the 1989 agreement was 
  inoperative and ordered Blackwell to contribute to RIM in order to repay Edens 
  and Smith for their payment of the Blackwell note. That ruling was error.
In reaching its conclusion, the trial court relied 
  partially on the South Carolina Uniform Partnership Act, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 33-41-510 
  (1994). The Act states in pertinent part: â€œThe partnership must indemnify every 
  partner in respect of payments made and personal liabilities reasonably incurred 
  by him in the ordinary and proper conduct of its business or for the preservation 
  of its business or property.â€ Â§ 33-41-510(2). But that very section subordinates 
  that general principle to the partiesâ€™ agreements, explaining that the â€œrights 
  and duties of the partners in relation to the partnership shall be determined, 
  subject to any agreement between them, by the following rules . . . .â€ 
  Â§ 33-41-510 (emphasis added). The question then becomes what agreements existed 
  among Blackwell, the partners, and RIM and what effect those agreements had 
  on the issue of contributing additional capital.Â  The record indicates that 
  the partners had a partnership agreement, an Amended and Restated Indemnification 
  Agreement (the 1989 agreement), and the 1999 settlement. [5]  The trial judge found that the 
  partiesâ€™ 1999 settlement rescinded the 1989 agreement. There is no evidence 
  to support that conclusion. 
Any modification of a written contract must satisfy 
  all the requirements of a contract, including a meeting of the minds. First 
  Union Mortgage Corp. v. Thomas, 317 S.C. 63, 70, 451 S.E.2d 907, 912 (Ct. 
  App. 1994). Here, there is no evidence of any discussion, action, or agreement 
  to rescind the 1989 agreement by implication or otherwise. [6] Â  There can be no â€œmeeting of the mindsâ€ if the issue was not 
  a part of the partiesâ€™ agreement. Just as importantly, the July 1999 Order specifically 
  states that â€œ[t]he Amended and Restated indemnification Agreement dated 1 February, 
  1989 was not addressed in the settlement agreement reached by the parties and 
  therefore it is not part of the settlement.â€ 
Moreover, there is no evidence that the 1989 agreement 
  and the 1999 settlement materially contradict each other. Both documents provide 
  that Blackwell would remain a partner and share in the partnershipâ€™s profits 
  and debts, including the Blackwell note. And both documents placed restrictions 
  on how the Blackwell note could be paid. The 1989 agreement stated: â€œEden, Finley, 
  and Smith shall not have the right to require contribution from Blackwell on 
  account of any payment they may have to make on the Note. Any such payment(s) 
  shall be deemed to be a capital contribution(s) to the Partnership by the party 
  making the same.â€ The 1999 settlement, too, forbade RIM to borrow money to pay 
  the Blackwell note without Blackwellâ€™s prior permission. Although Blackwell 
  may be required to contribute to the payment of the note, the documents, when 
  read together, limit Blackwellâ€™s contribution toward the Blackwell note to his 
  share of the funds generated by RIM and only if RIM did not default on the note. 

This conclusion is reinforced by RIMâ€™s pleading 
  in the prior action. Paragraphs 37 and 39 of RIMâ€™s Amended Third Party Answer 
  And Claims state that RIM relied on Blackwellâ€™s representation that the â€œ[s]o-calledÂ  
  [Blackwell note] would be a â€˜cash flow,â€™ â€˜softâ€™ note and would be paid from 
  distributions from operations and refinancing of the hotel.â€ 
  [7]  It is clear that the parties never agreed that Blackwell would make 
  a capital call contribution to pay the Blackwell note. 

  III.          
Effect of prior rulings  
 Â Â 

Blackwell raises a res judicata argument, asserting 
  that the trial court erred when it held that its November 2, 1999 Order did 
  not bar RIMâ€™s current action seeking contribution from Blackwell. We agree.Â Â  

â€œA case that is dismissed â€˜with prejudiceâ€™ indicates 
  an adjudication on the merits and, pursuant to res judicata, prohibits subsequent 
  litigation to the same extent as if the action had been tried to a final adjudication.â€ 
  Nelson v. QHG of S.C., Inc., 354 S.C. 290, 311, 580 S.E.2d 171, 182 (Ct. 
  App. 2003). â€œTo establish res judicata, the defendant must prove the following 
  three elements: (1) identity of the parties; (2) identity of the subject matter; 
  and (3) adjudication of the issue in the former suit.â€ Plum Creek Dev. Co. 
  v. City of Conway, 334 S.C. 30, 34, 512 S.E.2d 106, 109 (1999). Res judicata 
  is an affirmative defense that must be pled at trial in order to be pursued 
  on appeal. Wagner v. Wagner, 286 S.C. 489, 491, 335 S.E.2d 246, 247 (Ct. 
  App. 1985). An affirmative defense is waived if not pled. Howard v. S. C. 
  Depâ€™t of Highways, 343 S.C. 149, 152, 538 S.E.2d 291, 294 (Ct. App. 2000). 
  Generally, claims or defenses not presented in the pleadings will not be considered 
  on appeal. McNeely v. S.C. Farm Bureau Mut. Ins. Co., 259 S.C. 39, 41, 
  190 S.E.2d 499, 499 (1972).
On appeal, RIM insists that a res judicata defense 
  is not available to Blackwell because Blackwell did not raise it in his answer. 
  Blackwell counters that the res judicata issue is preserved because RIM did 
  not object when Blackwell argued the issue before the trial court and because 
  the trial court ruled on the matter in its appealed order. Generally, â€œres judicata 
  must be pleaded to be established,â€ but an exception to the broad rule exists 
  â€œwhere the matter â€˜becomes an issue without objection based upon the lack of 
  pleading.â€™â€ Baty v. Stanley, 291 S.C. 546, 548, 354 S.E.2d 571, 572 (Ct. 
  App. 1987) (citing Beall v. Doe, 281 S.C. 363, 367, 315 S.E.2d 186, 188 
  (Ct. App. 1984)). Therefore, RIM waived any valid objection it might have otherwise 
  had by not timely objecting to Blackwellâ€™s res judicata argument. 
We agree that the issue was preserved and we hold 
  that the 1999 settlement does preclude the current claim. â€œRes judicata 
  bars subsequent actions by the same parties when the claims arise out of the 
  same transaction or occurrence that was the subject of a prior action between 
  those parties.â€ Plum Creek Dev. Co., 334 S.C. at 34, 512 S.E.2d at 109. 
  The doctrine bars not only the claims that were actually raised, but also those 
  â€œissues which might have been raised in the former suit.â€ Id. 
  (citation omitted) (emphasis added). 
The 1999 settlement stipulated that â€œ[a]ll of the 
  pending litigation against John and Hazel Blackwell will be dismissed with prejudice.â€ 
  And in an amended order, the trial court dismissed with prejudice â€œall causes 
  of action and claims by and againstâ€ Blackwell that were â€œassertedâ€ as well 
  as â€œall claims made by RIMâ€ in the Amended Fourth Party Complaint. At the time, 
  RIM had numerous claims against Blackwell, including one for â€œEstoppel/Breach 
  of Partnership Agreement.â€ RIM sought indemnification as a remedy. In its 2001 
  action against Blackwell, RIM again claimed â€œBreach of Partnership Agreement,â€ 
  but attempted to add a claim for contribution. The question then is whether 
  this claim is a new and separate one, as to be beyond the reach of the 1999 
  documents. 
RIM asserts that the contribution claim is permissible 
  because it had not accrued and was not yet â€œassertedâ€ in 1999. Since we find 
  that RIM did not plead a cause of action for contribution, its argument may 
  well be moot. However, we choose to address it and hold that the claim is barred 
  by res judicata. It is well settled that â€œ[r]es judicata bars subsequent actions 
  by the same parties when the claims arise out of the same transaction or 
  occurrence that was the subject of a prior action between these parties.â€ 
  Nelson, 354 S.C. at 304, 580 S.E.2d at 178 (emphasis added). The source 
  was the same in RIMâ€™s prior action as in the action sub judice: the payment 
  of the Blackwell note. Therefore, RIMâ€™s current action is barred. Â 
RIM also contends that res judicata does not apply 
  because the earlier action was one for indemnification, not contribution. But 
  RIM is merely seeking a different remedy here. â€œA different remedy, however, 
  does not alter the fact that the claims are identical.â€ Plum Creek Dev. Co., 
  334 S.C. at 35, 512 S.E.2d at 109 (citing 46 Am. Jur. 2d Judgments Â§ 
  536 (1994) (â€œA claim for damages is a claim for relief rather than an assertion 
  of a different cause of action for purposes of determining the applicability 
  of res judicata.â€)). â€œ[F]or purposes of res judicata, â€˜cause of actionâ€™ is not 
  the form of action in which a claim is asserted but, rather the â€˜cause for action, 
  meaning the underlying facts combined with the law giving the party a right 
  to a remedy of one form or another based thereon.â€™â€ Id. at 36, 512 S.E.2d 
  at 110 (citing 50 C.J.S. Judgment Â§ 749 (1997)). [8]  As stated earlier, the genesis of this action 
  and of the previous one is the collection of the Blackwell note. Additionally, 
  the parties involved are the same. Therefore, res judicata is applicable and 
  bars this action.

  IV.          
RIMâ€™s borrowing           

Blackwell argues the trial court erred when it found that RIM did not borrow 
  the funds to pay the Blackwell note in violation of the 1999 settlement. We 
  agree. [9] 
The 1999 settlement included a stipulation that 
  RIM would not attempt to borrow money to pay the Blackwell note, â€œexcept with 
  the prior written approval of John Blackwell.â€ Aware of that condition, RIM 
  asked its accountant, Marty Ouzts, to treat the two million dollars from Edens 
  and Smith as an â€œadvance.â€ But an advance is nothing more than a loan. See 
  Tuller v. Nantala Park Co., 276 S.C. 667, 281 S.E.2d 474 (1981) (treating 
  advances as money given as part of a loan); Okatie River, L.L.C. v. Southeastern 
  Site Prep, L.L.C., 353 S.C. 327, 336, 577 S.E.2d 468, 473 (Ct. App. 2003) 
  (finding that a company was entitled to repayment even though the money it gave 
  was identified as an advance). As Outzts himself admitted, â€œan advance is something 
  that is anticipated to be repaid.â€ Smith, one of the partners, repeated as much 
  during his testimony. He was asked: â€œIn your terminology, does a loan and an 
  advance mean two different things, or is it the same thing?â€ Smith responded: 
  â€œI donâ€™t know of any difference.â€ In this instance, RIM entered the money received 
  from Smith and Edens as an advance, and that advance â€“ used to pay the Blackwell 
  note â€“ entitled Smith and Edens to immediate repayment.Â  Clearly, to the extent 
  that RIM â€œpaidâ€ the debt, it borrowed the money from Smith and Edens. Under 
  the 1999 settlement, RIM was not allowed to do so since Blackwell had not agreed 
  to the loan in writing. [10]  
  Therefore, RIMâ€™s action for contribution is barred.
RIM argues that the payment was made directly to 
  Blackwell by the partners as guarantors of the note. Thus, it was not a loan 
  to RIM. [11]  If this were true, then RIM would have had 
  no need to record the money given to Blackwell in its books as an advance from 
  the partners. RIMâ€™s argument convinces the Court that the surviving guarantors 
  of the Blackwell note were cognizant of the restrictions in the 1989 agreement 
  and in the 1999 settlement and attempted to circumvent those restrictions. The 
  only reasonable conclusion from looking at the evidence is that RIM borrowed 
  the money to pay the Blackwell note in violation of the 1999 settlement. 
The trial courtâ€™s finding that the partnership 
  agreement authorized capital calls is unavailing to RIM. The 1989 agreement 
  exempted Blackwell from contributing to the partners for any payment made on 
  the Blackwell note. See supra. The 1989 agreement also required 
  that such payment be considered a capital contribution. Since the partnership 
  agreement prohibited the partners from withdrawing their capital contributions, 
  any payment on the Blackwell note would be payable only upon the dissolution 
  of the partnership. Therefore, RIM had no immediate debt to the partners, and 
  Blackwell had no duty to make a contribution. 
 
  CONCLUSION
We find that (1) RIM had the authority to bring 
  the current action; (2) the 1999 settlement did not rescind the 1989 agreement, 
  andÂ  Blackwell had no duty to contribute under that agreement; (3) the 1999 
  litigation precludes the current action pursuant to res judicata; and (4) to 
  the extent that RIM paid the Blackwell note, RIM borrowed the money, clearly 
  violating the partiesâ€™ agreements. Having so found, we need not reach Blackwellâ€™s 
  remaining arguments. The trial judgeâ€™s ruling is 
REVERSED.
GOOLSBY and HUFF, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1]  The Partnership Agreement prohibited the withdrawal of capital contributions. 
  

 
   [2]  Jim Finley has died; RIM is now suing his estate. 
  

 
   
    [3]  The reference in RIMâ€™s complaint to a cause of action for contribution 
    is a misnomer.Â  RIM merely alleges that Blackwell breached the partnership 
    agreement since that agreement provided for capital calls and Blackwell refused 
    to contribute when requested.Â  RIMâ€™s complaint does not reflect any allegation 
    that RIM had paid the partnership debt. An action for contribution cannot 
    be maintained prior to the payment of a debt. First Gen. Serv. of Charleston, 
    Inc. v. Miller, 314 S.C. 439, 443, 445 S.E.2d 446, 448 (1994) (affirming 
    the dismissal of an action for contribution where the plaintiff had not made 
    any payment since â€œthe right to contribution does not arise prior to paymentâ€); 
    Andrade v. Johnson, 345 S.C. 216, 225, 546 S.E.2d 665, 670 (Ct. App. 
    2001) (defining contribution as â€œthe â€˜[r]ight of one who has discharged a 
    common liability to recover of another also liable, the aliquot portion which 
    he ought to pay or bearâ€™â€), revâ€™d on other grounds, Andrade v. Johnson, 
    356 S.C. 238, 588 S.E.2d 588 (2003); 18 Am. Jur. 2d Contribution Â§ 
    19 (2004) (explaining that a party seeking contribution is entitled to recover 
    â€œthe amount he has paid in excess of his share â€¦ a ratable sum of the loss 
    actually sustainedâ€). Therefore, the right of contribution rises only after 
    a party â€œhas been compelled to pay what another should have paid.â€ 18 Am. 
    Jur. 2d Contribution Â§ 2 (2004). Here, since RIM does not allege in 
    its complaint that it paid the Blackwell note, it is doubtful that RIM can 
    sustain an action for contribution. Even if RIMâ€™s cause of action for contribution 
    was feasible, the standard of review would be the same since an action for 
    contribution lies in equity. See Few v. Few, 239 S.C. 321, 334, 
    122 S.E.2d 829, 835 (1961) (noting that â€œthe right to contribution is ordinarily 
    enforced in equityâ€); Kafka v. Pope, 521 N.W.2d 174, 176 (Wis. Ct. 
    App. 1994) (explaining that the contribution process â€œis based on principles 
    of equity . . . â€). Â 

 
   [4]  RIM alleges the lack of an adequate remedy at 
    law. 

 
   
    [5]  The partners contend that the parties reached a settlement on April 
    9, as per a letter from Blackwell to the partners. Blackwell disputed the 
    settlement, but the trial judge found in his June 11 Order that the parties 
    had reached a settlement â€œaccording to the terms of the March 31st 
    letter.â€ Contrary to RIMâ€™s assertion, however, the March 31 letter does not 
    represent the complete settlement between the parties. In response to a motion 
    to reconsider the June 11 Order, the trial court ruled in its July 1, 1999 
    Order that certain items not included in that letter are â€œthe 
    basis for the settlement.â€ Moreover, the trial court indicated that the April 
    9, 1999 letter mentioned at least one term not contained in the March 31 letter, 
    which term is also a condition of the settlement. We therefore must glean 
    the complete terms of the 1999 settlement from more than one document. The 
    parties are appealing neither the June 11 nor the July 11 Orders.Â  

 
   
    [6] The parties had expressly invalidated â€œin its entiretyâ€ their 1985 
    Indemnification Agreement, replacing it with the 1989 agreement. Had they 
    wished to invalidate the 1989 agreement, they certainly could have included 
    similar language in the 1999 settlement.Â  

 
   [7]  When the hotel was refinanced, RIM retained the 
    excess proceeds and did not pay the Blackwell note.

 
   
    [8] RIM could also have brought an action for exoneration whereby it could 
    have sought payment from Blackwell even before satisfying the Blackwell note. 
    See 38 Am. Jur. 2d Guaranty Â§ 124 (1994).

 
   
    [9]  The Court understands that the debt was indeed paid. We maintain 
    only that RIM never alleged in its complaint that it had paid the debt. 
  

 
   
    [10]  In the order now on appeal, the trial court declared that Blackwell 
    had given his â€œprior written approvalâ€ to a loan â€œby virtue of the settlement 
    that was reached . . . and confirmed in writingâ€ by the parties. Again, the 
    record does not provide a scintilla of evidence for such a conclusion. Reaching 
    a settlement is a far cry from agreeing that a debt can be repaid with a loan.

 
   
    [11]  We note that this argument supports the notion that RIM cannot bring 
    a cause of action for contribution since RIM was not the party that paid the 
    debt.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Roger A. Gaddy, M.D.,
as Attorney-in-Fact for Ms. M,        Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
George G. Douglass, III and William P.
Sherrod, as purported Attorneys-in-Fact 
        for Ms. M,        Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Fairfield County
Thomas L. Hughston, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Opinion No. 3797
Heard January 14, 2004 â€“ Filed May 17, 
  2004

 AFFIRMED IN PART AND VACATED IN PART


  
    
      
Desa A. Ballard, of West Columbia and S. Murry Kinard, of 
  Lexington, for Appellants.
S. Jahue Moore, of West Columbia 
  and Thomas H. Pope, III and W. Chad Jenkins, both of Newberry, for Respondent.
      
    
  


KITTREDGE, J.: Dr. Roger A. Gaddy brought 
  this action as the attorney-in-fact for Ms. M [1]  against George G. Douglass, III and William 
  P. Sherrod (Appellants) seeking to declare invalid a March 12, 1999 power of 
  attorney executed by Ms. M in favor of Appellants and the concomitant revocation 
  of Ms. Mâ€™s durable power of attorney executed in 1988.Â  Appellants, third cousins 
  of Ms. M, appeal the trial courtâ€™s order finding that Ms. M lacked capacity 
  to execute the documents.Â  We affirm, finding that on March 12, 1999, Ms. M 
  was suffering from chronic and severe dementia caused by the advanced state 
  of Alzheimerâ€™s disease.Â  We, however, vacate the trial courtâ€™s sua sponte 
  finding that Ms. M lacked testamentary capacity on March 12, 1999.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œA suit for declaratory judgment is neither 
  legal nor equitable, but is determined by the nature of the underlying issue.â€Â  
  Felts v. Richland County, 303 S.C. 354, 356, 400 S.E.2d 781, 782 (1991).Â  
  â€œ[A]n action to set aside a power of attorney and an instrument revoking a power 
  of attorney on the ground of a lack of mental capacity sounds in equity.â€Â  In 
  re Thames, 344 S.C. 564, 571, 544 S.E.2d 854, 857 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  We thus 
  utilize an equity standard of review.Â  As such, this court has jurisdiction 
  to find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  
  Pinckney v. Warren, 344 S.C. 382, 387, 544 S.E.2d 620, 623 (2001).Â  â€œHowever, 
  this broad scope of review does not require an appellate court to disregard 
  the findings below or ignore the fact that the trial judge is in the better 
  position to assess the credibility of the witnesses.â€Â  Id.Â Â  Additionally, 
  Appellants carry the burden of proving that the trial court made erroneous findings.Â  
  Id., 344 S.C. at 387, 544 S.E.2d at 623-24.
FACTS
Ms. M was born in 1918 and grew up in Fairfield 
  County.Â  She moved to Greenville, where she majored in sociology at Furman University 
  and later worked for the South Carolina Department of Social Services.Â  After 
  retiring, Ms. M returned to Fairfield where she lived on her family farm with 
  her brother, a dentist, until his death in the early 1980s.Â  Ms. M never married.Â  

Dr. Gaddy was Ms. Mâ€™s physician and a close family 
  friend. [2] Â  Ms. M and Dr. Gaddyâ€™s family 
  lived on nearby farms and visited each other frequently throughout the 1980s 
  and 1990s.Â Â  For many years Ms. M spent holidays and birthdays with the Gaddy 
  family rather than her own family.Â  She also attended the Gaddy family reunions 
  and visited Dr. Gaddyâ€™s family in Aiken.Â Â  Eventually, Ms. M grew to refer to 
  Dr. Gaddy as her â€œsonâ€ and his children as her â€œgrandchildren.â€
Conversely, Ms. M had little contact with many 
  of her relatives, including Appellants. 
In 1988, Ms. M asked Dr. Gaddy to accompany 
  her to a meeting with Albert C. Todd, III, her estate-planning attorney. [3] Â  After Ms. M met privately with Todd, Dr. Gaddy 
  was called into Toddâ€™s office, at which point Todd informed Dr. Gaddy that Ms. 
  M desired for Dr. Gaddy to handle her affairs.Â  Dr. Gaddy consented.Â  Ms. M 
  then executed a durable general power of attorney (1988 durable power of attorney) 
  designating Dr. Gaddy as her attorney-in-fact.Â  She also executed a will (1988 
  Will) leaving Dr. Gaddy her personal property and farm, and appointing him as 
  trustee of a revocable trust she created to provide scholarships to the Medical 
  University of South Carolina.
Dr. Gaddy did not immediately record the 1988 durable 
  power of attorney, and Ms. M continued to manage her affairs.Â  However, by 1994, 
  Ms. M began showing signs of dementia.Â  For example, she became forgetful, locked 
  herself out of her home, and neglected her personal hygiene.Â  She eventually 
  stopped cooking and cleaning for herself.Â  Concerns about Ms. Mâ€™s progressively 
  worsening mental condition prompted Dr. Gaddy to file the 1988 durable power 
  of attorney in November 1995.Â  Pursuant to the 1988 durable power of attorney, 
  Dr. Gaddy began to act as Ms. Mâ€™s attorney-in-fact and assumed control of her 
  finances, farm, and health care.Â  His responsibilities included paying her bills, 
  tilling her garden, repairing fences, and hiring caregivers.
In March 1996, Dr. Gaddy discovered Ms. M had fallen 
  in her home and fractured a vertebra.Â  Ms. M was hospitalized for six weeks.Â  
  During the hospitalization, Dr. Gaddy fumigated and cleaned her home, which 
  had become flea-infested and unclean to the point where rat droppings were found 
  in the house.Â  Finding that Ms. M was not mentally competent to care for herself, 
  he arranged for full-time caretakers to attend to her after she recovered from 
  the injuries she sustained in her fall.Â  He made improvements in her home, including 
  replacing moth-eaten area rugs with new rugs and upgraded her kitchen to enable 
  caretakers to prepare her meals.Â  Dr. Gaddy also made plumbing repairs to the 
  house, and took steps to adapt a bathroom to make it safer for caretakers to 
  bathe Ms. M, who was incapable of doing so unassisted.Â  During Ms. Mâ€™s hospitalization, 
  neither of the Appellants visited her in the hospital or sought to assist her 
  in any manner.
Dr. Gaddy had Ms. M examined and evaluated by Dr. 
  James E. Carnes, a neurologist, in December 1996.Â  After examining Ms. M, Dr. 
  Carnes found that she suffered from dementia and confirmed she was unable to 
  handle her affairs. 
As Ms. Mâ€™s Alzheimerâ€™s disease progressed and her 
  faculties deteriorated, Dr. Gaddy managed her financial affairs, oversaw maintenance 
  of her properties, and ensured that she received constant care including food, 
  clothing, bathing, and housekeeping.Â  He also constructed a metal barn for multiple 
  purposes, including the storing of Ms. Mâ€™s personal property and farm equipment 
  used to maintain the 200-acre farm.Â  The barn also included small living accommodations 
  that Dr. Gaddy planned to use to house a caretaker or someone to maintain the 
  farm.Â  
Ms. Mâ€™s long-standing distant relationship with 
  some members of her family, including Appellants, changed in March of 1999. 

On March 12, 1999, Appellants visited 
  Ms. M, and with the help of disgruntled caretaker Lil Heller, took her to an 
  appointment with Columbia attorney Douglas N. Trulsow to â€œget rid of Dr. Gaddy.â€ [4] Â  On the drive to Truslowâ€™s office, 
  Heller had to remind Ms. M several times of their destination and purpose.Â  
  At Truslowâ€™s office, Ms. M signed a document revoking the 1988 Will and the 
  1988 durable power of attorney.Â  She also signed a new durable power of attorney 
  (1999 durable power of attorney) naming Appellants as her attorneys-in-fact.Â  
  Appellants failed to disclose Ms. Mâ€™s dementia to Truslow. [5] Â  David Byrd, a witness to the 
  execution of the March 12 documents, was likewise not informed of Ms. Mâ€™s dementia.Â  

Armed with the revocation of the 1988 power of 
  attorney and recently executed power of attorney in their favor, Appellants 
  prohibited Dr. Gaddy from contacting Ms. M.Â  Dr. Gaddy was even threatened with 
  arrest if he tried to visit Ms. M.
On March 15, 1999, three days after Ms. M purportedly 
  revoked the 1988 documents and executed the 1999 durable power of attorney, 
  Dr. Gaddy initiated the present action as her attorney-in-fact pursuant to the 
  1988 durable power of attorney.Â  He alleged, among other things, that the purported 
  revocation of the 1988 durable power of attorney and the execution of the 1999 
  durable power of attorney were invalid because â€œon March 12, 1999, the date 
  on which Ms. M purportedly signed the 1999 power of attorney and the revocation, 
  she was not mentally competentâ€ due to â€œsenile dementia of the Alzheimerâ€™s type.â€Â  
  The action sought declaratory judgment to render the 1999 durable power of attorney 
  invalid and declare the 1988 durable power of attorney valid.
The case proceeded to trial on February 19, 2001.Â  
  By order of the Chief Justice of the South Carolina Supreme Court, and with 
  the consent of the parties, Judge Thomas L. Hughston, Jr. was appointed to preside 
  over the case. [6] Â  Judge Hughston 
  conducted a four-day bench trial.Â  During the trial, substantial medical and 
  lay evidence was presented regarding Ms. Mâ€™s progressively degenerative mental 
  state.Â Â Â  
Medical testimony was presented from five physicians 
  who had examined Ms. M.Â  One was Dr. Carnes, who examined Ms. M on three occasions 
  from December 1996 through September 2000.Â  Dr. Carnes, a neurologist and expert 
  in the field of dementia, had treated â€œthousandsâ€ of Alzheimerâ€™s disease patients 
  over a fifteen-year period. 
Dr. Carnes first conducted a neurological exam of Ms. 
  M in December 1996, when she was accompanied by one of her long-time caretakers, 
  Rosemary Wade.Â  During the examination, Ms. M could not answer simple questions 
  such as naming the President of the United States or recalling the year or month.Â  
  Dr. Carnes said he administered a typical memory test in which he showed her 
  three objects and named the objects, and then a very short time later asked 
  her to name the objects. Ms. M was unable to name the objects.Â  Ms. M also had 
  difficulty with tests designed to assess memory, language function, and â€œintellectual 
  performance.â€Â  Based on this first examination, Dr. Carnes determined Ms. M 
  had moderate â€œsenile dementia of the Alzheimerâ€™s typeâ€ and was â€œnot capable 
  of handling financial affairs.â€  [7] Â Â  He concluded that she was not 
  able to make rational decisions or exercise proper judgment. 
Dr. Carnesâ€™ second examination of Ms. M occurred on 
  March 19, 1999, seven days after Ms. M executed documents revoking her 1988 
  Will and 1988 durable power of attorney, and executed the 1999 durable power 
  of attorney.Â  She was accompanied by Wade and her minister.Â  Dr. Carnes found 
  Ms. M â€œpleasantâ€ but â€œdisoriented.â€Â  When asked to identify the month and year, 
  she would not answer.Â  Dr. Carnes asked Ms. M to â€œjust name any President,â€ 
  and she was unable to do so.Â  She was also unable to recall three simple objects 
  shown to her by Dr. Carnes, and was not able to reproduce simple line drawings.Â  
  The balance of the examination produced similarly revealing results, leading 
  Dr. Carnes to conclude that Ms. Mâ€™s level of dementia was â€œmoderate to severeâ€ 
  or in the â€œlater stages of moderate.â€Â  Dr. Carnes further opined that Ms. M 
  would not have been able to understand the nature and effects of her acts, make 
  rational decisions, or exercise proper judgment.Â  He added that she would not 
  have been able to know the extent of her estate, exercise proper judgment regarding 
  the distribution of her estate, or have been able to understand the execution 
  and meaning of legal documents.
Dr. Carnes examined 
  Ms. M a third time in September 2000.Â  She was accompanied by Lil Heller, the 
  caretaker who accompanied Ms. M to attorney Truslowâ€™s office, and Lynn Douglass, 
  a third cousin of Ms. Mâ€™s.Â  During this examination, Ms. M did not know the 
  month or year.Â  According to Dr. Carnes, she was unable to determine whether 
  the time of day was morning, afternoon, or evening.Â  Ms. M told him that she 
  was taking no medications, although she was taking a variety of prescription 
  medicine on a daily basis.Â  She also told Dr. Carnes that she lived alone, cared 
  for herself, and cooked for herself.Â  However, she had received full-time care 
  for several years.
Based on Dr. Carnesâ€™s third examination 
  of Ms. M, he concluded that she was severely demented although physically normal 
  for a person her age.Â  Dr. Carnes noted that Ms. M had â€œsenile dementia of the 
  Alzheimerâ€™s type â€¦ that had progressed beyond the point when [he] saw her previously 
  and that she had â€¦ clearly shown progression of this disease â€¦.â€Â  Dr. Carnes 
  added that she was â€œunable to handle her financial affairsâ€ and â€œwould need 
  help managing her daily activities â€¦.â€
When asked whether Ms. M may 
  have had a â€œlucid momentâ€ in her stage of dementia, Dr. Carnes responded, â€œNo 
  â€¦ [a] lucid moment is â€¦ a term that doesnâ€™t fit well with â€¦ Alzheimerâ€™s Disease.â€Â  
  He then distinguished a psychiatric disease from Alzheimerâ€™s disease, noting 
  the former involves treatable chemical defects while the latter involves the 
  â€œprogressive death of brain cells.â€Â  Dr. Carnes further observed that dementia 
  results in a â€œfaulty rational processâ€ or an â€œintellectual process that is impaired.â€Â  
  He stated that dementia sufferers do not â€œfully understand the nature of what 
  they [are] doing and they [do] not fully understand the ramifications of what 
  [is] there.â€
A second neurologist, Dr. Robert R. Taylor, Jr., also 
  examined Ms. M on March 19, 1999, the same day that Dr. Carnes examined her 
  for the second time.Â  Dr. Taylor practiced neurology from 1967 until his retirement 
  in 2000, during which time he treated â€œthousandsâ€ of Alzheimerâ€™s patients.Â  
  He described Alzheimerâ€™s disease as a cerebral degenerative disease that is 
  organic, rather than chemical, in nature.Â  He added that the Alzheimerâ€™s is 
  a â€œprimaryâ€ disease, resulting in the destruction of brain cells.Â  As the brain 
  disease progresses, according to Dr. Taylor, patients have increased memory 
  problems until they are â€œunable to perform the daily activities of living adequately 
  and have to have caregivers.â€
Dr. Taylor tested six components of Ms. Mâ€™s mental 
  faculties, including intellect, attention span, affect, and memory, â€œespecially 
  recent memory.â€Â  He noted that her memory and intellect were â€œmarkedly impairedâ€ 
  and that her â€œjudgment did not appear adequate â€¦.â€Â  For example, she â€œdidnâ€™t 
  recall what she had for breakfast or supper,â€ nor did she know the month, year, 
  or day of the week.
Â Dr. Taylor concluded that Ms. M was â€œvery dementedâ€ 
  and that her level of dementia from Alzheimerâ€™s disease was â€œsevereâ€ and in 
  â€œadvanced stages.â€Â  In Dr. Taylorâ€™s judgment, Ms. M â€œwas mentally incompetent 
  to manage any of her business affairs or manage her daily activities of livingâ€ 
  such as â€œdressing appropriatelyâ€ and â€œprepar[ing] food adequately.â€Â  In such 
  a condition, Dr. Taylor opined that Ms. M was susceptible to influence of others 
  and unable to â€œmake rational decisions or exercise reasonable judgment about 
  legal matters or any kind of business matter.â€Â  He additionally noted that Ms. 
  M would be unable â€œto understand the execution and meaning of legal documents, 
  such as [a] power of attorney and wills or revocations of those.â€Â  Dr. Taylor 
  found that Ms. M had been in such a condition â€œcertainly for several yearsâ€ 
  before his March 1999 meeting with her.Â  Dr. Taylor finally determined, consistent 
  with the view expressed by Dr. Carnes, that Ms. M would not â€œever have moments 
  of lucidityâ€ to â€œunderstand legal documents â€¦.â€
Additional expert testimony was provided by a third 
  neurologist, Dr. Charles B. McClure, who was selected by the parties to conduct 
  an independent medical evaluation of Ms. M.Â  Board certified in neurology and 
  psychiatry, Dr. McClure estimated he had examined â€œaround a thousandâ€ Alzheimerâ€™s 
  patients during the preceding twenty years in his practice.
Prior to examining Ms. M, Dr. McClure thoroughly reviewed 
  her medical records, including notes from Drs. Carnes and Taylor.Â  He performed 
  a neurological evaluation on September 26, 2000.Â  During his examination, he 
  performed a â€œmental status examâ€ that indicated Ms. M was â€œperfectly awake and 
  alert.â€Â  Ms. M, however, did not know the Presidentâ€™s name or the year, and 
  that she â€œcould not repeat three objects immediately after [Dr. McClure] gave 
  her the objects.â€Â  Based on this information and other aspects of the examination, 
  Dr. McClure assessed that Ms. M â€œhad a substantial dementiaâ€ and that â€œher dementia 
  dated back to at least 1996.â€Â  When asked if he would classify her impairment 
  as â€œmoderate,â€ Dr. McClure responded, â€œNo, I think she had significant cortical 
  impairment.â€Â  Dr. McClure explained that Ms. M doesnâ€™t â€œthink wellâ€ and that 
  her â€œmemory is poor and sheâ€™s just not able to cognate well.â€
Dr. McClure added that Alzheimerâ€™s disease, which he 
  described as a degenerative illness in which brain cells die and never regenerate, 
  caused Ms. Mâ€™s dementia.Â  He confirmed that the disease causes a decrease in 
  higher cortical functioning, which leads to a loss of reasoning and impaired 
  judgment.Â  Dr. McClure concluded that on March 12, 1999, Ms. M lacked â€œsufficient 
  mental capacity to understand legal documents such as a revocation or creation 
  of a power of attorney.â€
Dr. Linda June Campbell, who saw Ms. M for a physical 
  examination on March 12, 1999, testified for Appellants. [8] Â  As an internist, Dr. Campbell acknowledged that a neurologist 
  â€œwould definitely have more expertise than an internistâ€ for evaluating a patientâ€™s 
  mental status.
Ms. M was by accompanied to Dr. Campbellâ€™s office 
  by Lynn Douglass and caretaker Lil Heller.Â Â  Lynn Douglass had called Dr. Campbell 
  and scheduled the appointment.Â  Dr. Campbell testified that while Ms. M was 
  in her office, one of her nurses attempted a â€œmini mental status examâ€ of Ms. 
  M, but Ms. Mâ€™s lack of cooperation prevented the nurse from finishing.Â  She 
  testified that Ms. M â€œdefinitely had Alzheimerâ€™sâ€ disease and â€œhad some mild 
  dementia, for sure.â€Â  Nevertheless, Dr. Campbell testified that on March 12, 
  1999, Ms. M understood â€œthe objects of her affection and extent of properties,â€ 
  and â€œthe nature and the effect of her actions, particularly with regards to 
  legal documents[.]â€Â  The trial court found, as do we, Dr. Campbellâ€™s testimony 
  unpersuasive.Â  When asked if she claimed â€œto have any expertise in the area 
  of Alzheimerâ€™s disease or dementia,â€ she replied, â€œI donâ€™t.â€
Of similar import was the testimony of Appellantsâ€™ 
  second medical expert, Dr. Edward Zamrini.Â  Dr. Zamrini, a â€œbehavioral neurologist,â€ 
  determined that Ms. M suffered from â€œmild to moderateâ€ dementia.Â  He opined, 
  however, that Ms. M had the ability on March 12, 1999, to make â€œa rational decision 
  about what she wanted to do with her property[.]â€Â  Significantly, Dr. Zamrini 
  never reviewed the records of the other neurologists, although he requested 
  such records from Appellants.Â  At trial, Dr. Zamrini acknowledged that he â€œdefinitelyâ€ 
  would have preferred to have been provided with Ms. Mâ€™s medical records.  
  [9] 
A review of the lay testimony supports the findings 
  of the trial court. Frank Eppes, a former circuit court judge and long-time 
  friend of Ms. M and her late brother, testified that he had been a frequent 
  overnight guest in their home when he held court in Fairfield County.Â  Judge 
  Eppes visited Ms. M an estimated ten times a year for thirty years preceding 
  1998.Â  He noted that Ms. M displayed photographs of Dr. Gaddy and his family 
  in her home, that she considered Dr. Gaddy her son and his children her grandchildren, 
  and that Ms. M enjoyed spending her holidays with the Gaddyâ€™s.
Judge Eppes observed that Ms. Mâ€™s home had become flea-infested 
  and full of junk.Â  Judge Eppes was well aware of Ms. Mâ€™s mental decline, even 
  to the point that he discontinued his overnight stays due to concerns that in 
  her confusion she might shoot him by accident.Â  His visits with Ms. M came to 
  an end in October 1998 because her confusion was so great that she no longer 
  recognized him.Â  It was Judge Eppesâ€™ firm conviction that Ms. M was permanently 
  and mentally incapacitated, and unable to understand legal documents.Â  Judge 
  Eppes finally observed that it was Dr. Gaddy, not Ms. Mâ€™s family, who had a 
  positive presence in her life.
Earl Wilkes, a former neighbor of Ms. Mâ€™s, began noticing 
  a decline in Ms. Mâ€™s health in 1996.Â  He recounted incidents where Ms. M lost 
  her car, locked herself out of her house, and seemed confused.Â  He said she 
  often appeared dirty and failed to take care of her personal hygiene.
Rosemary Wade, one of Ms. Mâ€™s caretakers from the fall 
  of 1997 until March 1999, testified that Ms. M did not understand what she watched 
  on television, could not remember trips or locations from which she had just 
  returned, and could not even order meals from a restaurant menu.Â  Wade witnessed 
  Ms. M suffer from nighttime agitation and wander from the house at night.Â  She 
  added that Ms. M required assistance to handle basic activities of daily living, 
  such as dressing herself, preparing meals, or bathing. 
David Byrd, a private investigator and process server 
  to whom Appellants had paid approximately $1,500 for investigative work, witnessed 
  Ms. Mâ€™s execution of the 1999 durable power of attorney and revocation.Â  Byrd 
  first met Ms. M at attorney Truslowâ€™s office on March 12, 1999.Â  Byrd admitted 
  that at the time he had no knowledge of her Alzheimerâ€™s disease, dementia, or 
  that Ms. M required constant care because of her dementia.Â  Nevertheless, Byrd 
  was willing to opine that Ms. M â€œunderstood the nature and effect of the action[s] 
  she was takingâ€ in signing the documents at Truslowâ€™s office. 
  [10] 
Ms. Mâ€™s January 2002 deposition was also admitted.Â  
  Ms. M claimed to pay her own bills and clean her own house, although she had 
  done neither since at least 1996.Â  She mistakenly claimed to drive her own car, 
  as well as her tractor.Â  Ms. M testified that she had no caretakers or aids, 
  and that she was capable of taking care of herself, although she had continuous 
  caretakers since 1996.Â  She claimed she had no attorney, although Cameron B. 
  Littlejohn, Jr., her attorney of record, was seated with her at the deposition.Â  
  She could not name the President of the United States, Vice President of the 
  United States, or the Governor of South Carolina.Â  Ms. M failed several simple 
  memory tests, including identifying three objects shown to her minutes before.Â  
  She could not recall where she ate lunch that day.Â  When asked if she may have 
  revoked the 1988 power of attorney, Ms. M replied, â€œGood Lord, what do you expect 
  me to remember something [sic] twelve years ago?Â  I donâ€™t remember what happened 
  yesterday.â€
The trial court issued its final order in May 2001.Â  
  Having determined that Dr. Gaddyâ€™s witnesses were â€œparticularly credible,â€ he 
  found, as do we, that â€œthe medical testimony clearly indicates â€¦ that [Ms. M] 
  lacked mental capacity to understand or to execute any kind of legal documents 
  in March 1999.â€Â  He based his conclusion on evidence that she suffered from 
  severe dementia caused by Alzheimerâ€™s disease, which he found progressively 
  destroys brain cells, resulting in the progressive loss of cognitive functioning. 

The trial court concluded that Ms. M lacked contractual 
  and testamentary capacity â€œfrom March 12, 1999 and continuously thereafter.â€Â  
  As a result, he invalidated the 1999 revocation of the 1988 durable power of 
  attorney and the 1988 Will.Â  He also invalidated the 1999 durable power of attorney, 
  and declared valid the 1988 durable power of attorney.Â  Finally, he awarded 
  Dr. Gaddy litigation expenses to be paid from Ms. Mâ€™s assets.
DISCUSSION
Since 1986, the South Carolina Legislature 
  has expressly authorized and sanctioned the use and efficacy of durable 
  powers of attorneys. [11] Â  
  S.C. General Assembly Act No. 539, Â§ 1.Â  Section 62-5-501 of the Code of Laws 
  of South Carolina (Supp. 2003) provides in part:

  (A)      Whenever a principal designates another his 
  attorney in fact by a power of attorney in writing and the writing contains 
  (1) the words â€œThis power of attorney is not affected by physical disability 
  or mental incompetence of the principal which renders the principal incapable 
  of managing his own estateâ€,â€¦ or (3) similar words showing the intent of the 
  principal that the authority conferred is exercisable notwithstanding his physical 
  disability or mental incompetence or either physical disability or mental incompetence, 
  the authority of the attorney in fact is exercisable by him as provided in the 
  power on behalf of the principal notwithstanding later physical disability or 
  mental incompetence of the principal â€¦

Upon the execution of a durable 
  power of attorney, the attorney-in-fact retains authority to act on the principalâ€™s 
  behalf notwithstanding the subsequent physical disability or mental incompetence 
  of the principal.Â  To honor this unmistakable legislative intent, it is incumbent 
  on courts to uphold a durable power of attorney unless the principal retains 
  contractual capacity to revoke the then existing durable power of attorney or 
  to execute a new power of attorney.Â  Otherwise, the very purpose of section 
  62-5-501 would be undermined.
Contractual Capacity
Â Appellants contend the trial court 
  erred in finding Ms. M was incompetent to execute the 1999 durable power of 
  attorney and revocation.Â  We disagree, and find the evidence compellingly supports 
  the findings of the trial court.Â  
â€œ[I]n order to execute or revoke a valid power of 
  attorney, the principal must possess contractual capacity.â€Â  Thames, 
  344 S.C. at 570, 544 S.E.2d at 857.Â  Contractual capacity is generally defined 
  as a personâ€™s ability to understand in a meaningful way, at the time the contract 
  is executed, the nature, scope and effect of the contract.Â  In re Nightingaleâ€™s 
  Estate, 182 S.C. 527, 541, 189 S.E.2d 890, 896 (1937).Â  Where, as here, 
  the mental condition of the principal is of a chronic nature, evidence of the 
  principalâ€™s prior or subsequent condition is admissible as bearing upon his 
  or her condition at the time the contract is executed.Â  53 Am. Jur. 2d Mentally 
  Impaired Persons Â§ 157 (1996).Â  In McCollum v. Banks, 213 S.C. 476, 
  483, 50 S.E.2d 199, 202 (1948), our supreme court held a testatorâ€™s insanity, 
  in order to invalidate a will, should be established at the time of execution, 
  unless the insanity is â€œof a permanent or chronic nature.â€Â  See also 
  In re Brazmanâ€™s Will, 172 S.C. 188, 194, 173 S.E. 623, 625 (1934) (stating 
  if the evidence shows the insanity is chronic, it is presumed to continue).
Here, the credible medical and lay testimony presented 
  compellingly indicates that Ms. M suffered from at least moderate to severe 
  dementia caused by Alzheimerâ€™s Disease, a chronic and permanent organic disease, 
  on March 12, 1999.Â  We are firmly persuaded that Ms. Mâ€™s dementia, chronic and 
  progressive in nature, clearly rendered her incapable of possessing contractual 
  capacity to revoke the 1988 durable power of attorney or execute the 1999 power 
  of attorney.Â  We find this conclusion inescapable based on the record before 
  us.
Specifically, the evidence supplied by Doctors 
  Carnes, Taylor and McClure established Ms. Mâ€™s history of debilitating dementia 
  dating back to 1996, as well as the progressive, chronic, organic, and irreversible 
  nature of the disease.Â  Although a patient suffering from such severe dementia 
  may at times appear normal, they opined such a patient could not make rational 
  decisions, understand the nature of his or her actions, or handle their business 
  or legal affairs.Â  The credible lay testimony of Judge Eppes, Earl Wilkes, and 
  Rosemary Wade provides forceful evidence corroborating the testimony ofÂ  these 
  three neurologists.
In contrast, the only expert medical testimony 
  supporting Appellantsâ€™ position that Ms. M possessed sufficient capacity to 
  execute or revoke a power of attorney came from their two medical experts, Drs. 
  Campbell and Zamrini.Â  As noted, Dr. Campbell, an internist, when asked if she 
  claimed â€œto have any expertise in the area of Alzheimerâ€™s disease or dementia,â€ 
  replied, â€œI donâ€™t.â€Â  Dr. Zamriniâ€™s testimony is similarly lacking, primarily 
  as a result of the false medical history provided to him by Appellants. 
Based on our view of the evidence, 
  we conclude that by at least March 12, 1999, and at all times thereafter, Ms. 
  M lacked contractual capacity because she suffered from severe dementia caused 
  by Alzheimerâ€™s disease, a chronic illness involving the irreversible degeneration 
  of brain cells. [12] Â  
Testamentary Capacity
Appellants assert the trial court 
  erred in addressing Ms. Mâ€™s testamentary capacity on March 12, 1999.Â  We reluctantly 
  agree, and vacate that portion of the trial courtâ€™s order finding Ms. M lacked 
  testamentary capacity on March 12, 1999.
Dr. Gaddy did not plead the issue 
  of Ms. Mâ€™s testamentary capacity.Â  In his complaint, he sought relief from the 
  attempted revocation of the 1988 power of attorney, not revocation of the 1988 
  Will.Â  The trial court addressed the issue of testamentary capacity on its own 
  volition because the revocations were contained in the same document, and because 
  it believed the best use of judicial resources favored disposing of all issues 
  in one action. We concur with the trial courtâ€™s sentiment to achieve finality 
  regarding testamentary capacity and to avoid further siphoning by Appellants 
  of Ms. Mâ€™s assets.Â  Having failed, however, to plead the matter of testamentary 
  capacity in the context of the purported revocation of the 1988 Will, we find 
  it was error for the trial court to address and decide the issue, especially 
  in light of Appellantsâ€™ objection at the commencement of the trial to the trial 
  courtâ€™s consideration of the matter.Â  We, therefore, vacate that portion of 
  the circuit court judgment concerning the issue of testamentary capacity. [13]   
Necessary Party
Appellants argue the trial courtâ€™s 
  decision must be vacated due to the absence of a necessary party, Ms. M.Â  We 
  disagree.Â  
We find Ms. M was adequately 
  represented in this action because Dr. Gaddy brought this action as Ms. Mâ€™s 
  attorney-in-fact, and therefore, the action was brought on her behalf.Â  â€œWhenever 
  a[n]â€¦incompetent person has a representative, such as a general guardian, committee, 
  conservator or other like fiduciary, the representative may sue or defend on 
  behalf of the ... incompetent person ....â€Â  Rule 17(c), SCRCP.Â Â  Ms. M was incompetent 
  prior to and at the time Dr. Gaddy brought this action.Â  Therefore, under Rule 
  17(c), Ms. M was not required to be individually named as a party in this action. 
  [14] Â  
We further note Appellants never 
  raised this issue in the trial court. 
  [15] Â  Appellants, in an attempt to circumvent issue preservation rules, 
  seek to recast the argument as one of subject matter jurisdiction by claiming 
  that Ms. M is an indispensable party under Rule 19, SCRCP.Â  Ms. Mâ€™s incompetence 
  involves her â€œcapacity to sue or be suedâ€ as the real party in interest which 
  invokes Rule 17.Â  â€œRule 17â€¦ clearly indicates the question of real party in 
  interest does not involve subject matter jurisdiction.â€Â Â Â  Bardoon Properties, 
  NV v. Eidolon Corp., 326 S.C. 166, 170, 485 S.E.2d 371, 373 (1997). 
  [16] Â  We conclude the issue is not preserved for our review.Â Â  See 
  Toal, Vafai, and Muckenfuss, Appellate Practice in South Carolina at 
  63 (2d Ed. 2002) (citing Tupper v. Dorchester County, 326 S.C. 318, 487 
  S.E.2d 187 (1997) for the proposition that issue preservation requires â€œthat 
  the objection in the trial court must have been made by the party who raises 
  the issue in the appellate court.â€).Â  
Litigation Expenses 
Appellants claim the trial court erred in authorizing 
  Dr. Gaddy to reimburse his litigation expenses from Ms. Mâ€™s assets. We affirm 
  in result.
The 1988 power of attorney specifically authorizes 
  Dr. Gaddy to â€œinstitute, prosecute â€¦ or otherwise engage in litigation involving 
  me, my property or any interests of mine; â€¦ to employ â€¦ attorneys-at-law â€¦ for 
  the proper administration of my property â€¦ to pay and adjust debts incurred 
  by me or by my attorney-in-fact in connection with any power authorized hereunder.â€Â  
  Because we find Dr. Gaddy was acting on behalf of Ms. M as her attorney-in-fact 
  when he instituted this action, the language of the 1988 power of attorney, 
  which provides for payment of such litigation expenses, controls.Â  Therefore, 
  we affirm the trial courtâ€™s award of litigation expenses to Dr. Gaddy based 
  on the language in the 1988 power of attorney.Â  See Iâ€™On, L.L.C. v. 
  Town of Mt. Pleasant, 338 S.C. 406, 417, 526 S.E.2d 716, 722 (2000) (stating 
  that the appellate court may affirm for any reason appearing in the record).Â  
  We reiterate that Dr. Gaddy was acting appropriately and within his fiduciary 
  capacity in bringing this action. [17]   
Propriety of Judge Hughston Serving as Trial Judge
Appellants argue that Judge Hughston 
  lacked jurisdiction and impartiality.Â  These contentions, asserted for the first 
  time on appeal, are utterly specious.Â  In light of the serious nature of these 
  allegations, we elect to review the procedural history.Â  
Judge Hughston was assigned by South Carolinaâ€™s 
  Chief Justice, through the Office of Court Administration, to a common pleas 
  nonjury term in the sixth judicial circuit in October 1999.Â  During that term 
  of court, pending motions in this case came before Judge Hughston, one of which 
  was a motion to designate the case as complex.Â  Judge Hughston recognized that 
  designation of a case as complex is generally a function of the chief administrative 
  judge for the circuit.Â  It was observed, however, that the resident circuit 
  judges of the sixth circuit, including the then current administrative judge, 
  were disqualified due to conflicts.Â  Consequently, at the request of the parties, 
  Judge Hughston agreed to resolve the motions, handle pretrial matters and preside 
  over the trial.
The trial commenced on February 19, 2001.Â  
  Judge Hughston was assigned by the Chief Justice to preside over the February 
  19 term of court.Â  Following four days of testimony, Judge Hughston took the 
  matter under advisement and issued his final order on May 2, 2001.Â  
From Judge Hughstonâ€™s initial involvement 
  in this case in October of 1999 through the issuance of the final order, the 
  record contains not the slightest hint of a challenge to Judge Hughstonâ€™s authority 
  or impartiality.Â  Moreover, Appellants filed a motion to alter the judgment 
  on May 18, 2001, containing forty-six grounds of error, none of which is directed 
  against Judge Hughstonâ€™s authority or impartiality.Â  In sum, at the trial level, 
  Appellants never took exception to either Judge Hughstonâ€™s involvement 
  in or handling of this case.Â  
On appeal, we hear for the first time 
  that Judge Hughston was an â€œadvocate in these proceedings,â€ and that his involvement 
  â€œaffected his ability to impartially try the case.â€Â  The simple response is 
  that this court will not address matters not raised and ruled upon in the trial 
  court.Â  Wilder Corp. v. Wilkie, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 
  (1998) (â€œIt is axiomatic that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on 
  appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be 
  preserved for appellate review.â€).Â  In an effort to circumvent the issue preservation 
  rule, a fundamental principle of appellate procedure with which Appellants are 
  familiar, we are once again confronted with a subject matter jurisdiction claim.Â  
  We reject this desperate, eleventh-hour attack on Judge Hughston and the assertion 
  that he lacked jurisdiction to preside over this case.Â  His authority to render 
  judgment is beyond question, and if Appellants desired his recusal, they should 
  have done so in a proper and timely manner.Â  See Parker v. Shecut, 
  340 S.C. 460, 496-97, 531 S.E.2d 546, 566 (Ct. App. 2000) (holding the issue 
  of recusal of the trial judge, to be preserved for appellate review, must be 
  raised in the trial court).
Lifting of the Automatic Stay
On October 10, 2001, a panel of this court enforced 
  an automatic stay of the trial courtâ€™s order, and â€œrevivedâ€ the March 12, 1999 
  revocation of the 1998 durable power of attorney, as well as the 1999 power 
  of attorney naming Appellants as Ms. Mâ€™s attorneys-in-fact.Â  With our decision 
  today, we immediately lift the automatic stay as provided in the October 10, 
  2001 order and Rule 225, SCACR. Dr. Gaddy shall immediately resume his responsibilities 
  as the legal, duly authorized attorney-in-fact for Ms. M.Â  Appellants George 
  G. Douglass, III, and William P. Sherrod are hereby enjoined from conducting 
  any business on behalf of Ms. M.Â  Additionally, Appellants George G. Douglass, 
  III, and William P. Sherrod shall within five days of receipt hereof deliver 
  to Dr. Gaddy, through counsel, all documents pertaining to Ms. M, including 
  all financial records, and as provided in the decree of the trial courtâ€™s final 
  order of May 2, 2001.Â  
CONCLUSION
The very idea of a durable power of attorney is to protect 
  the principal should he or she become incapacitated.Â  This case is precisely 
  the type of situation for which the durable power of attorney is intended.Â  
  On March 12, 1999, Ms. M, due to her chronic and severe dementia, lacked capacity 
  to revoke the 1988 durable power of attorney and execute the 1999 power of attorney, 
  and the evidence in this regard is overwhelming. In so holding, we return to 
  Dr. Gaddy his fiduciary obligations to Ms. M, which he faithfully discharged 
  prior to Appellantsâ€™ regrettable involvement.Â  The decision of the trial court 
  is 
AFFIRMED IN PART AND VACATED IN PART. 
 HEARN, C.J., and HOWARD, J., concur.

 
   
    [1]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  We recognize that Ms. Mâ€™s true identity may be discovered 
    through public records and otherwise.Â  We merely desire to preserve some vestige 
    of respect and decency for this elderly woman as she faces the end of her 
    lifeâ€™s journey in the grip of debilitating dementia caused by Alzheimerâ€™s 
    disease.

 
   
    [2]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  Dr. Gaddy has continuously practiced medicine in Fairfield 
    County since 1981, during which time he served as chief of staff at a local 
    hospital and president of the South Carolina Medical Association.

 
   
    [3]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  At one time, Ms. Mâ€™s assets included a 200-acre farm in Fairfeld 
    County, on which her home was situated, securities, and a checking account 
    containing approximately $339,000 in cash.Â  

 
   
    [4]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  The trial court found that Heller â€œhad at least some bias 
    in favor ofâ€ Appellants because Dr. Gaddy had declined her repeated requests 
    to be switched from her weekend shift to a weekday shift.Â  Once Appellants 
    assumed control of Ms. Mâ€™s affairs in March 1999, they rewarded Heller with 
    the shift she wanted and several pay raises.

 
   
    [5]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  Ms. M did not schedule the appointment with Truslow.Â  It is 
    not our intent to assign nefarious motives to Truslow, for he was simply a 
    pawn in Appellantsâ€™ scheme to gain control over Ms. Mâ€™s assets.Â  Indeed, Truslow 
    admitted that he â€œmight have done things differentlyâ€ had he known the truth 
    about Ms. Mâ€™s condition. Â When asked if â€œthereâ€™s some things that you 
    now know that you did not know when you [sic] executed the revocationsâ€ Truslow 
    responded, â€œThatâ€™s an understatement.â€

 
   
     
    [6]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  The resident judges of the sixth judicial circuit, where Fairfield 
    County is located, were disqualified due to conflicts.Â  

 
   
    [7]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  Dr. Carnes found nothing to suggest Ms. M suffered from brain 
    tumors or stroke.Â  He further determined that her medications or outside stress 
    did not affect his diagnosis.

 
   
    [8]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  Dr. Campbell testified that she had examined Ms. M approximately 
    eight times since March 1999, but limited her testimony to the findings from 
    her examinations in that month.

 
   
    [9]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  In fairness to Dr. Zamrini, he was misled by Appellants, similar 
    to their deceit of attorney Truslow.Â  Dr. Zamriniâ€™s report reveals Appellantsâ€™ 
    efforts to recast the medical history of Ms. M.Â Â  For example, Appellants 
    desired that Dr. Zamrini believe that Ms. Mâ€™s dementia was first noticed in 
    1996 with an â€œabrupt onset.â€ Â A review of the medical records establishes 
    the progressive nature of Ms. Mâ€™s dementia.Â  When confronted on cross-examination 
    with the fact that short-term memory loss was documented in 1993, Dr. Zamrini 
    could only respond, â€œI was not aware of that.â€

 
   
     
    [10]  Â Â Â Â Â  The trial court assigned little weight to Byrdâ€™s testimony, 
    primarily as a result of his financial ties to Appellants.Â  Our assessment 
    of Byrdâ€™s testimony is the same.

 
   
    [11] Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  â€œDurableâ€ is a term of art signifying that a power of attorney 
    survives the principalâ€™s disability.Â  See Â 3 Am.Jur.2d Agency Â§ 28 
    (1986).

 
   
    [12]  Â Â Â Â Â  We in no way suggest that all people suffering some degree 
    of dementia, from Alzheimerâ€™s disease or otherwise, invariably lack contractual 
    capacity.Â  We hold that the subject of contractual capacity of 
    one suffering dementia should be decided in a fact-driven, individualized 
    manner.Â  There may well be situations where an individual at the onset of 
    Alzheimerâ€™s disease, or in the early stages of dementia, may retain sufficient 
    capacity to contract.Â  This, however, is not such a case, for Ms. Mâ€™s capacity 
    to contract had long since passed when her previously absent family members 
    entered her life and attempted to gain control of her assets.

 
   
    [13]  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Having disposed of this issue on the ground of failure 
    to plead, we do not address the jurisdictional question whether oneâ€™s testamentary 
    capacity may be determined prior to death.

 
   
    [14]  Â Â Â Â Â  From a legal and practical standpoint, it is beyond challenge 
    (even from Appellantsâ€™ view of the evidence) that Ms. M was incompetent when 
    the case was tried.Â  That undeniable fact essentially renders this issue moot, 
    for Ms. M was either represented by Dr. Gaddy pursuant to the 1988 power of 
    attorney or by Appellants pursuant to the 1999 power of attorney.

 
   
    [15]  Â Â Â Â Â  At trial, Appellants only objected to the inclusion of the 
    word â€œpurportedâ€ in the caption when listing their names as Ms. Mâ€™s attorneys-in-fact.

 
  Â  
    [16] Â Â Â Â Â  For a more thorough discussion on the lack of a relationship 
    between a partyâ€™s status as a real party in interest and subject matter jurisdiction, 
    see Bardoon Properties, NV v. Eidolon Corp., supra.

 
   
    [17] Â Â Â Â Â Â  We find it extremely troubling that by May 2001, Appellants 
    had paid from Ms. Mâ€™s funds approximately $160,000 for attorney fees and costs 
    they incurred.Â  Appellants did so without court authorization, as they apparently 
    believed they could do so unilaterally under the language of the 1999 power 
    of attorney.Â  Incredibly, Appellants criticize Dr. Gaddy for incurring approximately 
    $90,000 in legal fees, while they make no mention of their unapologetic invasion 
    into Ms. Mâ€™s funds to pay their legal fees.

title: State v. Douglas
description: In this case, Appellant appeals her convictions for murder and armed robbery as well as her sentence for murder.  Appellant contends the trial judge erred in admitting the following evidence:  (1) testimony concerning her inquiry about procuring a life insurance policy for the victim; (2) a secretly recorded conversation with an investigator; and (3) items seized during the investigation.  She further asserts the judge erred in:  (1) denying her motions for a directed verdict as to the charges of murder and armed robbery; (2) sentencing her to life imprisonment for the charge of murder; and (3) denying her motion for a new trial.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Helen Marie Douglas, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Colleton County
Â A. Victor Rawl, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3772
Heard December 10, 2003 â€“ Filed April 
  5, 2004
Withdrawn, Substituted and Refiled May 
  21, 2004

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, 
  AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Jack B. Swerling, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, 
  all of Columbia; David Michael Pascoe, Jr. and Jonathan S. Gasser, both of Columbia, 
  for Respondent.
      
    
  

CURETON, A.J.:Â  Helen Marie Douglas was 
  convicted of murder and armed robbery.Â  She received concurrent sentences of 
  life imprisonment for murder and thirty years imprisonment for armed robbery.Â  
  Douglas appeals.Â  We affirm in part, reverse in part, and remand.
FACTS
Douglas and her husband, Ronnie Douglas, 
  owned two houses in Colleton County.Â  Douglas was in the habit of staying at 
  the river house, and Ronnie usually stayed at the house in town.Â  On the morning 
  of November 3, 1997, Douglas knocked on a neighborâ€™s door across the street 
  from the town house, explaining that something had happened to Ronnie.Â  The 
  neighbor called 911 and went with Douglas to the town house, which she stated 
  appeared to be ransacked.Â  The neighbor also testified that Ronnieâ€™s head was 
  surrounded by blood and he did not have a pulse.Â  Douglas and the neighbor then 
  left the house, and the neighbor called Douglasâ€™s two sons.Â  Police arrived 
  at the scene and determined there was no evidence of forced entry.Â Â  A treating 
  paramedic testified that Ronnie was dead and appeared to have a gunshot wound 
  to the head.  [1]   
Douglas gave two statements to police 
  in the days following Ronnieâ€™s murder.Â  On each occasion, officers advised Douglas 
  of her Miranda [2]  rights before openly tape-recording her statements.Â  
  Douglas later called Investigator Stanfield, the investigating officer, and 
  asked him to come speak to her at the river house.Â  The officers decided to 
  send Stanfield out to the house with a hidden tape recorder.Â  When he met with 
  Douglas he did not advise her of her Miranda rights.Â  Though Douglas 
  did not make any incriminating comments about Ronnieâ€™s murder, she did admit 
  that she had lied to the police about having an extramarital affair at the time 
  of Ronnieâ€™s death.Â  Though finding the secret tape-recording a â€œvery, very, 
  very poor practice,â€ the trial judge allowed admission of a redacted version
