THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Jill H. McCall,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
State Farm Mutual Automobile Insurance Company, Kimberly J. Sullivan 
        and Marcia Hardy,        Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Oconee County
J. Cordell Maddox, Jr., Circuit 
  Court Judge

Opinion No. 3803
Submitted May 12, 2004 â€“ Filed May 
  24, 2004

AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED


  
    
      
Richard L. Whitt, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Michael T. Cole and Charles R. Norris, of Charleston, for Respondents.
      
    
  

ANDERSON, J.:Â  This suit arises as a result 
  of an insurance dispute.Â  Appellant contends her late husbandâ€™s automobile insurance 
  policy either contained an automobile death indemnity provision or would have 
  if not for Respondentsâ€™ negligence.Â Â  The circuit court granted Respondentsâ€™ 
  motion for summary judgment as to the South Carolina parties and applied the 
  South Carolina door closing statute to dismiss the case.Â  We affirm as modified. 
  [1] 
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Brian and Jill McCall lived 
  in North Carolina and had a State Farm automobile insurance policy, which contained 
  an automobile death indemnity provision.Â  This North Carolina automobile insurance 
  policy was obtained through Tom Sawyer Agency.Â  In February 2000, Brian and 
  Jill McCall separated and Brian McCall moved to South Carolina.Â  In South Carolina, 
  Brian McCall contacted Sullivan Insurance Agency and acquired State Farm automobile 
  insurance for his vehicle.Â  Brian McCall purchased a State Farm policy containing 
  comprehensive and collision coverage, but not an automobile death indemnity 
  provision.Â  Brian McCall signed a policy application that explicitly omitted 
  the automobile death indemnity provision.
Jill McCall informed Tom Sawyer Agency that she 
  and Brian McCall had separated.Â  As a result, Tom Sawyer Agency removed the 
  automobile death indemnity coverage from the policy.Â  Tragically, in March 2000, 
  Brian McCall died in an automobile accident.Â  Appellant, Jill McCall, seeks 
  an automobile death indemnity from State Farm; however, the insurer denies one 
  existed at the time of the accident.Â  Appellant brought causes of action for 
  bad faith refusal to pay, negligent supervision, breach of contract, respondeat 
  superior, unfair trade practices, and negligence against State Farm and the 
  South Carolina agents that sold Brian McCall his policy.
It is undisputed that the North Carolina policy 
  originally contained an automobile death indemnity provision.Â  Appellant asserts 
  the South Carolina agents erred by omitting the death indemnity provision contained 
  in the North Carolina policy when they wrote the South Carolina policy.
In February 2002, the circuit court heard Respondentsâ€™ 
  motion for summary judgment and dismissed the two South Carolina insurance agents, 
  Marcia Hardy and Kimberly Sullivan, as well as any claims arising from the South 
  Carolina policy.Â  However, the court did grant Appellant thirty days to amend 
  her complaint to allege a cause of action arising under the North Carolina policy.Â  
  No appeal was taken from this Order.Â  Appellant filed an amended complaint restating 
  her claims as arising under the North Carolina policy. 
In the amended complaint, Appellant 
  maintained the South Carolina agents caused the North Carolina automobile death 
  indemnity provision to be cancelled and they failed to notify Brian McCall of 
  the cancellation or provide him a refund of the unearned premium.Â  Respondents 
  deny the South Carolina agents had any involvement with the cancellation of 
  the North Carolina automobile death indemnity provision. 
In October 2002, the circuit court heard 
  Respondentsâ€™ motion for summary judgment as to the claims in the amended complaint.Â  
  Again, the South Carolina insurance agents were dismissed from the case.Â  In 
  addition, the court applied the door closing statute, section 15-5-150 of the 
  South Carolina Code, to dismiss the suit because neither Jill McCall nor State 
  Farm is a resident of South Carolina.Â  Appellant argues the circuit court erred 
  in granting summary judgment and in applying section 15-5-150 to the North Carolina 
  claims.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œSummary judgment is appropriate only when â€˜the 
  pleadings, depositions, answers to interrogatories, and admissions on file, 
  together with the affidavits, if any, show that there is no genuine issue as 
  to any material fact and that the moving party is entitled to a judgment as 
  a matter of law.â€™â€Â Â  Trivelas v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Transp., 348 
  S.C. 125, 130, 558 S.E.2d 271, 273 (Ct. App. 2001) (quoting Rule 56(c), SCRCP); 
  see also Tupper v. Dorchester County, 326 S.C. 318, 325, 487 S.E.2d 
  187, 191 (1997) (â€œSummary judgment is proper where there is no genuine issue 
  as to any material fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter 
  of law.â€).
â€œThe party seeking summary judgment has the burden 
  of clearly establishing the absence of a genuine issue of material fact.â€Â  McNair 
  v. Rainsford, 330 S.C. 332, 342, 499 S.E.2d 488, 493 (Ct. App. 1998) (citing 
  Baughman v. American Tel. & Tel. Co., 306 S.C. 101, 410 S.E.2d 537 
  (1991); Standard Fire Ins. Co. v. Marine Contracting & Towing Co., 
  301 S.C. 418, 392 S.E.2d 460 (1990)).Â  â€œIn determining whether any triable issues 
  of fact exist, the evidence and all inferences which can be reasonably drawn 
  therefrom must be viewed in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party.â€ 
  Lanham v. Blue Cross & Blue Shield of South Carolina, Inc., 349 S.C. 
  356, 361-62, 563 S.E.2d 331, 333 (2002) (citing Summer v. Carpenter, 
  328 S.C. 36, 492 S.E.2d 55 (1997)).Â  â€œSummary judgment is not appropriate where 
  further inquiry into the facts of the case is desirable to clarify the application 
  of the law.â€Â  Id. at 362, 563 S.E.2d at 333 (citing Brockbank v. Best 
  Capital Corp., 341 S.C. 372, 534 S.E.2d 688 (2000)).Â  
â€œAll ambiguities, conclusions, and inferences arising 
  from the evidence must be construed most strongly against the moving party.â€Â  
  Hall v. Fedor, 349 S.C. 169, 173, 561 S.E.2d 654, 656 (Ct. App. 2002) 
  (citing Young v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Corrections, 333 S.C. 714, 511 
  S.E.2d 413 (Ct. App. 1999)).Â  â€œEven when there is no dispute as to evidentiary 
  facts, but only as to the conclusions or inferences to be drawn from them, summary 
  judgment should be denied.â€Â  Id. at 173-74, 561 S.E.2d at 656.Â  â€œBecause 
  it is a drastic remedy, summary judgment should be cautiously invoked so no 
  person will be improperly deprived of a trial of the disputed factual issues.â€Â  
  Murray v. Holnam, Inc., 344 S.C. 129, 138, 542 S.E.2d 743, 747 (Ct. App. 
  2001) (citing Carolina Alliance for Fair Employment v. South Carolina Depâ€™t 
  of Labor, Licensing & Regulation, 337 S.C. 476, 523 S.E.2d 795 (1999)).Â Â  

â€œAn appellate court reviews the granting of summary 
  judgment under the same standard applied by the trial court pursuant to Rule 
  56, SCRCP.â€Â  Murray, 344 S.C. at 138, 542 S.E.2d at 747 (citing Brockbank, 
  341 S.C. 372, 534 S.E.2d 688; Wells v. City of Lynchburg, 331 S.C. 296, 
  501 S.E.2d 746 (Ct. App. 1998)).
LAW/ANALYSIS

  1.     Motion for Summary Judgment  

Appellant contends the circuit court erred in granting 
  Respondentsâ€™ motion for summary judgment.Â  Appellant argues there existed both 
  genuine issues of material fact and a disputed matter of law.Â  Specifically, 
  Appellant points to alleged inconsistencies in the various affidavits presented 
  to the court by Respondents and to an admission that Appellantâ€™s husband was 
  provided a quote for a South Carolina policy containing an automobile death 
  indemnity provision.Â  
However, these allegations of factual inconsistencies 
  and admission disregard the procedural and factual predicate of the suit.Â  Appellant 
  neglects the fact that the unappealed February 2002 Order is the law of the 
  case.Â  While affidavits were submitted stating the South Carolina agents, Marcia 
  Hardy and Kimberly Sullivan, did not have any involvement in the cancellation 
  of the automobile death indemnity from the North Carolina policy, there is a 
  complete dearth of any evidence that they were involved in the cancellation.Â  


A.Â  The Law of the Case

An unappealed order becomes the law of the case.Â  
  Tolerâ€™s Cove Homeowners Assâ€™n v. Trident Const. Co., Inc., 355 S.C. 605, 
  610, 586 S.E.2d 581, 584 (2003); Charleston Lumber Co. v. Miller Housing 
  Corp., 338 S.C. 171, 174-75, 525 S.E.2d 869, 871 (2000); Priester v. 
  Brabham, 230 S.C. 201, 203, 95 S.E.2d 167, 168 (1956); Wooten v. Wooten, 
  354 S.C. 242, 250, 580 S.E.2d 765, 769 (Ct. App. 2003); Larimore v. Carolina 
  Power & Light, 340 S.C. 438, 445, 531 S.E.2d 535, 538-39 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  
  â€œA portion of a judgment that is not appealed presents no issue for determination 
  by the reviewing court and constitutes, rightly or wrongly, the law of the case.â€Â  
  Austin v. Specialty Transp. Servs., ___ S.C. ___, ___, 594 S.E.2d 867, 
  ___ (Ct. App. 2004).
On April 8, 2002, the circuit court signed an order 
  dismissing Marcia Hardy and Kimberly Sullivan from the case, stating â€œthere 
  is no genuine issue of material fact as to the plaintiffâ€™s claim under or related 
  to the South Carolina policy and, therefore, the plaintiffâ€™s claims related 
  to that policy and to the State Farm insurance agents involved in the issuance 
  of that policy are dismissed with prejudice.â€Â  Appellant did not appeal, but 
  filed an amended complaint as allowed by the Order.Â  Therefore, the ruling by 
  the circuit court is the law of the case.
The April 8, 2002 Order dismissed the South Carolina 
  agents.Â  Appellant tried to avoid this Order by amending the complaint to allege 
  the South Carolina agents caused the North Carolina automobile death indemnity 
  provision to be cancelled and failed to notify Brian McCall of the cancellation 
  or provide him a refund of the unearned premium.Â  In the initial complaint, 
  the Appellant asserted the South Carolina agents erred by omitting the death 
  indemnity provision contained in the North Carolina policy.
Appellant relies on this difference in verbiage 
  to suggest she is advancing different actions in the first and amended complaint.Â  
  However, the result under each is the sameâ€”no automobile death indemnity provision 
  exists.Â  This similarity is reinforced by Jill McCallâ€™s affidavit submitted 
  during the second summary judgment motion hearing:Â  â€œThe change in coverage 
  on the North Carolina State Farm Insurance policy, caused by the issuance of 
  the new South Carolina State Farm Insurance policy, had the same result as canceling 
  the death indemnity coverage under the North Carolina State Farm Insurance Policy.â€Â  
  During the second summary judgment hearing, Appellantâ€™s counsel summarized that 
  â€œsomething happened between the North Carolina agents and the South Carolina 
  agents that caused coverage to lap[se] under that North Carolina policy.â€
Veritably, any difference in argument 
  advanced against the South Carolina agents in the initial and amended complaint 
  is nothing more than semantic.Â  In both complaints, Appellant essentially argues 
  the South Carolina agentsâ€™ omission of the death indemnity provision had the 
  effect of canceling the provision.Â  The April 8, 2002 Order dismissed this claim.Â  
  Because that Order was not appealed, a challenge on this point is not properly 
  before this court.

  B.     Summary 
  Judgment Proceeding  

During the summary judgment motion, there were 
  four affidavits before the circuit court that stated the South Carolina agents 
  had no involvement in the cancellation of the North Carolina death indemnity 
  policy.Â  These included affidavits from agents Marcia Hardy and Kimberly Sullivan, 
  which denied any involvement in canceling the death indemnity provision.Â  Another 
  affidavit came from Audrey Martens, a State Farm employee in the underwriting 
  department, who reported the death indemnity provision was removed as a result 
  of a change sent to State Farm underwriting from Tom Sawyer Agency.Â  Finally, 
  there is an affidavit from Judith Sawyer, of Tom Sawyer Agency, stating that 
  after the agency learned of the McCallsâ€™ separation, the agency removed the 
  death indemnity provision from the North Carolina policy as a result of the 
  separation.Â  The assertion that the provision was removed at the instruction 
  of Tom Sawyer Agency after they learned of the McCallâ€™s separation is supported 
  by the fact that Appellant admits to advising Judith Sawyer that the couple 
  had separated.
â€œOnce the party moving for summary judgment 
  meets the initial burden of showing an absence of evidentiary support for the 
  opponentâ€™s case, the opponent cannot rest on mere allegations or denials contained 
  in the pleadings.Â  Rather, the non-moving party must come forward with specific 
  facts showing there is a genuine issue for trial.â€Â  Hansen v. United Serv. 
  Auto. Assâ€™n, 350 S.C. 62, 67, 565 S.E.2d 114, 116 (Ct. App. 2002); see 
  also Humana Hosp.-Bayside v. Lightle, 305 S.C. 214, 216-17, 407 S.E.2d 
  637, 638 (1991).Â  Because four affidavits state the South Carolina agents were 
  not involved, Appellant cannot simply rest on her pleadings.Â  Appellant submitted 
  one affidavit for the circuit courtâ€™s consideration, but this affidavit does 
  not address with any specificity the alleged actions the South Carolina agents 
  took to cancel the death indemnity provision.Â  Appellant submitted no evidence 
  to support her conclusion that the South Carolina actors had any involvement 
  with the cancellation of the automobile death indemnity provision; apodictically, 
  a consideration of the grant of summary judgment on its merits would yield the 
  same result reached by simply applying the law of the case.

  2.     Door closing statute  

After the circuit court determined the claims against 
  the South Carolina agents should be dismissed with prejudice, the remaining
